column1: Alopochen aegyptiacahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian%20goose"Ancient Egyptian deities are the gods and goddesses worshipped in ancient Egypt. The beliefs and rituals surrounding these gods formed the core of ancient Egyptian religion
column2: which emerged sometime in prehistory. Deities represented natural forces and phenomena
column3: and the Egyptians supported and appeased them through offerings and rituals so that these forces would continue to function according to maat
column4: or divine order. After the founding of the Egyptian state around 3100 BC
column5: the authority to perform these tasks was controlled by the pharaoh
column6: who claimed to be the gods' representative and managed the temples where the rituals were carried out.

column1: The gods' complex characteristics were expressed in myths and in intricate relationships between deities: family ties
column2: loose groups and hierarchies
column3: and combinations of separate gods into one. Deities' diverse appearances in art‚Äîas animals
column4: humans
column5: objects
column6: and combinations of different forms‚Äîalso alluded
column7: through symbolism
column8: to their essential features.

column2: various gods were said to hold the highest position in divine society
column3: including the solar deity Ra
column4: the mysterious god Amun
column5: and the mother goddess Isis. The highest deity was usually credited with the creation of the world and often connected with the life-giving power of the sun. Some scholars have argued
column6: based in part on Egyptian writings
column7: that the Egyptians came to recognize a single divine power that lay behind all things and was present in all the other deities. Yet they never abandoned their original polytheistic view of the world
column8: except possibly during the era of Atenism in the 14th century BC
column9: when official religion focused exclusively on an abstract solar deity
column10: the Aten.

column1: Gods were assumed to be present throughout the world
column2: capable of influencing natural events and the course of human lives. People interacted with them in temples and unofficial shrines
column3: for personal reasons as well as for larger goals of state rites. Egyptians prayed for divine help
column4: used rituals to compel deities to act
column5: and called upon them for advice. Humans' relations with their gods were a fundamental part of Egyptian society.

column1: The beings in ancient Egyptian tradition who might be labeled as deities are difficult to count. Egyptian texts list the names of many deities whose nature is unknown and make vague
column2: indirect references to other gods who are not even named. The Egyptologist James P. Allen estimates that more than 1

column4: whereas his colleague Christian Leitz says there are ""thousands upon thousands"" of gods.The Egyptian language's terms for these beings were n·πØr

The hieroglyphs that were used as ideograms and determinatives in writing these words show some of the traits that the Egyptians connected with divinity. The most common of these signs is a flag flying from a pole. Similar objects were placed at the entrances of temples

column22: which modern scholars often call ""demons"". Egyptian religious art also depicts places

column1: The first written evidence of deities in Egypt comes from the Early Dynastic Period (c. 3100‚Äì2686 BC). Deities must have emerged sometime in the preceding Predynastic Period (before 3100 BC) and grown out of prehistoric religious beliefs. Predynastic artwork depicts a variety of animal and human figures. Some of these images
column2: such as stars and cattle
column3: are reminiscent of important features of Egyptian religion in later times
column4: but in most cases
column5: there is not enough evidence to say whether the images are connected with deities. As  Egyptian society grew more sophisticated
column6: clearer signs of religious activity appeared. The earliest known temples appeared in the last centuries of the predynastic era
column7: along with images that resemble the iconographies of known deities: the falcon that represents Horus and several other gods
column8: the crossed arrows that stand for Neith
column9: and the enigmatic ""Set animal"" that represents Set.

column1: Many Egyptologists and anthropologists have suggested theories about how the gods developed in these early times. Gustave J√©quier
column2: for instance
column3: thought the Egyptians first revered primitive fetishes
column4: then deities in animal form
column5: and finally deities in human form
column6: whereas Henri Frankfort argued that the gods must have been envisioned in human form from the beginning. Some of these theories are now regarded as too simplistic
column7: and more current ones
column8: such as Siegfried Morenz' hypothesis that deities emerged as humans began to distinguish themselves from and personify their environment
column9: are difficult to prove.Predynastic Egypt originally consisted of small
column10: independent villages. Because many deities in later times were strongly tied to particular towns and regions
column11: many scholars have suggested that the pantheon formed as disparate communities coalesced into larger states
column12: spreading and intermingling the worship of the old local deities. Others have argued that the most important predynastic gods were
column13: like other elements of Egyptian culture
column14: present all across the country despite its political divisions.The final step in the formation of Egyptian religion was the unification of Egypt
column15: in which rulers from Upper Egypt made themselves pharaohs of the entire country. These sacred kings and their subordinates assumed the right to interact with the gods
column16: and kingship became the unifying focus of the religion.New deities continued to emerge after this transformation. Some important deities such as Isis and Amun are not known to have appeared until the Old Kingdom (c. 2686‚Äì2181 BC). Places and concepts could inspire the creation of a deity to represent them
column17: and deities were sometimes created to serve as opposite-sex counterparts to established gods or goddesses. Kings were said to be divine
column18: although only a few continued to be worshipped long after their deaths. Some non-royal humans were said to have the favor of the gods and were venerated accordingly. This veneration was usually short-lived
column19: but the court architects Imhotep and Amenhotep son of Hapu were regarded as gods centuries after their lifetimes
column20: as were some other officials.Through contact with neighboring civilizations
column21: the Egyptians also adopted foreign deities. Dedun
column22: who is first mentioned in the Old Kingdom
column23: may have come from Nubia
column24: and Baal
column25: Anat
column26: and Astarte
column27: among others
column28: were adopted from Canaanite religion during the New Kingdom (c. 1550‚Äì1070 BC). In Greek and Roman times
column29: from 332 BC to the early centuries AD
column30: deities from across the Mediterranean world were revered in Egypt
column31: but the native gods remained
column32: and they often absorbed the cults of these newcomers into their own worship.

column1: Modern knowledge of Egyptian beliefs about the gods is mostly drawn from religious writings produced by the nation's scribes and priests. These people were the elite of Egyptian society and were very distinct from the general populace
column2: most of whom were illiterate. Little is known about how well this broader population knew or understood the sophisticated ideas that the elite developed. Commoners' perceptions of the divine may have differed from those of the priests. The populace may
column3: for example
column4: have mistaken the religion's symbolic statements about the gods and their actions for literal truth. But overall
column5: what little is known about popular religious belief is consistent with the elite tradition. The two traditions form a largely cohesive vision of the gods and their nature.

column1: Most Egyptian deities represent natural or social phenomena. The gods were generally said to be immanent in these phenomena‚Äîto be present within nature. The types of phenomena they represented include physical places and objects as well as abstract concepts and forces. The god Shu was the deification of all the world's air; the goddess Meretseger oversaw a limited region of the earth
column2: the Theban Necropolis; and the god Sia personified the abstract notion of perception. Major gods were often involved in several types of phenomena. For instance
column3: Khnum was the god of Elephantine Island in the midst of the Nile
column4: the river that was essential to Egyptian civilization. He was credited with producing the annual Nile flood that fertilized the country's farmland. Perhaps as an outgrowth of this life-giving function
column5: he was said to create all living things
column6: fashioning their bodies on a potter's wheel. Gods could share the same role in nature; Ra
column7: Atum
column8: Khepri
column9: Horus
column10: and other deities acted as sun gods. Despite their diverse functions
column11: most gods had an overarching role in common: maintaining maat
column12: the universal order that was a central principle of Egyptian religion and was itself personified as a goddess. Yet some deities represented disruption to maat. Most prominently
column13: Apep was the force of chaos
column14: constantly threatening to annihilate the order of the universe
column15: and Set was an ambivalent member of divine society who could both fight disorder and foment it.Not all aspects of existence were seen as deities. Although many deities were connected with the Nile
column16: no god personified it in the way that Ra personified the sun. Short-lived phenomena
column17: such as rainbows or eclipses
column18: were not represented by gods; neither were fire
column19: water
column20: or many other components of the world.The roles of each deity were fluid
column21: and each god could expand its nature to take on new characteristics. As a result
column22: gods' roles are difficult to categorize or define. Despite this flexibility
column23: the gods had limited abilities and spheres of influence. Not even the creator god could reach beyond the boundaries of the cosmos that he created
column24: and even Isis
column25: though she was said to be the cleverest of the gods
column26: was not omniscient. Richard H. Wilkinson
column27: however
column28: argues that some texts from the late New Kingdom suggest that as beliefs about the god Amun evolved he was thought to approach omniscience and omnipresence
column29: and to transcend the limits of the world in a way that other deities did not.The deities with the most limited and specialized domains are often called ""minor divinities"" or ""demons"" in modern writing
column30: although there is no firm definition for these terms. Some demons were guardians of particular places
column31: especially in the Duat
column32: the realm of the dead. Others wandered through the human world and the Duat
column33: either as servants and messengers of the greater gods or as roving spirits that caused illness or other misfortunes among humans. Demons' position in the divine hierarchy was not fixed. The protective deities Bes and Taweret originally had minor
column35: but over time they came to be credited with great influence. The most feared beings in the Duat were regarded as both disgusting and dangerous to humans. Over the course of Egyptian history
column36: they came to be regarded as fundamentally inferior members of divine society and to represent the opposite of the beneficial
column37: life-giving major gods. Yet even the most revered deities could sometimes exact vengeance on humans or each other
column38: displaying a demon-like side to their character and blurring the boundaries between demons and gods.

column1: Divine behavior was believed to govern all of nature. Except for the few deities who disrupted the divine order
column2: the gods' actions maintained maat and created and sustained all living things. They did this work using a force the Egyptians called heka
column3: a term usually translated as ""magic"". Heka was a fundamental power that the creator god used to form the world and the gods themselves.

column1: The gods' actions in the present are described and praised in hymns and funerary texts. In contrast
column2: mythology mainly concerns the gods' actions during a vaguely imagined past in which the gods were present on earth and interacted directly with humans. The events of this past time set the pattern for the events of the present. Periodic occurrences were tied to events in the mythic past; the succession of each new pharaoh
column3: for instance
column4: reenacted Horus's accession to the throne of his father Osiris.Myths are metaphors for the gods' actions
column5: which humans cannot fully understand. They contain seemingly contradictory ideas
column6: each expressing a particular perspective on divine events. The contradictions in myth are part of the Egyptians' many-faceted approach to religious belief‚Äîwhat Henri Frankfort called a ""multiplicity of approaches"" to understanding the gods. In myth
column7: the gods behave much like humans. They feel emotion; they can eat
column8: drink
column9: fight
column10: weep
column11: sicken
column12: and die. Some have unique character traits. Set is aggressive and impulsive
column13: and Thoth
column14: patron of writing and knowledge
column15: is prone to long-winded speeches. Yet overall
column16: the gods are more like archetypes than well drawn characters. Different versions of a myth could portray different deities playing the same archetypal role
column17: as in the myths of the Eye of Ra
column18: a feminine aspect of the sun god who was represented by many goddesses. Deities' mythic behavior is inconsistent
column19: and their thoughts and motivations are rarely stated. Most myths lack highly developed characters and plots
column20: because their symbolic meaning was more important than elaborate storytelling.The first divine act is the creation of the cosmos
column21: described in several creation myths. They focus on different gods
column22: each of which may act as creator deities. The eight gods of the Ogdoad
column23: who represent the chaos that precedes creation
column24: give birth to the sun god
column25: who establishes order in the newly formed world; Ptah
column26: who embodies thought and creativity
column27: gives form to all things by envisioning and naming them; Atum produces all things as emanations of himself; and Amun
column28: according to the theology promoted by his priesthood
column29: preceded and created the other creator gods. These and other versions of the events of creation were not seen as contradictory. Each gives a different perspective on the complex process by which the organized universe and its many deities emerged from undifferentiated chaos. The period following creation
column30: in which a series of gods rule as kings over the divine society
column31: is the setting for most myths. The gods struggle against the forces of chaos and among each other before withdrawing from the human world and installing the historical kings of Egypt to rule in their place.A recurring theme in these myths is the effort of the gods to maintain maat against the forces of disorder. They fight vicious battles with the forces of chaos at the start of creation. Ra and Apep
column32: battling each other each night
column33: continue this struggle into the present. Another prominent theme is the gods' death and revival. The clearest instance where a god dies is the myth of Osiris's murder
column34: in which that god is resurrected as ruler of the Duat. The sun god is also said to grow old during his daily journey across the sky
column35: sink into the Duat at night
column36: and emerge as a young child at dawn. In the process
column37: he comes into contact with the rejuvenating water of Nun
column38: the primordial chaos. Funerary texts that depict Ra's journey through the Duat also show the corpses of gods who are enlivened along with him. Instead of being changelessly immortal
column39: the gods periodically died and were reborn by repeating the events of creation
column40: thus renewing the whole world. Nonetheless
column41: it was always possible for this cycle to be disrupted and for chaos to return. Some poorly understood Egyptian texts even suggest that this calamity is destined to happen‚Äîthat the creator god will one day dissolve the order of the world
column42: leaving only himself and Osiris amid the primordial chaos.

column1: Gods were linked to specific regions of the universe. In Egyptian tradition
column2: the world includes the earth
column3: the sky
column4: and the underworld. Surrounding them is the dark formlessness that existed before creation. The gods in general were said to dwell in the sky
column5: although gods whose roles were linked with other parts of the universe were said to live in those places instead. Most events of mythology
column6: set in a time before the gods' withdrawal from the human realm
column7: take place in an earthly setting. The deities there sometimes interact with those in the sky. The underworld
column8: in contrast

column10: and the gods who dwell there have difficulties in communicating with those in the world of the living. The space outside the cosmos is also said to be very distant. It too is inhabited by deities
column11: some hostile and some beneficial to the other gods and their orderly world.In the time after myth
column12: most gods were said to be either in the sky or invisibly present within the world. Temples were their main means of contact with humanity. Each day
column13: it was believed
column14: the gods moved from the divine realm to their temples
column15: their homes in the human world. There they inhabited the cult images
column16: the statues that depicted deities and allowed humans to interact with them in temple rituals. This movement between realms was sometimes described as a journey between the sky and the earth. As temples were the focal points of Egyptian cities
column17: the god in a city's main temple was the patron deity for the city and the surrounding region. Deities' spheres of influence on earth centered on the towns and regions they presided over. Many gods had more than one cult center and their local ties changed over time. They could establish themselves in new cities
column18: or their range of influence could contract. Therefore
column19: a given deity's main cult center in historical times is not necessarily his or her place of origin. The political influence of a city could affect the importance of its patron deity. When kings from Thebes took control of the country at start of the Middle Kingdom (c. 2055‚Äì1650 BC)
column20: they elevated Thebes' patron gods‚Äîfirst the war god Montu and then Amun‚Äîto national prominence.

column1: The Egyptians regarded the division between male and female as fundamental to all beings
column2: including deities. Male gods tended to have a higher status than goddesses and were more closely connected with creation and with kingship
column3: while goddesses were more often thought of as helping and providing for humans. Some deities were androgynous

column11: stimulating their male consorts' virility and nurturing their children

column21: and homosexual acts were usually viewed with disapproval. Some texts nevertheless refer to homosexual behavior between male deities. In some cases

column1: The gods were believed to manifest in many forms. The Egyptians had a complex conception of the human soul
column2: consisting of several parts. The spirits of the gods were composed of many of these same elements. The ba was the component of the human or divine soul that affected the world around it. Any visible manifestation of a god's power could be called its ba; thus
column3: the sun was called the ba of Ra. A depiction of a deity was considered a ka
column4: another component of its being
column5: which acted as a vessel for that deity's ba to inhabit. The cult images of gods that were the focus of temple rituals

column7: were believed to house divine bas in this way. Gods could be ascribed many bas and kas
column8: which were sometimes given names representing different aspects of the god's nature. Everything in existence was said to be one of the kas of Atum the creator god

Gods' manifestations also differed according to their roles. Horus could be a powerful sky god or vulnerable child
column20: and these forms were sometimes counted as independent deities.Gods were combined with each other as easily as they were divided. A god could be called the ba of another

Syncretic combinations were not permanent; a god who was involved in one combination continued to appear separately and to form new combinations with other deities. Closely connected deities did sometimes merge. Horus absorbed several falcon gods from various regions

column1: === Unity of the divine in traditional religion ===
Scholars have long debated whether traditional Egyptian religion ever asserted that the multiple gods were
column2: on a deeper level
column3: unified. Reasons for this debate include the practice of syncretism
column4: which might suggest that all the separate gods could ultimately merge into one
column5: and the tendency of Egyptian texts to credit a particular god with power that surpasses all other deities. Another point of contention is the appearance of the word ""god"" in wisdom literature
column6: where the term does not refer to a specific deity or group of deities. In the early 20th century
column7: for instance

column10: who wrote the wisdom literature. His contemporary James Henry Breasted thought Egyptian religion was instead pantheistic

column13: Erik Hornung published a study rebutting such views. He points out that in any given period many deities
column14: even minor ones
column15: were described as superior to all others. He also argues that the unspecified ""god"" in the wisdom texts is a generic term for whichever deity is relevant to the reader in the situation at hand. Although the combinations

column20: Hornung says

column23: at the time before creation

column34: the dominant god in the late New Kingdom

column36: as well as with the henotheistic practice of ordinary worshippers. He says that the Egyptians may have recognized the unity of the divine by ""identifying their uniform notion of 'god' with a particular god

column1: Egyptian writings describe the gods' bodies in detail. They are made of precious materials; their flesh is gold

column7: functioning much like the ideograms in hieroglyphic writing. For this reason

column9: a creature whose scavenging habits threaten the preservation of buried mummies

column14: the Egyptians expressed different aspects of its essential nature. The gods are depicted in a finite number of these symbolic forms

column2: pharaohs are said to be divine
column3: and they are constantly depicted in the company of the deities of the pantheon. Each pharaoh and his predecessors were considered the successors of the gods who had ruled Egypt in mythic prehistory. Living kings were equated with Horus and called the ""son"" of many male deities

Pharaohs had their own mortuary temples where rituals were performed for them during their lives and after their deaths. But few pharaohs were worshipped as gods long after their lifetimes
column7: and non-official texts portray kings in a human light. For these reasons

column12: with their priests and laborers. Yet

column16: which maintained maat in the cosmos so humans could continue to live.

But many deities‚Äîincluding some important gods as well as those that were minor or hostile‚Äîwere never given temples of their own

column1: Alternanthera philoxeroides can thrive in both dry and aquatic environments and is characterized by whitish
column2: papery flowers along its short stalks
column3: irregular
column4: or sprawling hollow stems
column5: and simple and opposite leaf pattern sprouting from its nodes. The species is dioecious. It is also considered a herbaceous plant due to its short-lived shoot system. It produces horizontal stems
column6: otherwise known as stolons
column7: that can sprout up to 10 metres (33 ft) in length and thanks to its hollow stems
column8: floats easily. This results in large clusters of stem amassing and create dense mats along the surface. The plant flowers from December to April and usually grows around 13 millimetres (1‚ÅÑ2 in) in diameter and tend to be papery and ball-shaped. The weed's intricate root system can either allow them to hang free in the water to absorb nutrients or directly penetrate the soil/sediment and pull their nutrients from below.

column1: Alternanthera philoxeroides is considered a major threat to ecosystems because of the adverse effects it poses on both aquatic and terrestrial environments
column2: as well as the negative influence it has on society. The species features on the list of invasive alien species of Union Concern since 2017. This means that import and trade of this species is forbidden in the whole of the European Union.

column1: The presence of this invasive species disrupts the natural flow of water due to the dense mats created by its clusters of stems. It out competes the native vegetation for space and solar energy through these dense mats because they form large clusters and limit the amount of light that submerged vegetation receives. These compact clusters of stems also disturb the regular exchange of gases that occurs underneath the surface that directly influences aerobic processes
column2: such as photosynthesis. Aside from driving down the population of native aquatic vegetation
column3: A. philoxeroides can also influence the growth and yield of crops in pastures and fields. These dense mats can affect the natural flow of water that is used in irrigation systems and as well as affect the quality of the water by increasing the sedimentation present in the water. Both of these factors must remain undisturbed for crops to grow well
column4: and thus to provide a healthy yield for farmers
column5: which will be discussed in the later section on its impacts on society.  On top of this
column6: the likelihood of flooding is higher due to the impaired drainage caused by the dense mats
column7: which in turn can also damage crops. This invasive species also has other negative impacts on the environment.

column2: the compact mats formed by this species can drive down the population of native vegetation in the environments it invades. This then becomes a major issue for native herbivores because their food source declines. In addition
column3: the dense mats present a challenge for the native wildlife by acting as a barrier between them and natural water sources. However
column4: even if they can reach the water
column5: they are still at risk because the water quality can be contaminated by the increased sediments. Thus
column6: just as it did with the native vegetation
column7: A. philoxeroides is also driving down the populations of the native wildlife as well.

column1: Dense mats formed by this species influence the natural flow of water
column2: which can impede various recreational activities
column3: such as boating and fishing. The disruption of flow can also have a negative impact on infrastructure when it comes to energy
column4: such as the use of hydro-electric dams to power generators. The dense mats also present suitable ecological conditions that mosquitoes can thrive off of. This is a commensal relationship between mosquitoes and A. philoxeroides because mosquitoes receive a breeding ground and the plant gains nothing nor loses anything. The increased population of mosquitoes can bring an increased risk of mosquito-borne diseases in humans. Furthermore
column5: the dense mats produced by A. philoxeroides may not present suitable ecological conditions for native species or humans to thrive off.

column1: This invasive plant depends solely on vegetative means to reproduce and disperse itself in the area it has invaded and established its roots. In its native geographic range
column2: the species spreads to through means of producing viable seeds; however
column3: it has been observed within its non-native ranges that it rarely produces viable seeds. To accommodate this
column4: the A. philoxeroides reproduces through fragmentation; the plant can regenerate itself from small portions of stems or small leaf cuttings. These small fragments of the plant can then be dispersed through human means and natural means; once it is dispersed
column5: the fragments can then find suitable ecological conditions and root themselves and regenerate.

column1: In effort to eradicate the species by manual means
column2: such as mulching or pulling them out
column3: if not removed efficiently
column4: small stem fragments can be displaced to new areas. Soil movement caused by earthmoving machinery is another example of how humans influence the dispersal of the plant.

column2: the A. philoxeroides can easily disperse its fragments by being sucked into the path of the waterways. In terrestrial environments
column3: the small fragments of stems and leaf cuttings can be dispersed through the natural movement of soil caused by erosion. Thus
column4: the geographic range of this invasive species can easily be expanded by any means necessary due to its ability to regenerate from practically nothing.

column1: Early detection is the best bet to ensure that the invasive species does not successfully colonize a non-native region because of its ability to regenerate and propagate from small portions of its stem or leaf cuttings. However
column2: when that is not possible
column3: the best that can be done is to limit and control the presence of A. philoxeroides in an area. Alternanthera philoxeroides can only establish itself in shallow waters no deeper than 2 metres (2 yards)
column4: so one method of control is to erect barriers in shallower areas to limit the amount of suitable space the plant has. When it comes to terrestrial environments
column5: overpopulating the area with native species can limit the suitable space available for it. However
column6: this method is only effective before the invasive plant has asserted itself in an area. Lastly
column7: as previously mentioned
column8: this plant is only able to produce viable seeds in its native geographic range and not in the areas it has invaded. Learning why that is - what ecological conditions make it produce only sterile seeds - could be key to developing further preventative measures against it.

column1: Insects have been released for the biological control of A. philoxeroides. The most successful and widely used is Agasicles hygrophila commonly called the alligator weed flea beetle; it has been released for biocontrol in Australia
column2: China
column3: Thailand
column4: New Zealand
column5: and the United States. However
column6: their effectiveness is limited due to their inability to survive through temperatures lower than 11 ¬∞C (52 ¬∞F). Amynothrips andersoni
column7: the alligator weed thrips
column8: and Vogtia malloi
column9: the alligator weed stem borer
column10: have also been released in the United States. These species result in immediate wilting and limit A. philoxeroides reproduction by colonizing its stems. A variety of chemicals have been shown to be effective in controlling the plant
column11: the most useful of which include glyphosate
column12: triclopyr
column13: fluridone
column14: imazamox
column15: and imazapyr; however
column16: they must constantly be applied to be successful.

column1: === Legality of sale and shipment in the United States ===
In 1956 A. philoxeroides was banned for sale or shipment in the United States
column2: subject to a fine and/or imprisonment.This law was repealed by HR133 [116th Congress (2019-2020)] on 12/27/2020.

commonly called common milkweed

column7: is a species of flowering plant. It is native to southern Canada and much of the United States east of the Rocky Mountains
column8: excluding the drier parts of the prairies. It is in the genus Asclepias
column9: the milkweeds. It grows in sandy soils as well as other kinds of soils in sunny areas.

column1: A. syriaca is a clonal perennial forb growing up to 1.8 m (5 ft 11 in) tall. Individual plants grow from rhizomes. All parts of common milkweed plants produce a white latex when cut. The simple leaves are opposite
column2: sometimes whorled; broadly ovate-lanceolate. They grow to 10‚Äì28 cm (4‚Äì11 in) long and 4‚Äì12 cm (1+1‚ÅÑ2‚Äì4+3‚ÅÑ4 in) broad
column3: usually with entire
column4: undulate margins and reddish main veins. They have very short petioles and velvety undersides.

column2: nectariferous flowers vary from white (rarely) through pinkish and purplish and occur in umbellate cymes. Individual flowers are about 1 cm (0.4 in) in diameter
column3: each with five horn-like hoods and five pollinia. The seeds
column4: each with long
column5: white flossy hairs
column6: occur in large follicles. Fruit production from self-fertilization is rare. In three study plots
column7: outcrossed flowers had an average of about 11% fruit set.

column1: More than 450 insects species feed on A. syriaca
column2: including flies
column3: beetles
column4: ants
column5: bees
column6: wasps
column7: and butterflies; it is an important food source for monarch butterfly caterpillars (Danaus plexippus); other species that feed on the plant include red milkweed beetle (Tetraopes tetraophthalmus)
column8: the milkweed tussock caterpillar (Euchaetes egle) and Oncopeltus fasciatus and Lygaeus kalmii. Many kinds of insects visit A. syriaca flowers
column9: and some kinds pollinate them
column10: including Apis mellifera
column11: the Western honey bee
column12: and native Bombus spp. (bumblebees). In the U.S. mid-Atlantic region
column13: the introduced species A. mellifera was found to be the most ""effective"" pollinator
column14: but this occurs more often among flowers of the same plant; since  A. syriaca has a high level of self-incompatibility
column15: it is less effective than  'Bombus spp. in the fertilization of flowers because Bombus spp. are more likely to visit unrelated individuals.Monarch butterfly larvae consume only milkweeds
column16: and monarch populations may decline when milkweeds are eliminated with herbicides. The development and widely adopted cultivation of herbicide-resistant staple crops such as corn and soybeans have led to a massive reduction in weeds and native plants such as milkweeds. Subsequently
column17: this has played a significant part in the population decline of the monarch butterfly. In 2018 the CEO of the National Wildlife Federation stated that the population of the monarch butterfly is now down 90 percent in the last 20 years and cited the reduction in milkweed as a contributing factor.Many parts of the United States face a reduction in milkweed population due to factors such as increased habitat loss due to development
column18: roadside median mowing
column19: and herbicide use. Despite this
column20: deforestation due to human settlement may have expanded the range and density of common milkweed in some regions. Milkweed has even become invasive as it is naturalized in several areas outside of its original native range
column21: including Oregon and some parts of Europe.Over 40 distinct pathogens of Asclepias species have been identified
column22: including two dozen pathogens for A. syriaca. For example
column23: milkweed yellows is an infectious disease caused by the milkweed yellows phytoplasma
column24: a strain of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

column1: The species features since 2017 on the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union Concern. This means that import of the species and trade in the species is forbidden in the whole of the European Union.

A. syriaca can become invasive. It spreads aggressively from rhizomes and may not be suited to small gardens and formalized plantings. The plant is winter hardy in USDA zones 3‚Äì9; it has a preference for moist but well drained soils
column2: but is tolerant of dry conditions and clay soils. It is ideal in semi-dry places where it can spread without presenting problems for other ornamental species.Monarch Watch provides information on rearing monarchs and their host plants. Efforts to restore falling monarch butterfly populations by establishing butterfly gardens and monarch migratory ""waystations"" require particular attention to the target species' food preferences and population cycles
column3: as well to the conditions needed to propagate and maintain their food plants.In the northeastern United States
column4: monarch reproduction peaks in late summer when most of the plant's leaves are old and tough. Plants that are mowed or cut back in June ‚Äì August regrow rapidly from their rhizomes in time for peak monarch egg-laying
column5: when reproducing female monarchs have a preference for quickly-growing A. syriaca shoots whose foliage is tender and soft.A. syriaca is easily propagated by both seed and rhizome cuttings. The plant's seeds require a period of cold treatment (cold stratification) before they will germinate.To protect seeds from washing away during heavy rains and from seed‚Äìeating birds
column6: one can cover the seeds with a light fabric or with an 0.5 in (13 mm) layer of straw mulch. However
column7: mulch acts as an insulator. Thicker layers of mulch can prevent seeds from germinating if they prevent soil temperatures from rising enough when winter ends. Further
column8: few seedlings can push through a thick layer of mulch. Both seedlings and cuttings will usually bloom in their second year
column9: although cuttings will occasionally bloom during their first year.The nonnative Aphis nerii (oleander aphid) can become abundant on milkweed shoots.

column1: The plant's latex contains large quantities of cardiac glycosides
column2: making the leaves and stems of old tall plants toxic to humans and large animals. The young shoots
column3: young leaves
column4: flower buds and immature fruits are all edible raw.Euell Gibbons
column5: the author of Stalking the Wild Asparagus (1962)
column6: wrote that milkweed is bitter and toxic.  However
column7: he may have inadvertently prepared common dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum)
column8: a poisonous somewhat similar-looking plant instead. Gibbons devised a method to remove the bitterness and toxicity by plunging the young shoots into boiling water and cooking for one minute
column9: repeating the procedure at least three times to make the plant safe to eat. Some modern foragers consider the bitterness and toxicity issue a myth. The plants have no bitterness when tasted raw
column10: and can be cooked like asparagus
column11: with no special processing.Failed attempts have been made to exploit rubber (from the latex) and fiber (from seeds' ""floss"") production from the plant industrially. The fluffy seed hairs have been used as the traditional background for mounted butterflies and other insects. The compressed floss has a silk-like sheen. The plant has also been explored for commercial use of its bast (inner bark) fiber
column12: which is both strong and soft. U. S. Department of Agriculture studies in the 1890s and 1940s found that common milkweed has more potential for commercial processing than any other indigenous bast fiber plant
column13: with estimated yields as high as hemp and quality as good as flax. Both the bast fiber and the floss were used historically by Native Americans for cordage and textiles. Milkweed has also been cultivated commercially to be used as insulation in winter coats.Traditionally
column14: in both North America and Europe
column15: the plant was used to treat respiratory infections such as pleurisy.

column2: Pallas's squirrels are primarily herbivorous. They eat a wide range of different foods

column8: as well as occasional bird eggs.The squirrels breed throughout the year

column2: and inhabit much of the forest canopy

column12: and after

column1: The invasive potential for the species is great all over the tropics. This species is able to make use of resources with great flexibility and appears to be associated with humans

column1: House crows feed largely on refuse around human habitations
column2: small reptiles and mammals
column3: and other animals such as insects and other small invertebrates
column4: eggs
column5: nestlings

column8: they can survive on nearly anything that is edible. These birds can be seen near marketplaces and garbage dumps
column9: foraging for scraps. They have also been observed to eat sand after feeding on carcasses.

column2: and occasionally there are several nests in the same tree. In South Asia they are parasitized by the Asian koel. Peak breeding in India as well as Peninsular Malaysia is from April to July. Large trees with big crowns are preferred for nesting.

column1: House crows roost communally near human habitations and often over busy streets. A study in Singapore found that the preferred roost sites were in well-lit areas with a lot of human activity
column2: close to food sources and in tall trees with dense crowns that were separated from other trees. The roost sites were often enclosed by tall buildings. Before flying into roost trees

column4: roof tops
column5: wayside trees
column6: open fields
column7: and feed or preen during this time.

column2: such as PMV 1 that causes of Newcastle disease may be spread by Corvus splendens. Outbreaks of Newcastle disease in India were often preceded by mortality in crows. They have also been found to carry Cryptococcus neoformans

Eichhornia crassipeshttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eichhornia%20crassipes"Pontederia crassipes - commonly known as common water hyacinth
column2: (and also known as the ""terror of Bengal""; generally in Bengali it is often called 'kochuripana') - is an aquatic plant native to the Amazon basin
column3: and is often a highly problematic invasive species outside its native range. It is the sole species of Pontederia subg. Oshunae.

column1: Water hyacinth is a free-floating perennial aquatic plant (or hydrophyte) native to tropical and sub-tropical South America. With broad
column2: thick
column3: glossy
column4: ovate leaves
column5: water hyacinth may rise above the surface of the water as much as 1 meter (3 feet) in height. The leaves are 10‚Äì20 cm (4‚Äì8 inches) across on a stem which is floating by means of buoyant bulb-like nodules at its base above the water surface. They have long
column6: spongy and bulbous stalks. The feathery
column7: freely hanging roots are purple-black. An erect stalk supports a single spike of 8‚Äì15 conspicuously attractive flowers
column8: mostly lavender to pink in colour with six petals. When not in bloom
column9: water hyacinth may be mistaken for frog's-bit (Limnobium spongia) or Amazon frogbit (Limnobium laevigatum).

column1: One of the fastest-growing plants known
column2: water hyacinth reproduces primarily by way of runners or stolons
column3: which eventually form daughter plants. Each plant additionally can produce thousands of seeds each year
column4: and these seeds can remain viable for more than 28 years. Some water hyacinths were found to grow between 2 and 5 meters (7 and 16 feet) a day in some sites in Southeast Asia. The common water hyacinth (Pontederia crassipes) are vigorous growers and mats can double in size in one to two weeks. And in terms of plant count rather than size
column5: they are said to multiply by more than a hundredfold in number
column6: in a matter of 23 days.

column2: these flowers are pollinated by long-tongued bees and they can reproduce both sexually and clonally. The invasiveness of the hyacinth is related to its ability to clone itself and large patches are likely to all be part of the same genetic form.

column1: Water hyacinth has three flower morphs and is termed ""tristylous"". The flower morphs are named for the length of their pistil: long
column2: medium and short. Tristylous populations are however limited to the native lowland South America range of water hyacinth; in the introduced range
column3: the M-morph prevails
column4: with the L-morph occurring occasionally and the S-morph is absent altogether. This geographical distribution of the floral morphs indicates that founder events have played a prominent role in the species' worldwide spread.

column1: Its habitat ranges from tropical desert to subtropical or warm temperate desert to rainforest zones. The temperature tolerance of the water hyacinth is the following; its minimum growth temperature is 12 ¬∞C (54 ¬∞F); its optimum growth temperature is 25‚Äì30 ¬∞C (77‚Äì86 ¬∞F); its maximum growth temperature is 33‚Äì35 ¬∞C (91‚Äì95 ¬∞F)
column2: and its pH tolerance is estimated at 5.0‚Äì7.5. Leaves are killed by frost and plants do not tolerate water temperatures > 34 ¬∞C (93 ¬∞F). Water hyacinths do not grow where the average salinity is greater than 15% that of sea water (around 5 g salt per kg). In brackish water
column3: its leaves show epinasty and chlorosis
column4: and eventually die. Rafts of harvested water hyacinth have been floated to the sea where it is killed.Azotobacter chroococcum
column5: a species of nitrogen-fixing bacteria
column6: is probably concentrated around the bases of the petioles
column7: but the bacteria do not fix nitrogen unless the plant is suffering extreme nitrogen deficiency.Fresh plants contain prickly crystals. This plant is reported to contain hydrogen cyanide
column8: alkaloids
column9: and triterpenoids
column10: and may induce itching. Plants sprayed with 2
column11: 4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid may accumulate lethal doses of nitrates
column12: and other harmful elements in polluted environments.

column1: Since the water hyacinths are so prolific
column2: harvesting them for industrial use serves also as a means of environmental control.
the Philippines

column5: the water hyacinth's stems are used as a braiding material and a source of fibers. Strings of dried fibers are woven or interlinked together to form a braid or cord used for making bags
column6: footwear
column7: wreaths
column8: hats
column9: vases
column10: Christmas lanterns
column11: and more decorative materials. Dried stems are used for baskets and furniture. Water hyacinth fibers are used as raw material for paper.

column1: Since the plant has abundant nitrogen content
column2: it can be used as a substrate for biogas production and the sludge obtained from the biogas. However

column4: the plant is prone to get contaminated when used as feed.

column30: it has become a serious pest. The common water hyacinth has become an invasive plant species on Lake Victoria in Africa after it was introduced into the area in the 1980s.When not controlled
column31: water hyacinth can cover lakes and ponds entirely; this dramatically affects water flow and blocks sunlight from reaching native aquatic plants
column32: which often die. The decay processes depletes dissolved oxygen in the water
column33: often killing fish. The plants also create a prime habitat for mosquitos
column35: and a species of snail known to host a parasitic flatworm
column36: which causes schistosomiasis (snail fever). Directly blamed for starving subsistence farmers in Papua New Guinea
column37: water hyacinth remains a major problem where effective control programs are not in place. Water hyacinth is often problematic in man-made ponds if uncontrolled
column38: but can also provide a food source for goldfish
column39: keep water clean and help to provide oxygen.Water hyacinth often invades bodies of water that have already been affected by human activities. For example
column40: the plants can unbalance natural lifecycles in artificial reservoirs or in eutrophied lakes that receive large amounts of nutrients.

column2: several biological control agents have been released to control it

column5: and the moth Niphograpta albiguttalis (Warren) (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae). Neochetina eichhorniae causes ""a substantial reduction in water hyacinth production"" (in Louisiana); it reduces plant height
column6: weight

column8: and makes the plant produce fewer daughter plants. N. eichhorniae was introduced from Argentina to Florida in 1972. A semi-aquatic grasshopper
column9: Cornops aquaticum
column10: is being investigated in South Africa as an additional control agent.

column1: Various accounts are given as to how the water hyacinth was introduced to the United States.
(1884 Exposition)The claim that the water hyacinth was introduced to the U.S. in 1884 at the World's Fair in New Orleans
column2: also known as the World Cotton Centennial
column3: has been characterized as the ""first authentic account""
column4: as well as ""local legend"".

column2: versions of the ""legend"" asserted that the plants had been given away as a gift by a Japanese delegation at the fair. This claim is absent in a pertinent article published in a military engineer's trade journal dating to 1940
column3: but appears in a piece penned in 1941 by the director of the wildlife and fisheries division at the Louisiana Department of Conservation
column4: where the author writes
column5: ""the Japanese government maintained a Japanese building"" at the fair
column6: and the ""Japanese staff imported from Venezuela considerable numbers of water hyacinth
column7: which were given away as souvenirs"". The claim has been repeated by later writers
column8: with various shifts in the details. Thus NAS fellow Noel D. Vietmeyer (1975) wrote that ""Japanese entrepreneurs"" introduced the plant into the U.S.
column9: and the plants had been ""collected from the Orinoco River in Venezuela""
column10: and the claim was echoed along the same gist by a pair of NASA researchers (Wolverton & McDonald 1979)
column11: who asserted that the souvenir plants were carelessly dumped in various waterways. Canadian biologist Spencer C. H. Barrett (2004) meanwhile favored the theory they were first cultivated in garden ponds
column12: after which they multiplied and escaped to the environs. The account gains a different detail as told by children's story-teller Carole Marsh (1992)
column13: who says ""Japan gave away water hyacinth seeds"" during the exposition
column14: and another Southern raconteur
column15: Gaspar J. ""Buddy"" Stall (1998) assured his readership that the Japanese gave each family a package of those seeds.

column1: (Other means of introduction)One paper has also inquired into the role which catalog sales of seeds and plants may have played in the dissemination of invasive plants. It has been found that P. crassipes was offered in the 1884 issue of Bordentown
column2: New Jersey-based Edmund D. Sturtevant's Catalogue of rare water lilies and other choice aquatic plants
column3: and Haage & Schmidt of Germany has offered the plant since 1864 (since the firm was founded). By 1895
column4: it was offered by seed-purveyors in the states of NJ
column5: NY
column6: California
column7: and Florida.The Harper's Weekly magazine (1895) printed an anecdotal account stating that a certain man from New Orleans collected and brought home water hyacinths he collected from Colombia
column9: and the plant proliferated in a matter of 2 years.

column1: ==== Infestation and control in the Southeast ====
As the hyacinths multiply into mats
column2: they eliminate the presence of fish
column3: and choke waterways for boating and shipping. This effect was well taking hold in the state of Louisiana by the turn of the 20th century.The plant invaded Florida in 1890
column4: and an estimated 50 kg/m2 of the plant mass choked Florida's waterways. The clogging of the St. Johns River was posing a serious threat
column5: and in 1897 the government dispatched a task force of the United States Army Corps of Engineers to solve the water hyacinth problem plaguing the Gulf states such as Florida and Louisiana.Thus in the early 20th century
column6: the U.S. War Department (i.e.
column7: the Army Corps of Engineers) tested various means of eradicating the plants
column8: including the jet-streaming of steam and hot water
column9: application of various strong acids
column10: and application of petroleum followed by incineration. Spraying with saturated salt solution (but not dilute solutions) effectively killed the plants; unfortunately this was considered prohibitively expensive
column11: and the engineers selected Harvesta brand herbicide
column12: whose active ingredient was arsenic acid
column13: as the optimal cost-effective tool for eradication. This herbicide was used until 1905
column14: when it was substituted with a different
column15: white arsenic based compound. An engineer charged with the spraying did not think the poison to be a matter of concern
column16: stating that the crew of the spraying boat would routinely catch fish from their working areas and consume them. However
column17: spraying had little hope of completely eradicating the water hyacinth
column18: due to the vastness of escaped colonies and the inaccessibility of some of the infested areas
column19: and the engineer suggested that some biological means of control may be needed. In 1910
column20: a bold solution was put forth by the New Foods Society. Their plan was to import and release hippopotamus from Africa into the rivers and bayous of Louisiana. The hippopotamus would then eat the water hyacinth and also produce meat to solve another serious problem at the time
column21: the American meat crisis.Known as the American Hippo bill
column22: H.R. 23621 was introduced by Louisiana Congressman Robert Broussard and debated by the Agricultural Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives. The chief collaborators in the New Foods Society and proponents of Broussard's bill were Major Frederick Russell Burnham
column23: the celebrated American Scout
column24: and Captain Fritz Duquesne
column25: a South African Scout who later became a notorious spy for Germany. Presenting before the Agricultural Committee
column26: Burnham made the point that none of the animals that Americans ate
column27: chickens
column28: pigs
column29: cows
column30: sheep
column31: lambs
column32: were native to the U.S.; all had been imported by European settlers centuries before
column33: so why should Americans hesitate to introduce hippopotamus and other large animals into the American diet? Duquesne
column34: who was born and raised in South Africa
column35: further noted that European settlers on that continent commonly included hippopotamus
column38: and other African wildlife in their diets and suffered no ill effects. The American Hippo bill nearly passed
column40: water hyacinths have also been introduced into waters inhabited by manatees in Florida
column41: for the purpose of bioremediation (cf. ¬ßPhytoremediation below) of the waters that have become contaminated and fallen victim to algal blooming. The manatees include the water hyacinth in their diet
column42: but it may not be the food of first choice for them.

column1: ==== Legality of sale and shipment in the United States ====
In 1956 E. crassipes was banned for sale or shipment in the United States
column2: subject to a fine and/or imprisonment. This law was repealed by HR133 [116th Congress (2019-2020)] on 12/27/2020.

column1: The water hyacinth may have been introduced into Egypt in the late 18th to early 19th century during Muhammad Ali of Egypt's era
column2: but was not recognized as an invasive threat until 1879. The invasion into Egypt is dated between 1879 and 1892 by Brij Gopal. Gopal; Junk; Davis (2000)

column1: The plant (Afrikaans: waterhiasint) arguably invaded South Africa in 1910

column3: without any natural enemies
column4: it has become an ecological plague
column5: suffocating the lake
column6: diminishing the fish reservoir
column7: and hurting the local economies. It impedes access to Kisumu and other harbors.

column5: and Lake Ellen near Alem Tena. By 2018

column1: The water hyacinth was introduced to Bengal

column2: water hyacinth which was imported in the 1990s as a decorative plant

Large sums of money are allocated to the removal of water hyacinth from the water bodies as well as figuring out how to destroy the remains harvested. Harvesting water hyacinth mechanically requires a lot of effort. A million tons of fresh biomass would require 75 trucks with a capacity of 40m^3
column38: for 365 days to get rid of a million tons of water hyacinth. The water hyacinth would then be transferred to a dumping site and allowed to decompose which releases CO2

column1: Control depends on the specific conditions of each affected location such as the extent of water hyacinth infestation
column2: regional climate
column3: and proximity to human and wildlife.

column1: Chemical control is the least used out of the three controls of water hyacinth
column2: because of its long-term effects on the environment and human health. The use of herbicides requires strict approval from governmental protection agencies of skilled technician to handle and spray the affected areas. The use of chemical herbicides is only used in case of severe infiltration of water hyacinth. However
column3: the most successful use of herbicides is when it is used for smaller areas of infestation of water hyacinth. This is because in larger areas
column4: more mats of water hyacinths are likely to survive the herbicides and can fragment to further propagate a large area of water hyacinth mats. In addition
column5: it is more cost-effective and less laborious than mechanical control. Yet
column6: it can lead to environmental effects as it can penetrate into the ground water system and can affect not only the hydrological cycle within an ecosystem but also negatively affect the local water system and human health. It is also notable that the use of herbicides is not strictly selective of water hyacinths; keystone species and vital organisms such as microalgae can perish from the toxins and can disrupt fragile food webs.The chemical regulation of water hyacinths can be done using common herbicides such as 2
column8: glyphosate
column9: and diquat. The herbicides are sprayed on the water hyacinth leaves and leads to direct changes to the physiology of the plant. The use of the herbicide known as 2
column10: 4-D leads to the death of water hyacinth through inhibition of cell growth of new tissue and cellular apoptosis. It can take almost a two-week period before mats of water hyacinth are destroyed with 2
column11: 4-D. Between 75
column13: 000 acres (30
column15: 000 ha) of water hyacinth and alligator weed are treated annually in Louisiana.The herbicide known as diquat is a liquid bromide salt that can rapidly penetrate the leaves of the water hyacinth and lead to immediate inactivity of plant cells and cellular processes. For the herbicide glyphosate
column16: it has a lower toxicity than the other herbicides; therefore
column17: it takes longer for the water hyacinth mats to be destroyed (about three weeks). The symptoms include steady wilting of the plants and a yellow discoloration of the plant leaves that eventually leads to plant decay.

column1: Physical control is performed by land-based machines such as bucket cranes
column2: draglines
column3: or boom or by water based machinery such as aquatic weed harvesters
column4: dredges
column5: or vegetation shredder. Mechanical removal is seen as the best short-term solution to the proliferation of the plant. A project on Lake Victoria in Africa used various pieces of equipment to chop
column6: collect
column7: and dispose of 1
column8: 500 hectares (3
column9: 700 acres) of water hyacinth in a 12-month period. It is
column10: however
column11: costly and requires the use of both land and water vehicles
column12: but it took many years for the lake to become in poor condition and reclamation will be a continual process.It can have an annual cost from $6 million to $20 million and is only considered a short-term solution to a long-term problem. Another disadvantage with mechanical harvesting is that it can lead to further fragmentation of water hyacinths when the plants are broken up by spinning cutters of the plant-harvesting machinery. The fragments of water hyacinth that are left behind in the water can easily reproduce asexually and cause another infestation.However
column13: transportation and disposal of the harvested water hyacinth is a challenge because the vegetation is heavy in weight. The harvested water hyacinth can pose a health risk to humans because of the plant's propensity for absorbing contaminants
column14: and it is considered toxic to humans. Furthermore
column15: the practice of mechanical harvesting is not effective in large-scale infestations of the water hyacinth
column16: because this aquatic invasive species grows much more rapidly than it can be eliminated. Only one to two acres (1‚ÅÑ2 to 1 ha) of water hyacinth can be mechanically harvested daily because of the vast amounts of water hyacinths in the environment. Therefore
column17: the process is very time-intensive.

column1: As chemical and mechanical removal is often too expensive
column2: polluting
column3: and ineffective
column4: researchers have turned to biological control agents to deal with water hyacinth. The effort began in the 1970s when USDA researchers released into the United States three species of weevil known to feed on water hyacinth
column5: Neochetina bruchi
column6: N. eichhorniae
column7: and the water hyacinth borer Sameodes albiguttalis. The weevil species were introduced into the Gulf Coast states
column8: such as Louisiana
column9: Texas
column10: and Florida
column11: where thousands of acres were infested by water hyacinth. It was found that a decade later in the 1980s that there was a decrease in water hyacinth mats by as much as 33%. However
column12: because the life cycle of the weevils is ninety days
column13: it puts a limitation on the use of biological predation to efficiently suppress water hyacinth growth. These organisms regulate water hyacinth by limiting water hyacinth size
column14: its vegetative propagation
column15: and seed production. They also carry microorganisms that can be pathological to the water hyacinth. These weevils eat stem tissue
column16: which results in a loss of buoyancy for the plant
column17: which will eventually sink. Although meeting with limited success
column18: the weevils have since been released in more than 20 other countries. However
column19: the most effective control method remains the control of excessive nutrients and prevention of the spread of this species.In May 2010
column20: the USDA's Agricultural Research Service released Megamelus scutellaris as an additional biological control insect for the invasive water hyacinth species. Megamelus scutellaris is a small planthopper insect native to Argentina. Researchers have been studying the effects of the biological control agent in extensive host-range studies since 2006 and concluded that the insect is highly host-specific and will not pose a threat to any other plant population other than the targeted water hyacinth. Researchers also hope that this biological control will be more resilient than existing biological controls and the herbicides that are already in place to combat the invasive water hyacinth.Another insect being considered as a biological control agent is the semi-aquatic grasshopper Cornops aquaticum. This insect is specific to the water hyacinth and its family
column21: and besides feeding on the plant
column22: it introduces a secondary pathogenic infestation. This grasshopper has been introduced into South Africa in controlled trials.The introduction of manatees into waterways was reportedly successful in controlling the plant's growth in Guyana.The Rhodes University Center for Biological Control is rearing Megamelus scutellaris en masse for biocontrol at dams in South Africa.

column31: which is essentially a batch operation.The labor involved in harvesting water hyacinth can be greatly reduced by locating collection sites and processors on impoundments that take advantage of prevailing winds. Wastewater treatment systems could also favorably be added to this operation. The harvested biomass would then be converted to ethanol

column2: waste water treatment ===

column1: Water hyacinth removes arsenic from arsenic-contaminated drinking water. It may be a useful tool in removing arsenic from tube well water in Bangladesh.Water hyacinth is also observed to enhance nitrification in wastewater treatment cells of living technology. Their root zones are superb micro-sites for bacterial communities.Water hyacinth is a common fodder plant in the third world especially Africa though excessive use can be toxic. It is high in protein (nitrogen) and trace minerals and the goat feces are a good source of fertilizer as well.

Water hyacinth is reported for its efficiency to remove about 60‚Äì80% nitrogen and about 69% of potassium from water. The roots of water hyacinth were found to remove particulate matter and nitrogen in a natural shallow eutrophicated wetland.The plant can also screen heavy metals and various other toxins from contaminated water.The roots of Pontederia crassipes naturally absorb pollutants
column2: including lead
column3: mercury
column4: and strontium-90
column5: as well as some organic compounds believed to be carcinogenic
column6: in concentrations 10
column7: 000 times that in the surrounding water. Water hyacinths can be cultivated for waste water treatment (especially dairy waste water).

column1: This species' distinguishing features are the dense patches of dark setae on its claws. The crab's body is the size of a human palm. The legs are about twice as long as the 3‚Äì10-centimeter-wide (1‚Äì4 in) carapace.
Mitten crabs spend most of their life in fresh water and return to the sea to breed. During their fourth or fifth year in late summer
column2: the crustaceans migrate downstream and attain sexual maturity in the tidal estuaries. After mating
column3: the females continue seaward
column4: overwintering in deeper waters. They return to brackish water in the spring to hatch their eggs. After development as larvae
column5: the juvenile crabs gradually move upstream into fresh water
column6: thus completing the life cycle.It moves from freshwater habitats to saltwater habitats once it has reached reproduction maturity. The types of estuaries suitable for the mitten crab is large brackish waters for the larva to develop in
column7: and large shallow waters for the growth of the juvenile crabs. An increase in microplastics has had a significant impact on the population as it affects their metabolism
column8: growth
column9: and oxidative stress response in the liver.The Chinese mitten crab originates from Hong Kong to the border of Korea. It can be found inland but prefers coastal areas. In the Yangtze
column10: the largest river in its native range
column11: Chinese mitten crabs have been recorded up to 1
column12: 400 km (760 nmi) upstream. It is known to settle in rice fields by the sea and rivers inland. Spawning crabs average around 5.5 cm (2+1‚ÅÑ4 in) in length. Since crabs spawn at the end of their life spans and perish at the end of the breeding cycle

column3: snails
column4: dead organic material

column1: Starts off as a fresh-water organism. In late August the crab's sexual instinct is awakened and they begin migrating downstream to the sea
column2: away from their feeding grounds. It is during this migration where the crabs reach puberty and develop their sex organs. The crabs begin to breed in the brackish waters in late fall. The males arrive first and stay in the brackish waters all winter; the females arrive after the males arrive. The eggs are laid within 24 hours of mating. They are attached to the abdomen of the female crab. After the eggs are attached
column3: the female leaves immediately heading to the mouth of the river. The larvae hatch from the eggs during summer
column4: after which they float and drift about the brackish waters. Because the journey to breed for crabs is so great
column5: they only breed once during their lifetimes. The breeding age is normally toward the end of their lifespans. Said crabs have sizable egg production count since these crabs only breed once. After the crabs successfully reproduce
column6: they have very little energy and begin to waste away.Different life stages of the mitten crab:

column1: 1) Eggs require pure salt water to mature. 2) Larvae hatch from the eggs in brackish waters. 3) The larvae gradually move from brackish water to fresh water. 4) The final stage of the larvae is the megalopa
column2: which is 3‚Äì4 millimeters (1‚ÅÑ8‚Äì5‚ÅÑ32 in) in length. 5) The megalopa then develop into small mitten crabs in the freshwater.

column1: This certain species of crab has been spread rapidly from Asia (China and Korea) to North America and Europe
column2: raising concerns that it competes with local species

column6: such as the Chesapeake Bay in Maryland and the Hudson River in New York (both locations where the crabs were first spotted in 2005)

column12: along with details (date

column22: it could have been the spawning time for the mitten crab. Since the larvae are free floating and 1.7‚Äì5 millimeters (1‚ÅÑ16‚Äì3‚ÅÑ16 in) in size

column24: the crab larvae were released. Over time
column25: this repetition would allow for a prominent mitten crab population in Europe. The crab has spread and can be found in Continental Europe

column27: United States of America (the San Francisco Bay)
column28: and the United Kingdom.  A 15-year period in Germany when the crabs were gradually entering Europe is known as the ""establishment phase"".

column1: Management efforts have shown to be very difficult. This is due to its abundance

column1: The life cycle of giant hogweed consists of four phases:1. Pre-flowering plants: In the first year
column2: leaves sprout from seed. In subsequent years

column1: 3. Seeds (late summer/early autumn): A flowering plant produces 20

column1: 4. Dead stems (late autumn/winter): After producing seeds

column1: During the first few years of growth

column3: the plant grows back from its root. In other words

column1: Seeds are typically produced in August. A single flowering plant will produce 20
column2: 000 seeds on average with seed production varying between 10
column4: 000 seeds per plant.Giant hogweed is a monocarpic perennial
column5: that is

Seeds may stay alive in the seed bank for more than five years.A seed deposited in the seed bank is initially dormant. Dormancy is broken by the cold and wet conditions of fall and winter

column1: Seeds normally result from cross-pollination between two or more plants but self-pollination is also possible. More than half the seeds produced by self-pollination will germinate and give rise to healthy seedlings. Hence a single isolated seed may give rise to a colony of new plants.

column1: Heracleum mantegazzianum is native to the western Caucasus region of Eurasia. Because of its impressive size

column1: The following historical information grew out of the European Giant Alien Project
column2: which began in 2005.

column1: Heracleum mantegazzianum was first described in scientific literature in 1895 but by that time more than a dozen European countries had already imported the plant as an ‚Äúornamental curiosity.‚Äù The introduction of Heracleum mantegazzianum was first recorded in Great Britain in 1817 when it was put on the seed list at the Kew Botanic Gardens in London. By 1828

column1: The spread of Heracleum mantegazzianum throughout Europe continued unabated until the middle of the 20th century
column2: at which time the dangers of giant hogweed had become more widely known. Despite the warnings
column3: however
column4: the plant continued to be used by gardeners
column5: beekeepers
column6: and farmers (for cattle fodder) for another 50 years. Heracleum mantegazzianum was finally de-listed by the Royal Horticultural Society of Great Britain in 2002.

column2: giant hogweed was transported to the United States and Canada for display in arboreta and Victorian gardens. The earliest recorded planting in North America was in 1917

column4: New York.

column2: giant hogweed had appeared in southern Ontario

column1: On the west coast of North America

column1: Giant hogweed is native to Russia and was further distributed during the late 1960s

column1: Giant hogweed is widespread throughout western and northern Europe
column2: especially along terrains such as coastal areas and riverbanks. By forming dense stands
column3: it can displace native plants and reduce wildlife habitats. It has spread in the northeastern and northwestern United States
column4: and southern Canada and is an invasive species across western Europe; in sites where it has settled
column5: it overtakes the local native species

column7: the plant occurs in most provinces
column8: except in the prairies. It has been seen in Quebec since the early 1990s.  The plant's spread in Ontario began in the southwest and was seen in 2010 in the Greater Toronto Area and Renfrew County near Ottawa.In the United States
column9: giant hogweed occurs in Maine

column11: Michigan

column14: it was reported growing in Virginia and North Carolina. The plant is federally listed as a noxious weed in many US states.Giant hogweed is widespread in Russia and the Baltic states

column1: The sap of the giant hogweed plant is phototoxic. Contact with the plant sap prevents the skin from being able to protect itself from sunlight
column2: which leads to phytophotodermatitis
column3: a serious skin inflammation. A phototoxic reaction can begin as soon as 15 minutes after contact with the sap. Photosensitivity peaks between 30 minutes and two hours after contact but can last for several days. Authorities advise that all humans (especially children) should stay away from giant hogweed. Protective clothing
column4: including eye protection
column5: should be worn when handling the plant. Parts of the body that come into contact with the sap of giant hogweed should be immediately washed with soap and cold water
column6: and further exposure to sunlight should be avoided for at least 48 hours. Other Heracleum species

Herpestes javanicushttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javan%20mongoose"The Javan mongoose (Urva javanica) is a mongoose species native to Southeast Asia.
Ichneumon javanicus was the scientific name proposed by √âtienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire in 1818. It was later classified in the genus Herpestes
column2: but all Asian mongooses are now thought to belong in the genus Urva.In the 19th and 20th centuries
column3: several zoological specimens were described
column4: which are now considered synonyms:

column1: Herpestes exilis by Paul Gervais in 1841 was a specimen from Tourane in Vietnam.
Herpestes rafflesii by John Anderson in 1875 was a specimen from Sumatra.
Mungos rubifrons by Joel Asaph Allen in 1909 were eight adult specimens collected around Wuzhi Mountain in Hainan Island
column2: China.

column1: Mungos exilis peninsulae by Ernst Schwarz in 1910 was a skin and a skull of a mongoose collected in Bangkok.
Mungos siamensis by Cecil Boden Kloss in 1917 was a skin of an adult female mongoose collected in northern Thailand.
Mungos parakensis by Kloss in 1917 was a skin and a skull of an adult female mongoose from the vicinity of Taiping
column2: Perak in Peninsular Malaysia.

column1: Herpestes javanicus tjerapai by Henri Jacob Victor Sody in 1949 was an adult male mongoose collected in Aceh Province
column2: Sumatra.The small Indian mongoose (U. auropunctata) was once considered to be a subspecies of the Javan mongoose.

column1: Genetic analysis of hair and tissue samples from 18 Javan and small Indian mongooses revealed that they form two clades and are distinct species. The Salween River in Myanmar is probably a barrier between the two species.

Analysis of mitochondrial DNA of Urva species revealed that the Javan mongoose forms a sister group with the Indian grey mongoose (U. edwardsii). The Javan mongoose probably evolved about 0.5 million years ago in the middle Miocene.
The Javan mongoose's fur is ferruginous to sepia and rich tawny brown on the back. It has short hairs on the ears. Its tail is tapering.
The Javan mongoose is native to Myanmar
column2: Thailand
column3: Cambodia
column4: Vietnam
column5: Laos
column6: Peninsular Malaysia and the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Java
column7: where it lives up to an elevation of 1
column9: 900 ft). Its presence is uncertain in China.

column3: including degraded mixed deciduous forest
column4: dry evergreen and dry dipterocarp forests
column5: as well as in abandoned plantations and pineapple fields.
