column1: Himalayan balsam is native to the Himalayas
column2: specifically to the areas between Kashmir and Uttarakhand. In its native range it is usually found in altitudes between 2000 and 2500 m above sea level
column3: although it has been reported in up to 4000 m above sea level.In Europe the plant was first introduced into the United Kingdom by Dr John Forbes Royle
column4: professor of medicine at King's College
column5: London who became Superintendent of the Botanic Gardens
column6: Saharanpur
column7: India.  It has now become naturalized and widespread across riverbanks. Presently it can be found almost everywhere across the continent.In North America it has been found in the Canadian provinces of British Columbia
column8: Manitoba
column9: Ontario
column10: Quebec
column11: Nova Scotia
column12: New Brunswick
column13: Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland. In the United States it is found on both the east and west coast
column14: seemingly restricted to northern latitudes.In New Zealand it is sometimes found growing wild along riverbanks and wetlands.

column1: Himalayan balsam is sometimes cultivated for its flowers. It is now widely established in other parts of the world (such as the British Isles and North America)
column2: in some cases becoming a weed. Its aggressive seed dispersal
column3: coupled with high nectar production which attracts pollinators
column4: often allow it to outcompete native plants. Himalayan balsam also promotes river bank erosion due to the plant dying back over winter
column5: leaving the bank unprotected from flooding. Invasive Himalayan balsam can also adversely affect indigenous species by attracting pollinators (e.g. insects) at the expense of indigenous species. It is considered a ""prohibited noxious weed"" under the Alberta Weed Control Act 2010.In the UK
column6: the plant was first introduced in 1839
column7: at the same time as giant hogweed and Japanese knotweed. These plants were all promoted at the time as having the virtues of ""herculean proportions"" and ""splendid invasiveness"" which meant that ordinary people could buy them for the cost of a packet of seeds to rival the expensive orchids grown in the greenhouses of the rich. Within ten years
column8: however
column9: Himalayan balsam had escaped from the confines of cultivation and begun to spread along the river systems of England.It has now spread across most of the UK
column10: and some local wildlife trusts organise ""balsam bashing"" events to help control the plant. However
column11: a study by Hejda & Py≈°ek (2006) concluded that
column12: in some circumstances
column13: such efforts may cause more harm than good. Destroying riparian stands of Himalayan balsam can open up the habitat for more aggressive invasive plants such as Japanese knotweed and aid in seed dispersal by dropped seeds sticking to shoes. Riparian habitat is suboptimal for I. glandulifera
column14: and spring or autumn flooding destroys seeds and plants. The research suggests that the best way to control the spread of riparian Himalayan balsam is to decrease eutrophication
column15: thereby permitting the better-adapted local vegetation
column16: that gets outgrown by the balsam on watercourses with high nutrient load
column17: to rebound naturally. The researchers caution that their conclusions probably do not hold true for stands of the plant at forest edges and meadow habitats
column18: where manual destruction is still the best approach.

column1: The Bionic Control of Invasive Weeds project
column2: in Wiesbaden

column4: is trying to establish a self-sufficient means of conserving their local biodiversity by developing several food products made from the Himalayan balsam flowers. If all goes well
column5: the project will have it financing its own eradication.

column2: CABI released a rust fungus in Berkshire
column3: Cornwall and Middlesex in the United Kingdom as part of field trials into the biological control of Himalayan balsam.Some research also suggests that I. glandulifera may exhibit allelopathy
column4: which means that it excretes toxins that negatively affect neighboring plants
column5: thus increasing its competitive advantage.The Royal Horticultural Society and the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology recommend that pulling and cutting is the main method of non-chemical control
column6: and usually the most appropriate.Natural Resources Wales has used manual methods
column7: such as pulling plants and using strimmers
column8: to largely eradicate Himalayan Balsam from reaches of the River Ystwyth.

column1: Lithobates catesbeianushttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American%20bullfrog"The American Bulldog is a large breed of utility dog descended from the Old English Bulldog. They are now used on animal farms
column2: dog sports
column3: and for showing. They are part of American culture and history
column4: and may be used as a cultural icon for the United States. They are generally represented as being strong and tough. In November 2019
column5: the American Bulldog was added to the American Kennel Club (AKC) Foundation Stock Service (FSS).

column1: The Old English Bulldog was preserved by working class immigrants who brought their working dogs with them to the American South; these dogs are believed to have first appeared as early as the 17th century. Small farmers and ranchers used this all-around working dog for many tasks including farm guardians
column2: stock dogs and catch dogs. These dogs were not an actual breed as considered by today's standards and neither were most other dogs: kennel clubs of any kind did not yet exist and would not until 1875
column3: at least two centuries after the Old English Bulldog first migrated to America.  In the 17th and 18th century
column4: the Old English Bulldog had many different strains for cattle-droving
column5: bull-baiting
column6: farm dogs
column7: and butcher's dogs. Bull-baiting was also a common blood sport of the era and though there is evidence of such migrating to America with the landrace bulldogs brought by working class Englishmen in colonial times
column8: it is also certain that the strains that migrated to America were unaffected by the banning of the sport in 1835 in the U.K. and
column9: therefore
column10: there was no need for a decline in the population of the old-type bulldog.

column2: there are no records but rather acknowledged landrace strains that initially depended on where a dog's master originated in England
column3: the majority of which were bred to work as evidenced by accounts of the age in local newspapers and written inventories upon death. Later
column4: breeding decisions were dependent on the best working farm dogs
column5: despite breed or background. Later
column6: in states like Texas
column7: several separate strains of the ""bulldog""-type dogs were kept by ranchers as utilitarian working dogs. Other dogs in time became guard dogs on plantations.Perhaps the most important role of the American Bulldog and the reason for its survival
column8: and in fact why it thrived throughout the South
column9: was because of the presence of feral pigs
column10: introduced to the New World and without predators. The bulldogs were the settlers' only means of sufficiently dealing with the vermin.

column2: the breed was near extinction until John D. Johnson scoured the back roads of the South looking for the best specimens to revive the breed. During this time
column3: a young Alan Scott grew an interest in Johnson's dogs and began to work with him on the revitalization process. At some point
column4: Scott began infusing non-Johnson catch bulldogs from working Southern farms with Johnson's lines
column5: creating what is now known as the Standard type American Bulldog
column6: also called the Scott type. At another point
column7: Johnson began crossing his original lines with an atavistic English bulldog from the North that had maintained its genetic athletic vigor
column8: creating the Bully type American Bulldog
column9: also known as the Johnson type or the Classic type.

column1: American Bulldogs are now safe from extinction and their popularity has increased in their homeland
column2: either as a working/protector dog
column3: as a family pet
column4: or both. All over the world
column5: they are used variously as ""hog dogs"" (catching escaped pigs or hunting razorbacks)
column6: as cattle drovers
column7: and as working or sport K-9s. American Bulldogs also successfully compete in several dog sports such as dog obedience
column8: Schutzhund
column9: French Ring
column10: Mondioring
column11: Iron Dog competition and weight pulling. They are also exhibited in conformation shows in the UKC
column12: NKC
column13: ABA
column14: ABRA
column15: ORKC
column16: EKC.  The AKC added the American Bulldog to the FSS on November 11

column1: The American Bulldog is a stocky
column2: well built
column3: strong-looking dog
column4: with a large head and a muscular build. The shoulders and chest tend to be the most muscular parts of the American Bulldog. Its coat is short and generally smooth
column5: requiring little maintenance except a bath every few weeks. The breed is a light to moderate shedder. Colors
column6: while historically predominantly white with patches of red
column7: black
column8: or brindle
column9: have grown in recent years to include many color patterns including black
column10: red
column11: brown
column12: fawn
column13: and all shades of brindle. The color conformation is quite varied
column14: but solid black or any degree of merle is considered a cosmetic fault
column15: and a blue color is a disqualification by the National Kennel Club Breed Standard. Black pigmentation on the nose and eye rims is traditionally preferred
column16: with only some pink allowed. Eye color is usually brown
column17: but heterochromia also occurs
column18: although this is also considered a cosmetic fault. American Bulldogs are known to drool more than other breeds of dog. The Bully type is generally a larger
column19: heavier dog with a shorter muzzle
column20: but the muzzle should never be so short that it causes difficulty with breathing. Standard types are generally more athletic with longer muzzles and a more square head. Many modern American Bulldogs are a combination of the two types
column21: usually termed ""hybrid."" In general
column22: American Bulldogs weigh between 27 and 54 kg (60 to 120 lb) and are 52 to 70 cm (20 to 28 in) at the withers
column23: but have been known to greatly exceed these dimensions
column24: especially in the ""out of standard
column25: nonworking stock.

column2: social
column3: ebullient and lively dogs that are at ease with their families. They bond strongly with their owners
column4: and are happiest when their masters can shower them with time and attention. They are not as friendly
column5: however
column6: with people they do not know: their ancestors were farm dogs who guarded the home
column7: the livestock
column8: and the kids when their master was away. They mature later than many other breeds
column9: not until the age of two
column10: and as puppies they will be curious yet aloof with strangers
column11: but confident at maturity.Socialization of this breed is paramount: this breed should never be left alone
column12: bored
column13: in a house or garage day after day
column14: as it may become chronically fearful and aggressive towards things it does not know or understand. This is a large breed that must not become a frog in a well that only knows its home territory and it must be trained out of the dog immediately if the dog is obtained past the age of 18 months.

column1: American Bulldogs are a known breed that will destroy furniture and shoes if they are not given enough to do and this is yet another reason too much isolation is disastrous for this breed. Fear- or aggression-causing triggers can include other dogs
column2: children it does not know
column3: postal workers
column4: and strangers. An American Bulldog does not trust anyone at first sight and must learn from its master what is a threat and what is not

True aggression towards babies and young children is rare and not characteristic of how the breed is meant to behave at all-this is a breed that ordinarily likes children;  so long as it has had time to get to know  them well it is more likely to play with the kids than hurt them.  In fact
column10: this breed can be very tolerant of a child's grabby hands that tug on its ears and can be a very devoted fellow mischief maker to the young ones in his family; the American Bulldog has a playful
column11: impish streak when well-raised
column12: well-bred
column13: well-loved. and well-rounded. Owners of this breed ideally will understand that this is a high-octane
column14: powerful
column15: headstrong breed and they shall be very careful to set limitations and rules for their dog and reinforce obedience training throughout the dog's life. They will not be first-time owners of a dog and shall be firm
column16: but fair ‚Äì harsh and violent methods will not work in training this breed

column1: Ongoing training both in the home and outside of the home is essential for this breed. While the goal of the breed was originally to produce a working farm utility dog that could catch and hold wild boar and cattle

Ludwigia peploideshttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwigia%20peploides"Ludwigia peploides is a species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family known by the common names floating primrose-willow and creeping water primrose. It is native to many parts of the Americas
column2: but it can be found on many continents and spreads easily to become naturalized. It is well known as a troublesome aquatic noxious weed that invades water ecosystems and can clog waterways. This is perennial herb which grows in moist to wet to flooded areas. The stem can creep over 2 meters long
column3: sometimes branching. It spreads to form mats on the mud
column4: or floats ascending in the water. The leaves are several centimeters long and are borne in alternately arranged clusters along the stem. The flower has 5 to 6 lance-shaped sepals beneath a corolla of 5 or 6 bright yellow petals up to 2.4 centimeters long. The fruit is a hard
column5: cylindrical capsule.

column1: Ludwigia peploides are native almost all over the United States. It lives predominately along east and south west coast. States between Nevada
column2: Washington
column3: Michigan and all states north of New York do have a native species of L. peploides nor are they invasive. A country that is having a serious problem with the L. peploides are the French. It is considered the most invasive alien aquatic plants in France. They have spread all across the country at such alarming rates that it has been assigned to the German Black List of invasive species. Other counties are also wary of this incredibly invasive species so there has  been a ban on the trade of L. peploides in France
column4: Portugal
column5: Netherlands
column6: Belgium and the UK. These species cause serious problems in area where they have been introduced and a ban on trade will hopefully prevent any further damage.

column2: ecology and dispersal ==

column1: The genus Ludwigia is present worldwide. There are 23 sections consisting of 82 species in total. They can be both woody
column2: herbaceous and aquatic. They have very high levels of reproduction and efficient dispersal capacity which is a large factor in its amazing ability to take over habitats all across the world. First their reproduction. It is divided into four steps that coincide with the changing seasons. During the spring
column3: new shoots form buds. If in shallow water
column4: it is formed in an erect position
column5: but if in a drained environment
column6: they will adopt a creeping form. The stems will eventually rise to the waters surface and will then form rosettes and small round leaves. The next step occurs over the summer where apical and branches begin to form whether the species formed in an erect or creeping form. After an overall lateral extension of 50 cm flowers can begin to emerge. Between late June to early October
column7: yellow flowers are produced and reproduction can occur. Unfortunately
column8: the sexual reproduction of these plants are relatively unknown due to lack of research and can vary from species to species.  In autumn
column9: from August to November fruiting occurs. For the rest of the year
column10: the winter months
column11: the species will break up
column12: dry out and decay but it has been seen that there are cases where it can survive.

column1: The reason these plants are scattered all over the globe is because Ludwigia can be generated during all seasons just from fragments of stems or rhizomes. They can be broken as easily by wind
column2: water flow or animals. Lugwigia Peploides have the ability to double their biomass from their broken particles between 15 and 90 days. This also allows this species to continue to thrive in habitat and regions where sexual reproduction cannot occur.

column1: The Ludwigia occur predominantly in wetlands and in the transition areas between aquatic and terrestrial environments. As a result of their high plasticity lugwigia can colonize pretty much anywhere in slow flowing waters
column2: river banks and wet meadows. They do prefer slow flowing water over water with a higher velocity. Most Lugwigia species where present in stagnant water
column3: from .06 to 1 metre deep. Great depths became a constraint on their development but shoots were still able to form flower buds. If they are in a low nutrient condition
column4: Ludwigia double their biomass. The only true weakness of this species is intense levels of salinity in the water they inhabit.

column2: Ludwigia peploides  is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: cultivated
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: planted
column7: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: Ludwigia peploides is an herbaceous perennial wetland plant usually common along mud or a water surface. L. Peploides sprawl flat along the mud or waters surface. It is very similar to the Ludwigia Hexapetala and very difficult to tell apart. The leaves are arranged in clusters and vary in size. The average leaf is approximately 3.5 inches long and can be egg shaped to lance-shaped. They are hairless and each leaf's base tappers off to a stalk that ranges from 1 to 1.5 inches. The stem can grow as long as 9 feet and can be hairless or slightly hairy but are always have a fleshy texture.

Ludwigia peploides flowers start from the stem which are floating or lying on the ground. Each flower has five yellow petals 1 to 1.5 cm in length. Each occur on long stalks that on each leaf axils. The fruits and seeds do not have extensive research done so the details are unclear but there are capsules that contain many seeds. Each seed is approximately 1 mm in size.

The Ludwigia species cause dense mats which form a perfect protective habitat for mosquitoes. This cause higher rates of the West Nile Virus and other diseases that mosquitoes commonly spread. They are also a serious nuisance for human activity. Leisure activities such as hunting
column2: fishing
column3: and boating can be extremely difficult. Flood risk increases due to the decrease in channel carry capacity. The rapid and uncontrolled growth of water primrose dominates native population and are damaging irrigation and drainage networks of water bodies. Fish can have a hard time moving through these dense Ludwigia populations
column4: which then in turn effect the habitat of surface animals such as birds.

column1: Luwigia peploides are not commonly ingested. They were traded originally for ornamental purposes.
Ludwigia peploides are both melliferous and polliniferous. Numerous compounds which have medicinal properties are produced by the Ludwigia species such as saponins
column2: tannins
column3: polyphenols
column4: alkaloids
column5: linoleic acids
column6: flavonoids
column7: starch grains and calcium oxalate crystals. There are also three medical compounds which contribute to antioxidant activities. Lastly
column8: there is a potential for water waste management in agriculture. Because the plant can accumulate high concentrations of nitrogen in can decrease level of ammonia and nitrates in soil. Sadly
column9: all of these are only potential uses of the plant since there has been close to no investigation of its use. Further research is required for their medicinal and agricultural benefits to be harnessed.

column2: commonly known as Japanese stiltgrass

column5: is an annual grass that is common in a wide variety of habitats and is well adapted to low light levels.

column1: Despite being non-native in the United States
column2: it serves as a host plant for some native satyr butterflies
column3: such as the Carolina Satyr Hermeuptychia sosybius and the endangered Mitchell's Satyr Neonympha mitchellii. Owing to its invasive potential
column4: the plant has been put on the European list of invasive alien species. This means the plant can no longer be imported into or traded in the European Union.

column1: It is native in much of South Asia

column1: In 2011 Japanese stiltgrass was found in Tennessee.

It typically grows to heights between 40 and 100 cm (1.3 and 3.3 ft) and is capable of rooting at each node. The plant flowers in late summer and produces its seeds in the form of a caryopsis shortly thereafter.
It is quite similar to and often grows along with the North American grass Leersia virginica
column2: but L. virginica lacks the distinctive silver stripe on the center of the leaf that is present on Japanese stiltgrass and also flowers one to two months earlier.The plant is known to be a common habitat for ticks such as the lone star tick. Browsing deer often transport these ticks into other areas where they can expand.

column1: The plant was accidentally introduced into the U.S. state of Tennessee around 1919 as a result of being used as a packing material in shipments of porcelain from China.  It has spread throughout the Southeastern US and is now found in 26 states.   Microstegium vimineum most commonly invades along roads
column2: floodplain and other disturbed areas
column3: but will also invade undisturbed habitats. Whitetail deer
column4: which do not browse the grass
column5: may facilitate spread by browsing on native species and thereby reducing competition for the exotic plant. Invasion of Microstegium can reduce growth and flowering of native species
column6: suppress native plant communities
column7: alter and suppress insect communities
column8: slow plant succession and alter nutrient cycling.  However
column9: removal of Microstegium can lead to recovery of native plant communities.

column1: As this plant serves as a host for satyr butterflies
column2: including at least one that is ranked imperiled or endangered
column3: its removal
column4: unless accomplished via biological control
column5: should be accompanied by a careful survey to avoid destroying existing butterflies in their various stages of growth as well as to ensure adequate alternative food plant availability.Biological control is the method of control that is the least-damaging to ecosystems not typified by monoculture
column6: like forested areas
column7: while also being the most efficient in terms of costs.

column1: Biological control is the foundation of the differentiation between native species living in complex ecological balance and non-native invasive species. It is nature's method of maintaining ecological balance.  Herbicide application and human-managed labor such as mowing
column2: tilling
column3: and pulling may be preferred for managing unwanted vegetation on land that is highly disturbed by human activity
column4: such as agricultural land. For more complex ecosystems such as forests
column5: effective biological control can eliminate or greatly reduce adverse impacts such as trampling and other physical disturbance such as soil compaction
column6: the spreading of seeds from clothing
column7: chemical toxicity
column8: unwanted damage to non-targeted species
column9: demanding human labor
column10: petrochemical consumption
column11: and other factors. Biological control agents are being evaluated for their effectiveness in controlling Microstegium vimineum as well as their chance to become pests themselves.Microstegium vimineum can be controlled with pre-emergent herbicides targeted for crabgrass
column12: in areas where native grasses subject to damage are not present in quantities sufficient to make herbicide application too undesirable. Post-emergent controls can also be considered. Some herbicides that target crab grass contain calcium acid methanearsonate
column13: a chemical that contains the element arsenic. In the US
column14: the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry ranked arsenic as number 1 in its 2001 Priority List of Hazardous substances at Superfund sites. Surfactants should be added to herbicides for better control
column15: unless noted. Non-ionic surfactants are considered less damaging for other plant life
column16: while crop oil containing surfactant is often considered somewhat more effective in killing grasses. Glyphosate has been found to be effective in controlling Microstegium vimineum by using as little as a half-percent of the concentrate in water. Being a non-specific herbicide
column17: however
column18: its effectiveness can come with damage to desirable plant life. Glyphosate also binds to soil phosphate
column19: potentially causing a reduction in phosphate available for the remaining plant life. In addition to herbicides
column20: hand weeding and mowing can be used for removal
column21: in circumstances where such methods are appropriate. As this grass is an annual
column22: in order to be effective
column23: mowing must be performed before the plants go to seed.

column1: Myriophyllum heterophyllumhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myriophyllum%20heterophyllum"Myriophyllum heterophyllum (English: twoleaf watermilfoil or broadleaf watermilfoil) is a species from the genus Myriophyllum. It was first described by Andr√© Michaux.

Myriophyllum heterophyllum is also known in English as either the twoleaf watermilfoil or broadleaf watermilfoil. It is a popular plant to in Aquariums or Garden-ponds.   The species is often misidentified or overlooked due to issues in predictions of infestations and dispersal. It is often mistaken as the M. verticillatum in Europe or the M. hippuroides
column2: M. laxum or M. pinnatum in North America due to their similar vegetation.

column2: Belgium
column3: Germany
column4: Spain
column5: France
column6: Hungary and the Netherlands. Citizen science observations also suggests occurrences in the western-part of the United States and Central America.

column1: In the European Union the species naturalised in the wild and poses a thread to the biodiversity. It grows rapidly and can form dense maths just underneath the water surface causing reduced availability of Oxygen and sunlight. The European Union considers the risk of the species spreading high within the EU. As a preventative measure
column2: Myriophyllum heterophyllum is included since 2017 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies a ban of the import
column3: trade
column4: sale and transport of the species within the EU.

column1: The area known as Croatia today was inhabited throughout the prehistoric period. Fossils of Neanderthals dating to the middle Palaeolithic period have been unearthed in northern Croatia
column2: with the most famous and the best presented site in Krapina. Remnants of several Neolithic and Chalcolithic cultures were found in all regions of the country. The largest proportion of the sites is in the river valleys of northern Croatia

column1: Tomislav was the first king of Croatia

column1: === Personal union with Hungary (1102) and Habsburg Monarchy (1527) ===

This led to the formation of the Kingdom of Dalmatia and the restoration of the Croatian Littoral to the Kingdom of Croatia

column1: The 1830s and 1840s saw romantic nationalism inspire the Croatian National Revival
column2: a political and cultural campaign advocating the unity of all South Slavs in the empire. Its primary focus was establishing a standard language as a counterweight to Hungarian while promoting Croatian literature and culture. During the Hungarian Revolution of 1848
column3: Croatia sided with the Austrians
column4: Ban Josip Jelaƒçiƒá helping defeat the Hungarian forces in 1849 and ushering a Germanization policy.

column2: failure of the policy became apparent
column3: leading to the Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867. The creation of a personal union between the Austrian Empire and the Kingdom of Hungary followed. The treaty left Croatia's status to Hungary
column4: and it was resolved by the Croatian‚ÄìHungarian Settlement of 1868 when kingdoms of Croatia and Slavonia were united. The Kingdom of Dalmatia remained under de facto Austrian control
column5: while Rijeka retained the status of Corpus separatum introduced in 1779.After Austria-Hungary occupied Bosnia and Herzegovina following the 1878 Treaty of Berlin
column6: the Military Frontier was abolished. The Croatian and Slavonian sectors of the Frontier returned to Croatia in 1881
column7: under provisions of the Croatian‚ÄìHungarian Settlement. Renewed efforts to reform Austria-Hungary

column1: On 29 October 1918 the Croatian Parliament (Sabor) declared independence and decided to join the newly formed State of Slovenes
column2: Croats
column3: and Serbs
column4: which in turn entered into union with the Kingdom of Serbia on 4 December 1918 to form the Kingdom of Serbs
column5: Croats
column6: and Slovenes. The Croatian Parliament never ratified a decision to unite with Serbia and Montenegro. The 1921 constitution defining the country as a unitary state and abolition of Croatian Parliament and historical administrative divisions effectively ended Croatian autonomy.

column1: The new constitution was opposed by the most widely supported national political party‚Äîthe Croatian Peasant Party (HSS) led by Stjepan Radiƒá.The political situation deteriorated further as Radiƒá was assassinated in the National Assembly in 1928
column2: leading to the dictatorship of King Alexander in January 1929. The dictatorship formally ended in 1931 when the king imposed a more unitarian constitution and changed the name to Yugoslavia. The HSS

column5: resulting in the Cvetkoviƒá‚ÄìMaƒçek Agreement of August 1939 and the autonomous Banovina of Croatia. The Yugoslav government retained control of the defence
column6: internal security
column7: foreign affairs
column8: trade
column9: and transport while other matters were left to the Croatian Sabor and a crown-appointed Ban.

column2: Yugoslavia was occupied by Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy. Following the invasion
column3: most of Croatia
column4: Bosnia and Herzegovina
column5: and the region of Syrmia were incorporated into the Independent State of Croatia (NDH)
column6: a Nazi-backed puppet state. Parts of Dalmatia were annexed by Italy and the northern Croatian regions of Baranja and Meƒëimurje by Hungary. The NDH regime was led by Ante Paveliƒá and ultranationalist Usta≈°e
column7: a fringe movement in pre-war Croatia. With German and Italian military and political support

column9: Jews
column10: and Roma. Many were imprisoned in concentration camps
column11: the largest of which was the Jasenovac complex. Anti-fascist Croats were targeted by the regime as well. Several concentration camps (most notably the Rab

column14: the Yugoslav Royalist and Serbian nationalist Chetniks pursued a genocidal campaign against Croats and Muslims
column15: aided by fascist Italy.A resistance movement soon emerged. On 22 June 1941
column16: the 1st Sisak Partisan Detachment was formed near Sisak
column17: the first military unit formed by a resistance movement in occupied Europe. That sparked the beginning of the Yugoslav Partisan movement
column18: a communist multi-ethnic anti-fascist resistance group led by Josip Broz Tito. In ethnic terms

column20: Croats contributed proportionately to their population within Yugoslavia as a whole. By May 1944 (according to Tito)
column21: Croats made up 30% of the Partisan's ethnic composition
column22: despite making up 22% of the population. The movement grew fast

column2: equipment
column3: training and airpower

column5: the Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia and the border regions of Italy and Austria by May 1945. Members of the NDH armed forces and other Axis troops

column2: Croatia became a single-party socialist federal unit of the SFR Yugoslavia
column3: ruled by the Communists
column4: but having a degree of autonomy within the federation. In 1967

column6: culminating in the Croatian Spring of 1971

column8: the 1974 Yugoslav Constitution gave increased autonomy to federal units
column9: basically fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents.Following the death of Yugoslav President Josip Broz Tito in 1980
column10: the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated
column11: with national tension fanned by the 1986 SANU Memorandum and the 1989 coups in Vojvodina
column12: Kosovo
column13: and Montenegro. In January 1990
column14: the Communist Party fragmented along national lines
column15: with the Croatian faction demanding a looser federation. In the same year
column16: the first multi-party elections were held in Croatia

column18: intent on achieving independence from Croatia.

column2: Croatia declared independence on 25 June 1991. However
column3: the full implementation of the declaration only came into effect on 8 October 1991. In the meantime
column4: tensions escalated into overt war when the Yugoslav People's Army (JNA) and various Serb paramilitary groups attacked Croatia. By the end of 1991
column5: a high-intensity conflict fought along a wide front reduced Croatia's control of only about two-thirds of its territory. The various Serb paramilitary groups then began pursuing a campaign of killing
column6: terror
column7: and expulsion of the Croats in the rebel territories
column8: killing thousands of Croat civilians and expelling or displacing as many as 400
column9: 000 Croats and other non-Serbs from their homes. Meanwhile
column10: Serbs living in Croatian towns
column11: especially those near the front lines
column12: were subjected to various forms of discrimination. Croatian Serbs in Eastern and Western Slavonia and parts of the Krajina
column13: were also forced to flee or were expelled by Croatian forces
column14: though on a restricted scale and in lesser numbers. The Croatian Government sought to stop such occurrences and were not a part of the Government's policy.On 15 January 1992
column15: Croatia gained diplomatic recognition by the European Economic Community members
column16: and subsequently the United Nations. The war effectively ended in August 1995 with a decisive victory by Croatia; the event is commemorated each year on 5 August as Victory and Homeland Thanksgiving Day and the Day of Croatian Defenders. Following the Croatian victory
column17: about 200
column18: 000 Serbs from the self-proclaimed Republic of Serbian Krajina fled from the region and hundreds of mainly elderly Serb civilians were killed in the aftermath of the military operation. Their lands were subsequently settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina. The remaining occupied areas were restored to Croatia following the Erdut Agreement of November 1995
column19: with the UNTAES mission concluded in January 1998. Each year
column20: Croatia commemorates the fall of Vukovar on November 18

column22: the Remembrance Day for Homeland War Victims and Remembrance Day for the Victims of Vukovar and Skabrnja became a national holiday.

column1: After the end of the war

column4: advancing democratic principles
column5: protection of human rights
column6: and general social and economic development. The post-2000 period is characterised by democratisation
column7: economic growth

column9: as well as problems such as unemployment
column10: corruption
column11: and the inefficiency of the public administration.Croatia joined the Partnership for Peace on 25 May 2000

column1: and became a member of the World Trade Organization on 30 November 2000.

column1: Although the Croatian economy had enjoyed a significant boom in the early 2000s
column2: the financial crisis in 2008 forced the government to cut public spending

column4: Croatia joined NATO. A wave of anti-government protests in early 2011 reflected a general dissatisfaction with the political and economic state.Croatia completed EU accession negotiations in 2011. A majority of Croatian voters opted in favour of country's EU membership at the 2012 referendum

column1: and Croatia joined the European Union effective 1 July 2013. Croatia was affected by the 2015 European migrant crisis in 2015 when Hungary's closure of its borders with Serbia forced over 700
column2: 000 refugees and migrants to pass through Croatia on their way to Western Europe.On 22 March 2020
column3: a 5.5 earthquake struck Croatia
column4: with the epicentre located 7 kilometres (4.3 mi) north of Zagreb city centre
column5: inflicting heavy structural damage in the historic city centre and causing 27 injuries with one fatality. Over 1
column6: 900 buildings were reported to have become uninhabitable by the earthquake damage. On 29 December 2020
column7: a 6.4 magnitude earthquake struck central Croatia
column8: with an epicentre located roughly 3 km (1.9 mi) west-southwest of Petrinja. The maximum felt intensity was estimated at VIII (Heavily damaging) to IX (Destructive) on the European macroseismic scale. Seven people were confirmed dead
column9: while 26 others were injured
column10: with six having serious injuries.  Both Petrinja and the Sisak-Moslavina county were severely damaged.

column1: Croatia is in Central and Southeast Europe

Part of the territory in the extreme south surrounding Dubrovnik is a practical exclave connected to the rest of the mainland by territorial waters

Natural resources found in the country in quantities significant enough for production include oil

column1: Most of Croatia has a moderately warm and rainy continental climate as defined by the K√∂ppen climate classification. Mean monthly temperature ranges between ‚àí3 ¬∞C (27 ¬∞F) in January and 18 ¬∞C (64 ¬∞F) in July. The coldest parts of the country are Lika and Gorski Kotar where the snowy forested climate is found at elevations above 1

column3: 900 feet). The warmest areas of Croatia are at the Adriatic coast and especially in its immediate hinterland characterised by the Mediterranean climate

column1: Croatia can be subdivided between several ecoregions because of its climate and geomorphology. The country is consequently one of the richest in Europe in terms of biodiversity. There are four types of biogeographical regions in Croatia‚Äîthe Mediterranean along the coast and in its immediate hinterland
column2: Alpine in most of Lika and Gorski Kotar
column3: Pannonian along Drava and Danube
column4: and Continental in the remaining areas. The most significant are karst habitats which include submerged karst
column5: such as Zrmanja and Krka canyons and tufa barriers
column6: as well as underground habitats. The country contains three ecoregions: Dinaric Mountains mixed forests
column7: Pannonian mixed forests
column8: and Illyrian deciduous forests.The karst geology harbours approximately 7
column9: 000 caves and pits
column10: some of which are the habitat of the only known aquatic cave vertebrate‚Äîthe olm. Forests are also significantly present in the country
column11: as they cover 2
column13: 000 hectares (6
column15: 000 acres) representing 44% of Croatian land area. Other habitat types include wetlands
column16: grasslands
column17: bogs
column18: fens
column19: scrub habitats
column20: coastal and marine habitats.

column2: Croatia is a part of the Boreal Kingdom and is a part of Illyrian and Central European provinces of the Circumboreal Region and the Adriatic province of the Mediterranean Region. The World Wide Fund for Nature divides Croatia between three ecoregions‚ÄîPannonian mixed forests
column3: Dinaric Mountains mixed forests and Illyrian deciduous forests.

column2: 000 known species in Croatia

column3: ranking it 113th globally out of 172 countries.The invasive algae are regularly monitored and removed to protect the benthic habitat. Indigenous sorts of cultivated plants and breeds of domesticated animals are also numerous. Those include five breeds of horses
column4: five breeds of cattle
column5: eight breeds of sheep
column6: two breeds of pigs
column7: and a poultry breed. The indigenous breeds include nine endangered or critically endangered ones. There are 444 protected areas of Croatia
column8: encompassing 9% of the country. Those include eight national parks
column9: two strict reserves
column10: and ten nature parks. The most famous protected area and the oldest national park in Croatia is the Plitvice Lakes National Park
column11: a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Velebit Nature Park is a part of the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Programme. The strict and special reserves
column12: as well as the national and nature parks
column13: are managed and protected by the central government
column14: while other protected areas are managed by counties. In 2005
column15: the National Ecological Network was set up
column16: as the first step in the preparation of the EU accession and joining of the Natura 2000 network.

column1: The Republic of Croatia is a unitary state using a parliamentary system of governance. With the collapse of the ruling communist party in SFR Yugoslavia
column2: Croatia organised its first multi-party elections and adopted its present Constitution in 1990. It declared independence on 8 October 1991 which led to the break-up of Yugoslavia and countries international recognition by the United Nations in 1992. Under its 1990 Constitution
column3: Croatia operated a semi-presidential system until 2000 when it switched to a parliamentary system. Government powers in Croatia are legislative
column4: executive
column5: and judiciary powers.

column1: The President of the Republic (Croatian: Predsjednik Republike) is the head of state
column2: directly elected to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to two terms. In addition to being the commander in chief of the armed forces
column3: the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the parliament and has some influence on foreign policy. The most recent presidential elections were held on 5 January 2020
column4: when Zoran Milanoviƒá became the new president. He took the oath of office on 18 February 2020.

column1: The Government is headed by the Prime Minister
column2: who has four deputy prime ministers and 16 ministers in charge of particular sectors. As the executive branch
column3: it is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget
column4: executing the laws
column5: and guiding the foreign and internal policies. The Government is seated at Banski dvori in Zagreb. Since 19 October 2016
column6: Croatian Prime Minister has been Andrej Plenkoviƒá.A unicameral parliament (Sabor) holds legislative power. A second chamber
column7: the House of Counties
column8: set up in 1993 according to the 1990 Constitution
column9: was abolished in 2001. The number of Sabor members can vary from 100 to 160. They are all elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms. The sessions of the Sabor take place from 15 January to 15 July
column10: and from 15 September to 15 December. The two largest political parties in Croatia are the Croatian Democratic Union and the Social Democratic Party of Croatia.

column1: Croatia has a civil law legal system in which law arises primarily from written statutes
column2: with judges serving merely as implementers and not creators of law. Its development was largely influenced by German and Austrian legal systems. Croatian law is divided into two principal areas‚Äîprivate and public law. By the time EU accession negotiations were completed on 30 June 2010
column3: Croatian legislation was fully harmonised with the Community acquis. The main law in the country is the Constitution adopted on 22 December 1990.

column1: The main national courts are the Constitutional Court
column2: which oversees violations of the Constitution
column3: and the Supreme Court
column4: which is the highest court of appeal. There are also Administrative
column5: Commercial
column6: County
column7: Misdemeanor
column8: and Municipal courts. Cases falling within judicial jurisdiction are in the first instance decided by a single professional judge
column9: while appeals are deliberated in mixed tribunals of professional judges. Lay magistrates also participate in trials. State's Attorney Office is the judicial body constituted of public prosecutors empowered to instigate prosecution of perpetrators of offences.Law enforcement agencies are organised under the authority of the Ministry of the Interior which consist primarily of the national police force. Croatia's security service is the Security and Intelligence Agency (SOA).

column1: Croatia has established diplomatic relations with 194 countries. As of 2020
column2: Croatia maintains a network of 57 embassies
column3: 30 consulates and eight permanent diplomatic missions abroad. Furthermore
column4: there are 56 foreign embassies and 67 consulates in the Republic of Croatia in addition to offices of international organisations such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD)
column5: International Organization for Migration (IOM)
column6: Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE)
column7: World Bank

column9: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY)
column10: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)
column11: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
column12: and UNICEF.

column2: the Croatian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration employed 1
column3: 381 personnel and expended 765.295 million kunas (‚Ç¨101.17 million). Stated aims of Croatian foreign policy include enhancing relations with neighbouring countries
column4: developing international co-operation and promotion of the Croatian economy and Croatia itself.Since 2003
column5: Croatian foreign policy has focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming a member state of the European Union (EU). In December 2011
column6: Croatia completed the EU accession negotiations and signed an EU accession treaty on 9 December 2011. Croatia joined the European Union on 1 July 2013 marking the end of a process started in 2001 by signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and Croatian application for the EU membership in 2003. A recurring obstacle to the negotiations was Croatia's ICTY co-operation record and Slovenian blocking of the negotiations because of Croatia‚ÄìSlovenia border disputes. The latter should be resolved through an Arbitration Agreement of 4 November 2009
column7: approved by national parliaments and a referendum in Slovenia
column8: but due to the events during arbitration
column9: Croatia does not accept results. As of 2021
column10: Croatia has unsolved border issues with all neighbouring former Yugoslav countries (Bosnia and Herzegovina
column11: Montenegro
column12: Serbia
column13: Slovenia).Another strategic Croatian foreign policy goal for the 2000s was NATO membership. Croatia was included in the Partnership for Peace in 2000
column14: invited to NATO membership in 2008 and formally joined the alliance on 1 April 2009. Croatia became a member of the United Nations Security Council for the 2008‚Äì2009 term
column15: assuming the presidency in December 2008. The country is preparing to join the Schengen Area.

column1: The Croatian Armed Forces (CAF) consist of the Air Force
column2: Army
column3: and Navy branches in addition to the Education and Training Command and Support Command. The CAF is headed by the General Staff
column4: which reports to the Defence Minister
column5: who in turn reports to the President. According to the constitution
column6: the President is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces. In case of immediate threat during wartime
column7: he issues orders directly to the General Staff.Following the 1991‚Äì95 war
column8: defence spending and CAF size have been in constant decline. As of 2019
column9: military spending was an estimated 1.68% of the country's GDP
column10: which placed Croatia 67th. Since 2005 the budget has been kept below 2% of GDP
column11: down from the record high of 11.1% in 1994. Traditionally relying on many conscripts
column12: the CAF also went through a period of reforms focused on downsizing
column13: restructuring and professionalisation in the years before accession to NATO in April 2009. According to a presidential decree issued in 2006
column14: the CAF employs around 18
column15: 100 active duty military personnel
column17: 000 civilians and 2
column18: 000 voluntary conscripts between 18 and 30 years old in peacetime.Compulsory conscription was abolished in January 2008. Until 2008 military service was obligatory for men at age 18 and conscripts served six-month tours of duty
column19: reduced in 2001 from the earlier scheme of nine-month conscription tours. Conscientious objectors could instead opt for an eight-month civilian service.As of May 2019
column20: the Croatian military had 72 members stationed in foreign countries as part of United Nations-led international peacekeeping forces. As of 2019
column21: 323 troops serve the NATO-led ISAF force in Afghanistan. Another 156 with the KFOR in Kosovo.Croatia also has a military industry sector which exported around 493 million kunas (‚Ç¨65
column22: 176 million) worth of military equipment and armament in 2020. Croatian-made weapons and vehicles used by CAF include the standard sidearm HS2000 manufactured by HS Produkt and the M-84D battle tank designed by the ƒêuro ƒêakoviƒá factory. Uniforms and helmets worn by CAF soldiers are also locally produced and successfully marketed to other countries.

column2: 688 billion

column1: Tourism dominates the Croatian service sector and accounts for up to 20% of Croatian GDP. Tourist industry income for 2019 was estimated to be ‚Ç¨10.5 billion. Its positive effects are felt through the Croatian economy in terms of increased business volume observed in a retail business
column2: processing industry orders and summer seasonal employment. The industry is an export business because it significantly reduces the country's external trade imbalance. Since the end of the Croatian War of Independence
column3: the tourist industry has rapidly grown
column4: recording a fourfold rise in tourist numbers
column5: with more than 11 million tourists each year. The most numerous are tourists from Germany
column6: Slovenia
column7: Austria
column8: Italy
column9: and Poland as well as Croatia itself. Length of a tourist stay in Croatia averaged 4.7 days in 2019.Much of the tourist industry is concentrated along the Adriatic Sea coast. Opatija was the first holiday resort. It first became popular in the middle of the 19th century. By the 1890s
column10: it had become one of the most significant European health resorts. Later many resorts sprang up along the coast and islands
column11: offering services catering to mass tourism and various niche markets. The most significant are nautical tourism
column12: as there are marinas with more than 16 thousand berths
column13: cultural tourism relying on the appeal of medieval coastal cities and cultural events taking place during the summer. Inland areas offer agrotourism
column14: mountain resorts
column15: and spas. Zagreb is also a significant tourist destination
column16: rivalling major coastal cities and resorts.Croatia has unpolluted marine areas with nature reserves and 116 Blue Flag beaches. Croatia ranks as the 23rd most popular tourist destination in the world. About 15% of these visitors
column17: or over one million per year
column18: are involved with naturism
column19: for which Croatia is famous. It was the first European country to develop commercial naturist resorts.

column1: The highlight of Croatia's recent infrastructure developments is its rapidly developed motorway network

column3: Croatia had completed 1

column6: connecting Zagreb to Split and the A3

The high quality and safety levels of the Croatian motorway network were tested and confirmed by several EuroTAP and EuroTest programmes.Croatia has an extensive rail network spanning 2
column2: 722 kilometres (1
column3: 691 miles)
column4: including 984 kilometres (611 miles) of electrified railways and 254 kilometres (158 miles) of double track railways. The most significant railways in Croatia are within the Pan-European transport corridors Vb and X connecting Rijeka to Budapest and Ljubljana to Belgrade
column5: both via Zagreb. Croatian Railways operates all rail services.The construction of 2.4-kilometer-long Peljesac Bridge

The construction of the Peljesac bridge started in July 2018 after Croatian road operator Hrvatske ceste (HC) signed a 2.08 billion kuna deal for the works with a Chinese consortium led by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC). The project is co-financed by the European Union with 357 million euro.

column1: The busiest cargo seaport in Croatia is the Port of Rijeka. The busiest passenger ports are Split and Zadar. Many minor ports serve ferries connecting numerous islands and coastal cities with ferry lines to several cities in Italy. The largest river port is Vukovar

column5: and several transhipment terminals. The system has a capacity of 20 million tonnes per year. The natural gas transportation system comprises 2

column13: hydropower (25.4%)

column1: With an estimated population of 4.13 million in 2019
column2: Croatia ranks 127th by population in the world. Its population density stood in 2018 at 72
column3: 9 inhabitants per square kilometre
column4: making Croatia one of the more sparsely populated European countries. The overall life expectancy in Croatia at birth was 76.3 years in 2018.The total fertility rate of 1.41 children per mother
column5: is one of the lowest in the world
column6: below the replacement rate of 2.1
column7: it remains considerably below the high of 6.18 children born per woman in 1885. Since 1991
column8: Croatia's death rate has continuously exceeded its birth rate. Croatia subsequently has one of the oldest populations in the world
column9: with the average age of 43.3 years. Since the late 1990s
column10: there has been a positive net migration into Croatia
column11: reaching a level of more than 26
column12: 000 net immigrants in 2018. The Croatian Bureau of Statistics forecast that the population may shrink to 3.85 million by 2061
column13: depending on actual birth rate and the level of net migration. The population of Croatia rose steadily from 2.1 million in 1857 until 1991
column14: when it peaked at 4.7 million
column15: with exception of censuses taken in 1921 and 1948
column16: i.e. following two world wars. The natural growth rate of the population is currently negative with the demographic transition completed in the 1970s. In recent years
column17: the Croatian government has been pressured each year to increase permit quotas for foreign workers
column18: reaching an all-time high of 68.100 in 2019. In accordance with its immigration policy
column19: Croatia is trying to entice emigrants to return.The population decrease was also a result of the Croatian War of Independence. During the war
column20: large sections of the population were displaced and emigration increased. In 1991
column21: in predominantly occupied areas
column22: more than 400
column23: 000 Croats were either removed from their homes by the rebel Serb forces or fled the violence. During the final days of the war in 1995
column24: about 150‚Äì200
column25: 000 Serbs fled before the arrival of Croatian forces during the Operation Storm. After the war
column26: the number of displaced persons fell to about 250
column27: 000. The Croatian government has taken care of displaced persons by the social security system
column28: and since December 1991 through the Office of Displaced Persons and Refugees. Most of the territories which were abandoned during the Croatian War of Independence were settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina
column29: mostly from north-western Bosnia
column30: while some of the displaced people returned to their homes.According to the 2013 United Nations report
column31: 17.6% of Croatia's population were foreign-born immigrants. Majority of the inhabitants of Croatia are Croats (90.4%)
column32: followed by Serbs (4.4%)
column33: Bosniaks (0.73%)
column35: Albanians (0.41%)
column43: and others (2.12%). Approximately 4 million Croats live abroad.

column1: Croatia has no official religion. Freedom of religion is a right defined by the Constitution which also defines all religious communities as equal before the law and separated from the state. According to the 2011 census
column2: 91.36% of Croatians identify as Christian; of these
column3: Catholics make up the largest group
column4: accounting for 86.28% of the population
column5: after which follows Eastern Orthodoxy (4.44%)
column6: Protestantism (0.34%)

column9: 70% answered yes to the question ""Is religion an important part of your daily life?"" However
column10: only 24% of the population attends religious services regularly.

column1: Croatian is the official language of Croatia and became the 24th official language of the European Union upon its accession in 2013. Minority languages are in official use in local government units where more than a third of the population consists of national minorities or where local legislation defines so. Those languages are Czech

column3: Italian
column4: Serbian

column2: 95.6% of citizens of Croatia declared Croatian as their native language
column3: 1.2% declared Serbian as their native language
column4: while no other language is represented in Croatia by more than 0.5% of native speakers among the population of Croatia. Croatian is a member of the South Slavic languages of Slavic languages group and is written using the Latin alphabet. There are three major dialects spoken on the territory of Croatia
column5: with standard Croatian based on the Shtokavian dialect. The Chakavian and Kajkavian dialects are distinguished by their lexicon
column6: phonology and syntax.Croatian replaced Latin as the official language of the Croatian government in the 19th century. In Yugoslavia
column7: from 1972 to 1989
column8: the language was constitutionally designated as the ""Croatian literary language"" and the ""Croatian or Serbian language"". It was the result of the resistance to ""Serbo-Croatian"" in the form of a Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language and Croatian Spring. Croatians are protective of their language from foreign influences and are known for Croatian linguistic purism
column9: as the language was under constant change and threats imposed by previous rulers
column10: i.e. loanwords are replaced with native Croatian counterparts.A 2011 survey revealed that 78% of Croatians claim knowledge of at least one foreign language. According to a survey ordered by the European Commission in 2005
column11: 49% of Croatians speak English as the second language
column12: 34% speak German
column13: 14% speak Italian
column14: and 10% speak French. Russian is spoken by 4%
column15: and 2% of Croatians speak Spanish. However there are large municipalities that have minority languages that include substantial populations that speak these languages. A majority of Slovenes (59%) have a certain level of knowledge of Croatian. The country is a part of various language-based international associations most notably the European Union Language Association.

column1: Literacy in Croatia stands at 99.2 per cent. A worldwide study about the quality of living in different countries published by Newsweek in August 2010 ranked the Croatian education system at 22nd

column2: Croatia represents a blend of four different cultural spheres. It has been a crossroads of influences from western culture and the east since the schism between the Western Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire

Further activities supporting the development of culture are undertaken at the local government level. The UNESCO's World Heritage List includes ten sites in Croatia. The country is also rich with intangible culture and holds 15 of UNESCO's World's intangible culture masterpieces

column2: Masqa·π≠ pronounced [ÀàmasqatÀ§]) is the capital city and is the most populated city in Oman. It is the seat of the Governorate of Muscat. According to the National Centre for Statistics and Information (NCSI)
column3: the total population of Muscat Governorate was 1.4 million as of September 2018. The metropolitan area spans approximately 3
column5: 400 sq mi) and includes six provinces called wilayats. Known since the early 1st century AD as an important trading port between the west and the east
column6: Muscat was ruled by various indigenous tribes as well as foreign powers such as the Persians
column7: the Portuguese Empire
column8: the Iberian Union and the Ottoman Empire at various points in its history. A regional military power in the 18th century
column9: Muscat's influence extended as far as East Africa and Zanzibar. As an important port-town in the Gulf of Oman
column10: Muscat attracted foreign tradesmen and settlers such as the Persians and the Balochis. Since the ascension of Qaboos bin Said as Sultan of Oman in 1970
column11: Muscat has experienced rapid infrastructural development that has led to the growth of a vibrant economy and a multi-ethnic society. Muscat is termed as a Beta - Global City by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network.The rocky Western Al Hajar Mountains dominate the landscape of Muscat. The city lies on the Arabian Sea along the Gulf of Oman and is in the proximity of the strategic Straits of Hormuz. Low-lying white buildings typify most of Muscat's urban landscape
column12: while the port-district of Muttrah
column13: with its corniche and harbour
column14: form the north-eastern periphery of the city. Muscat's economy is dominated by trade
column15: petroleum
column16: liquified natural gas and porting.

column1: Ptolemy's Map of Arabia identifies the territories of Cryptus Portus and Moscha Portus. Scholars are divided in opinion on which of the two is related to the city of Muscat. Similarly
column2: Arrianus references Omana and Moscha in Voyage of Nearchus. Interpretations of Arrianus' work by William Vincent and Jean Baptiste Bourguignon d'Anville conclude that Omana was a reference to Oman
column3: while Moscha referred to Muscat. Similarly
column4: other scholars identify Pliny the Elder's reference to Amithoscuta to be Muscat.The origin of the word Muscat is disputed. Some authors claim that the word has Arabic origins ‚Äì from moscha
column5: meaning an inflated hide or skin. Other authors claim that the name Muscat means anchorage or the place of ""letting fall the anchor"". Other derivations include muscat from Old Persian
column6: meaning strong-scented
column7: or from Arabic
column8: meaning falling-place
column9: or hidden.Cryptus Portus is synonymous with Oman (""hidden land""). But ""Ov-man"" (Omman)
column10: and the old Sumerian name Magan (Maa-kan)
column11: means sea-people in Arabic. An inhabitant is a Muscatter
column12: Muscatian
column13: Muscatite or Muscatan.

column1: In 1793 AD the capital was transferred from Rustaq to Muscat.
Founded 900 years ago and famous for its historical role
column2: it is an oasis of greenery
column3: cleanliness and order
column4: characterized by a modern road network and advanced organized services.

column1: Evidence of communal activity in the area around Muscat dates back to the 6th millennium BCE in Ras al-Hamra
column2: where burial sites of fishermen have been found. The graves appear to be well formed and indicate the existence of burial rituals. South of Muscat
column3: remnants of Harappan pottery indicate some level of contact with the Indus Valley Civilisation. Muscat's notability as a port was acknowledged as early as the 1st century CE by the Greek geographer Ptolemy
column4: who referred to it as Cryptus Portus (the Hidden Port)
column5: and by Pliny the Elder
column6: who called it Amithoscuta.The port fell to a Sassanid invasion in the 3rd century CE
column7: under the rule of Shapur I
column8: while conversion to Islam occurred during the 7th century. Muscat's importance as a trading port continued to grow in the centuries that followed
column9: under the influence of the Azd dynasty
column10: a local tribe. The establishment of the First Imamate in the 9th century was the first step in consolidating disparate Omani tribal factions under the banner of an Ibadi state. However
column11: tribal skirmishes continued
column12: allowing the Abbasids of Baghdad to conquer Oman. The Abbasids occupied the region until the 11th century
column13: when they were driven out by the local Yahmad tribe. Power over Oman shifted from the Yahmad tribe to the Azdi Nabahinah clan
column14: during whose rule
column15: the people of coastal ports such as Muscat prospered from maritime trade and close alliances with the Indian subcontinent
column16: at the cost of the alienation of the people of the interior of Oman.

column1: The Portuguese admiral Afonso de Albuquerque sailed to Muscat in 1507
column2: in an attempt to establish trade relations. As he approached the harbor
column3: his ships were fired on. He then decided to conquer Muscat. Most of the city burned to the ground during and after the fighting.

column1: The Portuguese maintained a hold on Muscat for over a century
column2: despite challenges from Persia and a bombardment of the town by the Ottoman Turks in 1546. The Turks twice captured Muscat from the Portuguese
column3: in the Capture of Muscat (1552) and 1581‚Äì88. The election of Nasir bin Murshid Al-Ya'rubi as Imam of Oman in 1624 changed the balance of power again in the region
column4: from the Persians and the Portuguese to local Omanis. Among the most important castles and forts in Muscat
column5: the Al Jalali Fort and the Al-Mirani Fort are the most prominent buildings left by the Portuguese. On August 16
column6: 1648 the Imam dispatched an army to Muscat
column7: which captured and demolished the high towers of the Portuguese
column8: weakening their grip over the town. Decisively
column10: a small but determined body of the Imam's troops attacked the port at night
column11: forcing an eventual Portuguese surrender on January 23
column12: 1650. A civil war and repeated incursions by the Persian king Nader Shah in the 18th century destabilised the region
column13: and further strained relations between the interior and Muscat. This power vacuum in Oman led to the emergence of the Al Bu Sa‚Äòid dynasty
column14: which has ruled Oman ever since.

column1: Muscat's naval and military supremacy was re-established in the 19th century by Said bin Sultan
column2: who signed a treaty with U.S. President Andrew Jackson's representative Edmund Roberts on September 21

column2: the fortunes of the Al Bu Sa`id declined and friction with the Imams of the interior resurfaced. Muscat and Muttrah were attacked by tribes from the interior in 1895 and again in 1915. A tentative ceasefire was brokered by the British
column3: which gave the interior more autonomy. However

column9: amidst the civilian armed conflict. On July 23

column1: Muscat is located in northeast Oman. The Tropic of Cancer passes south of the area. It is bordered to its west by the plains of the Al Batinah Region and to its east by Ash Sharqiyah Region. The interior plains of Ad Dakhiliyah Region border Muscat to the south

The Qurum Nature Reserve contains plants such as the Arthrocnemum Macrostachyum and Halopeplis Perfoliata. Coral reefs are common in Muscat. Muscat's main trading port

column4: the Indian subcontinent and the Far East with an annual volume of about 1.6 million tons. However
column5: the emergence of the Jebel Ali Free Zone in neighboring Dubai
column6: United Arab Emirates
column7: has made that port the premier maritime trading port of the region with about 44 million tons traded in cargo annually. Many infrastructural facilities are owned and operated by the government of Oman. Omantel is the major telecommunications organization in Oman and provides local
column8: long-distance and international dialing facilities and operates as the country's only ISP. Recent liberalization of the mobile telephone market has seen the establishment of a second provider
column9: Ooredoo.Muscat is home to multibillion-dollar conglomerate CK Industries with their headquarters located in Ruwi. Ajman based Amtek Industries also have a couple of offices around the city. It is also home to Galfar Engineering
column10: headed by P. Mohammed Ali.

column1: The airline Oman Air has its head office on the grounds of Muscat International Airport.
According to the 2003 census conducted by the Oman Ministry of National Economy
column2: the population of Muscat is over 630
column4: which included 370
column5: 000 males and 260
column6: 000 females. Muscat formed the second largest governorate in the country
column7: after Al Batinah
column8: accounting for 27% of the total population of Oman. As of 2003
column9: Omanis constituted 60% of the total population of Muscat
column10: while expatriates accounted for about 40%. The population density of the city was 162.1 per km2.

column1: The governorate of Muscat comprises six wilayats: Muttrah
column2: Bawshar
column3: Seeb
column4: Al Amrat
column5: Muscat and Qurayyat. Seeb
column6: located in the western section of the governorate
column7: was the most populous (with over 220
column8: 000 residents)
column9: while Muttrah had the highest number of expatriates (with over 100
column10: 000). Approximately 71% of the population was within the 15‚Äì64 age group
column11: with the average Omani age being 23 years. About 10% of the population is illiterate
column12: an improvement when compared to the 18% illiteracy rate recorded during the 1993 census. Expatriates accounted for over 60% of the labour force
column13: dominated by males
column14: who accounted for 80% of the city's total labour. A majority of expatriates (34%) engineering-related occupations
column15: while most Omanis worked in engineering
column16: clerical
column17: scientific or technical fields. The defense sector was the largest employer for Omanis
column18: while construction
column19: wholesale and retail trade employed the largest number of expatriates.

column1: The ethnic makeup of Muscat has historically been influenced by people not native to the Arabian Peninsula. British Parliamentary papers dating back to the 19th century indicate the presence of a significant Hindu Gujarati merchants in the city Indeed
column2: four Hindu temples existed in Muscat ca. 1760. Christianity flourished in Oman (Bƒì·πØ Maz≈´nƒÅyƒì ""land of the Maganites""; a name deriving from its Sumerian designation) from the late 4th century to early 5th century. Missionary activity by the Assyrians of the Church of the East resulted in a significant Christian population living in the region
column3: with a bishop being attested by 424 AD under the Metropolitan of Fars and Arabia. The rise of Islam saw the Syriac and Arabic-speaking Christian population eventually disappear. It is thought to have been brought back in by the Portuguese in 1507. Protestant missionaries established a hospital in Muscat in the 19th century.

column2: Arabic is the predominant language of the city. In addition
column3: English
column4: Balochi

column10: Marathi
column11: Odia
column12: Tamil

column1: Islam is the predominant religion in the city
column2: with most followers being Ibadi Muslims. Non-Muslims are allowed to practice their religion
column3: but may not proselytize publicly or distribute religious literature. In 2017 the Sultanate of Oman unveiled the Mushaf Muscat
column4: an interactive calligraphic Quran following a brief from the Omani Ministry of Endowments and Religious Affairs

column1: The city has numerous mosques including the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque
column2: Ruwi Mosque
column3: Saeed bin Taimoor and Zawawi Mosque. A few Shi'ite mosques also exist here.

column7: Sultan's Armed Forces Museum and the Omani Aquarium and Marine Science and Fisheries Centre. The Bait Al Falaj Fort played an important role in Muscat's military history.

column1: Recent projects include an opera house which opened on October 14

One of the most notable new projects is the Oman National Museum. It is expected to be an architectural jewel along with the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque. Visitors are also encouraged to visit Old Muscat and the Old Palace. The main shopping district is situated in Al Qurum Commercial Area. However
column2: shopping malls are spread out throughout the city. One of the largest malls in Oman is Oman Avenues Mall

column4: near the international airport
column5: called City Centre Muscat
column6: housing all major international brands and the largest Carrefour hypermarket. Two new megamalls opened recently in the Mabela area of Muscat are Al Araimi Boulevard and Mall of Muscat. Mall of Muscat is also home to Oman Aquarium and a snow park which will be opened in late 2019.

column1: Sultan Qaboos Port serves as one of the most important ports of Muscat Governorate
column2: which is well known for being sailing of many commercial ships and boats. Here also
column3: the traditional boats of Arabian Peninsula named Dhows can be also seen. This port since many centuries have been a main commercial and financial centre in terms of its international maritime trade.

column1: The main airport is Muscat International Airport (formerly known as Seeb International Airport) around 25 km (16 mi) from the city's business district of Ruwi and 15 to 20 km from the main residential localities of Al-Khuwair
column2: Madinat Al Sultan Qaboos

column1: The Muscat area is well serviced by paved roads and dual-carriageway connects most major cities and towns in the country.

column1: Routes 1b and 1A are special buses to Muscat International Airport.Several forms of public transport are popular in Oman. Most popular are the ""Baiza"" buses
column2: so named for the lower denomination of the Omani rial
column3: the baiza (an adaptation of the Indian lower denomination paisa). These are relatively inexpensive and service all major roadways
column4: as well as a wide and loose network of smaller byways in the greater Muscat metropolitan area
column5: opportunistically dropping off and picking up passengers at any location. Less popular and slightly more expensive are large public buses
column6: coloured red and green
column7: whose service is limited to major roadways and point-to-point travel routes between Oman's major cities and towns. Taxis
column8: also colour-coded orange and white
column9: provide semi-personal transportation in the form of both individual hire and the same opportunistic roadway service as Baiza buses.

column1: Baiza buses and colour-coded orange-and-white taxis are unmetered
column2: after several government initiatives to introduce meters were rejected. The fare is set by way of negotiation
column3: although taxi drivers usually adhere to certain unwritten rules for fares within the city. In many countries
column4: one is advised to negotiate a fare with the driver before getting into a taxi. However
column5: in Oman
column6: asking for the fare beforehand often demonstrates a passenger's newness and unfamiliarity with the area. One should always find out the normally accepted fare for one's journey from one's hotel or host before looking for a taxi. Taxis will also generally take passengers to locations out of the city
column7: including Sohar
column8: Buraimi and Dubai.

column2: Oman shares many of the cultural characteristics of its Arab neighbours
column3: particularly those in the Gulf Cooperation Council. Despite these similarities
column4: important factors make Oman unique in the Middle East. These result as much from geography and history as from culture and economics. The relatively recent and artificial nature of the state of Oman makes it difficult to describe a national culture; however
column5: sufficient cultural heterogeneity exists within its national boundaries to make Oman distinct from other Arab States of the Persian Gulf. Oman's cultural diversity is greater than that of its Arab neighbours
column6: given its historical expansion to the Swahili Coast and the Indian Ocean.Oman has a long tradition of shipbuilding
column7: as maritime travel played a major role in the Omanis' ability to stay in contact with the civilisations of the ancient world. Sur was one of the most famous shipbuilding cities of the Indian Ocean. The Al Ghanja ship takes one whole year to build. Other types of Omani ship include As Sunbouq and Al Badan.In March 2016
column8: archaeologists working off Al-Hallaniyah Island identified a shipwreck believed to be that of the Esmeralda from Vasco da Gama's 1502‚Äì1503 fleet. The wreck was initially discovered in 1998. Later underwater excavations took place between 2013 and 2015 through a partnership between the Oman Ministry of Heritage and Culture and Blue Water Recoveries Ltd.
column9: a shipwreck recovery company. The vessel was identified through such artifacts as a ""Portuguese coin minted for trade with India (one of only two coins of this type known to exist) and stone cannonballs engraved with what appear to be the initials of Vincente Sodr√©
column10: da Gama's maternal uncle and the commander of the Esmeralda.""

column1: Their breeding habitat is marshy lakes and ponds. They nest in dense marsh vegetation near water. The female builds the nest out of grass

These birds dive and swim underwater. They mainly eat seeds and roots of aquatic plants
