Pacifastacus leniusculushttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal%20crayfish"The signal crayfish (Pacifastacus leniusculus) is a North American species of crayfish. It was introduced to Europe in the 1960s to supplement the North European Astacus astacus fisheries
column2: which were being damaged by crayfish plague
column3: but the imports turned out to be a carrier of that disease. The signal crayfish is now considered an invasive species across Europe
column4: Japan
column5: and California ousting native species there.

column1: Members of this species are typically 6‚Äì9 cm (2.4‚Äì3.5 in) long
column2: although sizes up to 16‚Äì20 cm (6.3‚Äì7.9 in) are possible. They are bluish-brown to reddish-brown in colour
column3: with robust
column4: large
column5: smooth claws. They have a white to pale blue-green patch near the claw hinge
column6: like the white flags that signalmen used for directing trains‚Äîhence the name.

column1: The lifecycle of the signal crayfish is typical for the family Astacidae. Around 200‚Äì400 eggs are laid after mating in the autumn
column2: and are carried under the female's tail until they are ready to hatch the following spring. The eggs hatch into juveniles
column3: which pass through three stages (two moults) before leaving their mother. Sexual maturity is reached after 2‚Äì3 years
column4: and the lifespan can be up to 20 years.The signal crayfish is an omnivore
column5: with most of its dietary intake being detritus.

column1: The signal crayfish is native to North America west of the Rocky Mountains
column2: including the Canadian province of British Columbia
column3: and the U.S. states of Washington
column4: Oregon
column5: and Idaho. It was introduced to California in 1912 into the San Lorenzo River watershed and from there rapidly spread throughout the state. The only native crayfish remaining in California is the Shasta crayfish
column6: of Shasta County
column7: California (Pacifastacus fortis)
column8: where efforts are being made to create a barrier to signal crayfish invasion. Within North America
column9: it has also been introduced to Nevada
column10: and the populations in Utah may be the result of introductions. It has also been found in Alaska
column11: specifically Kodiak Island
column12: in the Buskin River and Buskin Lake. It is listed as a species of least concern on the IUCN Red List.

column2: crayfish plague
column3: an infectious disease caused by the water mould Aphanomyces astaci
column4: damaged stocks of the native European crayfish Astacus astacus. Since the signal crayfish occupied a similar ecological niche in its native range
column5: it was imported in the 1960s to Sweden and Finland to allow recreational and commercial crayfish capture. At the time
column6: the signal crayfish was not recognized as a carrier of the crayfish plague. All American species carry the infection
column7: but it is only lethal to individuals that are already stressed; to European species
column8: the infection is rapidly fatal.

column1: The signal crayfish is now the most widespread alien crayfish in Europe
column2: occurring in 25 countries
column3: from Finland to Great Britain and from Spain to Greece. It was first introduced to Great Britain in 1976 and is now widespread across the British mainland as far north as the Moray Firth. It has also been observed on the Isle of Man
column4: but not in Ireland. Ireland is  the last European country having no alien crayfish.

column1: In both Sweden and Finland (where crayfish are eaten)
column2: the catch of signal crayfish exceeds that of A. astacus (European/noble crayfish). The former is sold at roughly half the price compared to the latter.In Europe
column3: the signal crayfish is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column4: bred
column5: transported
column6: commercialized
column7: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

Parthenium hysterophorushttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthenium%20hysterophorus"Parthenium hysterophorus is a species of flowering plant in the aster family
column2: Asteraceae. It is native to the American tropics. Common names include Santa-Maria
column3: Santa Maria feverfew
column4: whitetop weed
column5: and famine weed. In India
column6: it is locally known as carrot grass
column7: congress grass or Gajar Ghas. It is a common invasive species in India
column8: Australia
column9: and parts of Africa.

column2: including roadsides. It infests pastures and farmland
column3: causing often disastrous loss of yield
column4: as reflected in common names such as famine weed.  In some areas
column5: heavy outbreaks have been ubiquitous
column6: affecting livestock and crop production
column7: and human health.  As an invader it first appeared as a contaminant in imported wheat.The plant produces allelopathic chemicals that suppress crop and pasture plants
column8: and allergens that affect humans and livestock. It also frequently causes pollen allergies. A study published in 2021 further showed that the plant could promote malaria by supplying much appreciated food and shelter to mosquitoes in Eastern Africa.It is being investigated as a means of removing heavy metals and dyes from the environment
column9: control of aquatic weeds
column10: commercial enzyme production
column11: an additive in manure for biogas production
column12: as a biopesticide
column13: and as green manure and compost.The species has been listed as an invasive alien species of Union Concern. This means it is illegal to import or sell this species in the whole of the European Union.

column1: Contact with the plant causes dermatitis and respiratory malfunction in humans
column2: and dermatitis in cattle and domestic animals. The main substance responsible is parthenin
column3: which is dangerously toxic.  It also is responsible for bitter milk disease in livestock when their fodder is polluted with Parthenium leaves.Among other allelopathic effects of the species
column4: the presence of Parthenium pollen grains inhibits fruit set in tomato
column5: brinjal
column6: beans
column7: and a number of other crop plants.

column1: Light infestations of Parthenium hysterophorus in cultivated fields may be hoed or weeded by hand if labour is available at acceptable cost.
Generally the application of herbicides is expensive and often harmful; Paraquat sprays may be applied while the weeds are young. Glyphosate is not effective against this species.

The most satisfactory and promising means of practical long-term control are biological. Several species that feed on the weed are variously in use or on trial in various countries. The best-established control organism so far is a beetle native to Mexico
column2: Zygogramma bicolorata
column3: which was first introduced to India in 1984. It since has become widespread and well-established on the subcontinent. It defoliates and often kills the weed
column4: and its damage to the young flowering tops reduces seed production.

column2: such as Australia and South Africa
column3: several other biocontrol agents have been released or are under evaluation. These include at least two more species of beetles that have been released in South Africa
column4: a stem boring weevil Listronotus setosipennis
column5: and a seed weevil Smicronyx lutulentus.Also in South Africa
column6: rust fungi have been of some use: the winter rust Puccinia abrupta var. partheniicola plus the summer rust Puccinia xanthiiIn Australia
column7: apart from the foregoing
column8: yet other biocontrol agents have been employed or evaluated on Parthenium hysterophorus
column9: to a total of 11 species since 1980. Of those eleven
column10: nine appear to have established in various regions. The two with the greatest effect seem to be the beetle Zygogramma bicolorata and a stem-galling moth Epiblema strenuana. However
column11: other species that appear to have established usefully include a leaf-mining moth
column12: Bucculatrix parthenica; a stem-galling weevil
column13: Conotrachelus albocinereus; and a root-boring moth Carmenta ithacae.

column2: known as rotan in Russia
column3: resembles a perch
column4: ruffe or sculpin. The eyes are placed high on the head which has a rounded snout and projecting lower jaw. There is little or no gap between the two dorsal fins
column5: the front one of which has six to eight spines and the back one nine to eleven soft rays. The anal fin has one to three spines and seven to ten soft rays. The pelvic fins are not fused together which helps to distinguish this fish from the gobies. The second dorsal and the anal fins are both more rounded and shorter than the gobies and the caudal fin is also more rounded. The general colour is brownish with a checker-board pattern of darker marks or dark barring. There are dark lines on the head radiating from the eye.  This species can reach a length of 25 centimetres (9.8 in) TL and the greatest recorded weight for a specimen is 250 grams (8.8 oz).

column1: The Chinese sleeper is native to the Far East but appeared in ponds in Eastern Europe in the early twentieth century and has since spread to large parts of the Danube
column2: the Vistula and other river basins where it is considered an invasive species. Its typical habitat is ponds
column3: closed water-bodies and slow-moving streams. The westernmost locality of the Chinese sleeper range is the ponds in the Bavarian Danube basin in Germany.

column2: the Chinese sleeper is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: The Chinese sleeper is an adaptable species and tolerant of widely different conditions. It feeds on insects and their larvae
column2: small crustaceans and fish fry. It spawns in warm shallows among vegetation and the male guards the eggs.

column1: This species is of minor importance to local commercial fisheries and has potential as an aquarium fish.  However
column2: introduced populations are of concern as they could become detrimental to the local fauna due to its predatory nature and voracious appetite.
known variously as the red swamp crayfish
column3: Louisiana crawfish or mudbug
column4: is a species of cambarid crayfish native to freshwater bodies of northern Mexico
column5: and southern and southeastern United States
column6: but also introduced elsewhere (both in North America and other continents)
column7: where it is often an invasive pest.

column1: P. clarkii is typically dark red
column2: with long claws and head
column3: small or no spines on the sides of its carapace just below the head
column4: and rows of bright red bumps on the front and side of the first leg.

column1: The native range of P. clarkii is from northern Mexico and far southeastern New Mexico
column2: through the Gulf States to the Florida Panhandle
column3: as well as inland north through the Mississippi Basin to southern Illinois and Ohio. It has also been introduced
column4: sometimes deliberately
column5: outside its natural range to countries in Asia
column6: Africa
column7: Europe and elsewhere in the Americas. In northern Europe
column8: the populations are self-maintaining but not expanding
column9: while in southern Europe
column10: P. clarkii is multiplying and actively colonizing new territories at the expense of the native crayfish
column11: Astacus astacus and Austropotamobius spp.  Individuals are reported to be able to cross many miles of relatively dry ground
column12: especially in wet seasons
column13: although the aquarium trade and anglers may have hastened the spread in some areas (anglers using P. clarkii as fishing bait are thought to have introduced it to the state of Washington). Attempts have also been made to use P. clarkii as a biological control organism
column14: to reduce levels of the snails involved in the lifecycle of schistosomiasis
column15: leading to the dispersal of P. clarkii in
column16: for instance
column17: Kenya.

column2: P. clarkii is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: P. clarkii is most commonly found in warm freshwater bodies such as slow-flowing rivers
column2: marshes
column3: reservoirs
column4: irrigation systems and rice paddies. It is considered to be the most ecologically plastic species in the order Decapoda
column5: and is able to grow quickly even in only seasonally present water
column6: being able to tolerate dry spells of up to four months. P. clarkii grows quickly
column7: and is capable of reaching weights in excess of 50 g (1.8 oz) and sizes of 5.5‚Äì12 cm (2.2‚Äì4.7 in) long. It is also able to tolerate slightly saline water
column8: which is unusual for a crayfish.  Additionally
column9: P. clarkii are physiologically capable of tolerating relatively low dissolved oxygen concentrations.  The average lifetime of Procambarus clarkii is five years
column10: although some individuals are known to have reached ages (in nature) of over six years.

column1: The burrowing activities of P. clarkii can lead to damage to existing water courses and to crops
column2: particularly rice
column3: and its feeding can disrupt native ecosystems. It may outcompete the native crayfish species
column4: and is a vector for the crayfish plague fungus Aphanomyces astaci
column5: for crayfish virus vibriosis and for a number of worms parasitic on vertebrates.  Their burrowing activities may also be a threat to civil infrastructure such as storm ponds and levees.

column1: Harvests of P. clarkii for food account for a large majority of the crayfish produced in the United States and elsewhere. Crayfish farming began in Louisiana in the 18th century
column2: taking place in rice fields in a concurrent or alternate culture system. The concurrent polyculture of rice and crayfish combination makes good use of land
column3: resources
column4: equipment and infrastructure already being used for rice production.

column2: crawfish production has decreased in recent years due to an increase of imports from China
column3: which is now the world's leading producer of farmed crawfish using a rice-based system. A number of species of crustaceans were introduced to China to create markets for aquaculture and because they are better adapted to growing in a rice field than native fish species. Rice-fish farming originated in China and is once again growing as the yields from Green Revolution practices used to grow rice are no longer increasing
column4: and resources such as land and water are becoming more limited.  Crayfish are also cultivated as animal feed for poultry farms
column5: fish farms and bullfrog farms
column6: or used to add into organic fertilizers.

column1: P. clarkii has also been introduced elsewhere for cultivation
column2: such as Spain
column3: where its success is attributable to its ability to colonize disturbed habitats that would be unsuitable for the native crayfish (Astacus astacus). P. clarkii is also marketed by biological supply companies for teaching and research. P. clarkii also exhibits different color morphs
column4: including white
column5: blue and orange
column6: which are commonly sold in pet stores.

column1: The introduction of P. clarkii has also resulted in economic losses in some regions. In the Baixo Mondego region of Portugal
column2: it caused a decrease in 6.3% of profits in rice fields. However
column3: this was on a wet-seeded field. All negative effects of crawfish can be avoided if adult crawfish are separated from the seed and seedlings.

column1: P. clarkii is eaten in China
column2: Cambodia
column3: Thailand
column4: Europe
column5: Africa
column6: the United States
column7: Canada
column8: Australia
column9: New Zealand and the Caribbean.  In the United States
column10: crayfish are particularly popular in Louisiana
column11: where the standard culinary terms vary between ""crawfish""
column12: ""crayfish""
column13: ""crawdaddy"" or ""mudbug""
column14: and crawfish boils are popular social gatherings centered around eating the crustaceans. Louisiana crawfish are usually boiled in a large pot with heavy seasoning (salt
column15: cayenne pepper
column16: lemon
column17: garlic
column18: bay leaf
column19: etc.) and other items such as potatoes and corn on the cob. Many differing methods are used to season the dish
column20: and there are an equal number of opinions on which one is correct.In 1990
column21: Louisiana produced 90% of the crawfish in the world
column22: and consumed 70% locally. However
column23: as early as 2003
column24: Asian fish farms and fisheries produced more and continued to outpace production in any other part of the world.  By 2018
column25: P. clarkii crawfish production in the Americas represented just 4% of total global P. clarkii supply. Louisiana crawfish remain in demand for local production and consumption. In 2018
column26: 93% of crawfish farms in the US were located in Louisiana.

column2: Procyon lotor)
column3: sometimes called the common raccoon to distinguish it from other species
column4: is a medium-sized mammal native to North America. It is the largest of the procyonid family
column5: having a body length of 40 to 70 cm (16 to 28 in)
column6: and a body weight of 5 to 26 kg (11 to 57 lb). Its grayish coat mostly consists of dense underfur
column7: which insulates it against cold weather. Three of the raccoon's most distinctive features are its extremely dexterous front paws
column8: its facial mask
column9: and its ringed tail
column10: which are themes in  the mythologies of the indigenous peoples of the Americas relating to the animal. The raccoon is noted for its intelligence
column11: as studies show that it is able to remember the solution to tasks for at least three years. It is usually nocturnal and omnivorous
column12: eating about 40% invertebrates
column13: 33% plants
column14: and 27% vertebrates.

column1: The original habitats of the raccoon are deciduous and mixed forests
column2: but due to their adaptability
column3: they have extended their range to mountainous areas
column4: coastal marshes
column5: and urban areas
column6: where some homeowners consider them to be pests. As a result of escapes and deliberate introductions in the mid-20th century
column7: raccoons are now also distributed across much of mainland Europe
column8: the Caucasus
column9: and Japan.

column2: the raccoon is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.Though previously thought to be generally solitary
column7: there is now evidence that raccoons engage in sex-specific social behavior. Related females often share a common area
column8: while unrelated males live together in groups of up to four raccoons
column9: in order to maintain their positions against foreign males during the mating season
column10: and other potential invaders. Home range sizes vary anywhere from 3 hectares (7.4 acres) for females in cities
column11: to 5
column12: 000 hectares (12
column13: 000 acres) for males in prairies. After a gestation period of about 65 days
column14: two to five young
column15: known as ""kits""
column16: are born in spring. The kits are subsequently raised by their mother until dispersal in late fall. Although captive raccoons have been known to live over 20 years
column17: their life expectancy in the wild is only 1.8 to 3.1 years. In many areas
column18: hunting and vehicular injury are the two most common causes of death.

column1: Names for the species include the common raccoon
column2: North American raccoon
column3: and northern raccoon
column4: The word ""raccoon"" was adopted into English from the native Powhatan term meaning ‚Äúanimal that scratches with its hands‚Äù
column5: as used in the Colony of Virginia. Its Latin name means  ‚Äúbefore-dog washer"". It was recorded on John Smith's list of Powhatan words as aroughcun
column6: and on that of William Strachey as arathkone. It has also been identified as a reflex of a Proto-Algonquian root ahrah-koon-em
column7: meaning ""[the] one who rubs
column8: scrubs and scratches with its hands"". The word is sometimes spelled as racoon.Spanish colonists adopted the Spanish word mapache from the Nahuatl mapachtli of the Aztecs
column9: meaning ""[the] one who takes everything in its hands"". In many languages
column10: the raccoon is named for its characteristic dousing behavior in conjunction with that language's term for bear
column11: for example Waschb√§r ('wash-bear') in German
column12: Vaskebj√∏rn ('wash-bear') in Norwegian
column13: Huan Xiong (Êµ£ÁÜä 'wash-bear') in Chinese
column14: dviv√≥n r√≥chetz (◊ì◊ë◊ô◊ë◊ï◊ü ◊®◊ï◊ó◊• 'washing-bear[DIM]') in Hebrew
column15: orsetto lavatore ('little washer bear') in Italian
column16: and araiguma (Ê¥óÁÜä („ÅÇ„Çâ„ÅÑ„Åê„Åæ) 'washing-bear') in Japanese. Alternatively
column17: only the washing behavior might be referred to
column18: as in Russian poloskun (–ø–æ–ª–æ—Å–∫—É–Ω
column19: 'rinser').  In French they are raton laveur ('little wash-rat')

column1: The colloquial abbreviation coon is used in words like coonskin for fur clothing and in phrases like old coon as a self-designation of trappers. In the 1830s
column2: the United States Whig Party used the raccoon as an emblem
column3: causing them to be pejoratively known as ""coons"" by their political opponents
column4: who saw them as too sympathetic to African-Americans. Soon after that the term became an ethnic slur
column5: especially in use between 1880 and 1920 (see coon song)
column6: and the term is still considered offensive. Dogs bred to hunt raccoons are called ""coonhound"" and ""coon dog"".

column1: In the first decades after its discovery by the members of the expedition of Christopher Columbus
column2: who were the first Europeans to leave a written record about the species
column3: taxonomists thought the raccoon was related to many different species
column4: including dogs
column5: cats
column6: badgers and particularly bears. Carl Linnaeus
column7: the father of modern taxonomy
column8: placed the raccoon in the genus Ursus
column9: first as Ursus cauda elongata (""long-tailed bear"") in the second edition of his Systema Naturae (1740)
column10: then as Ursus Lotor (""washer bear"") in the tenth edition (1758‚Äì59). In 1780
column11: Gottlieb Conrad Christian Storr placed the raccoon in its own genus Procyon
column12: which can be translated as either ""before the dog"" or ""doglike"". It is also possible that Storr had its nocturnal lifestyle in mind and chose the star Procyon as eponym for the species.

column1: Based on fossil evidence from Russia and Bulgaria
column2: the first known members of the family Procyonidae lived in Europe in the late Oligocene about 25 million years ago. Similar tooth and skull structures suggest procyonids and weasels share a common ancestor
column3: but molecular analysis indicates a closer relationship between raccoons and bears. After the then-existing species crossed the Bering Strait at least six million years later in the early Miocene
column4: the center of its distribution was probably in Central America. Coatis (Nasua and Nasuella) and raccoons (Procyon) have been considered to share common descent from a species in the genus Paranasua present between 5.2 and 6.0 million years ago. This assumption
column5: based on morphological comparisons of fossils
column6: conflicts with a 2006 genetic analysis which indicates raccoons are more closely related to ringtails. Unlike other procyonids
column7: such as the crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus)
column8: the ancestors of the common raccoon left tropical and subtropical areas and migrated farther north about 2.5 million years ago
column9: in a migration that has been confirmed by the discovery of fossils in the Great Plains dating back to the middle of the Pliocene. Its most recent ancestor was likely Procyon rexroadensis
column10: a large Blancan raccoon from the Rexroad Formation characterized by its narrow back teeth and large lower jaw.

column2: Mammal Species of the World recognizes 22 subspecies of raccoons. Four of these subspecies living only on small Central American and Caribbean islands were often regarded as distinct species after their discovery. These are the Bahamian raccoon and Guadeloupe raccoon
column3: which are very similar to each other; the Tres Marias raccoon
column4: which is larger than average and has an angular skull; and the extinct Barbados raccoon. Studies of their morphological and genetic traits in 1999
column5: 2003 and 2005 led all these island raccoons to be listed as subspecies of the common raccoon in Mammal Species of the World's third edition. A fifth island raccoon population
column6: the Cozumel raccoon
column7: which weighs only 3 to 4 kg (6.6 to 8.8 lb) and has notably small teeth
column8: is still regarded as a separate species.The four smallest raccoon subspecies
column9: with a typical weight of 1.8 to 2.7 kg (4.0 to 6.0 lb)
column10: live along the southern coast of Florida and on the adjacent islands; an example is the Ten Thousand Islands raccoon (Procyon lotor marinus). Most of the other 15 subspecies differ only slightly from each other in coat color
column11: size and other physical characteristics. The two most widespread subspecies are the eastern raccoon (Procyon lotor lotor) and the Upper Mississippi Valley raccoon (Procyon lotor hirtus). Both share a comparatively dark coat with long hairs
column12: but the Upper Mississippi Valley raccoon is larger than the eastern raccoon. The eastern raccoon occurs in all U.S. states and Canadian provinces to the north of South Carolina and Tennessee. The adjacent range of the Upper Mississippi Valley raccoon covers all U.S. states and Canadian provinces to the north of Louisiana
column13: Texas and New Mexico.The taxonomic identity of feral raccoons inhabiting Central Europe
column14: Causasia and Japan is unknown
column15: as the founding populations consisted of uncategorized specimens from zoos and fur farms.

column2: raccoons measure between 40 and 70 cm (16 and 28 in)
column3: not including the bushy tail which can

column1: measure between 20 and 40 cm (8 and 16 in)
column2: but is usually not much longer than 25 cm (10 in). The shoulder height is between 23 and 30 cm (9 and 12 in). The body weight of an adult raccoon varies considerably with habitat
column3: making the raccoon one of the most variably sized mammals. It can range from 5 to 26 kilograms (10 to 60 lb)
column4: but is usually between 5 and 12 kilograms (10 and 30 lb). The smallest specimens live in southern Florida
column5: while those near the northern limits of the raccoon's range tend to be the largest (see Bergmann's rule). Males are usually 15 to 20% heavier than females. At the beginning of winter
column6: a raccoon can weigh twice as much as in spring because of fat storage. The largest recorded wild raccoon weighed 28.4 kg (62.6 lb) and measured 140 cm (55 in) in total length
column7: by far the largest size recorded for a procyonid.The most characteristic physical feature of the raccoon is the area of black fur around the eyes
column8: which contrasts sharply with the surrounding white face coloring. This is reminiscent of a ""bandit's mask"" and has thus enhanced the animal's reputation for mischief. The slightly rounded ears are also bordered by white fur. Raccoons are assumed to recognize the facial expression and posture of other members of their species more quickly because of the conspicuous facial coloration and the alternating light and dark rings on the tail. The dark mask may also reduce glare and thus enhance night vision. On other parts of the body
column9: the long and stiff guard hairs
column10: which shed moisture
column11: are usually colored in shades of gray and
column12: to a lesser extent
column13: brown. Raccoons with a very dark coat are more common in the German population because individuals with such coloring were among those initially released to the wild. The dense underfur
column14: which accounts for almost 90% of the coat
column15: insulates against cold weather and is composed of 2 to 3 cm (0.8 to 1.2 in) long hairs.The raccoon
column16: whose method of locomotion is usually considered to be plantigrade
column17: can stand on its hind legs to examine objects with its front paws. As raccoons have short legs compared to their compact torso
column18: they are usually not able either to run quickly or jump great distances. Their top speed over short distances is 16 to 24 km/h (10 to 15 mph). Raccoons can swim with an average speed of about 5 km/h (3 mph) and can stay in the water for several hours. For climbing down a tree headfirst‚Äîan unusual ability for a mammal of its size‚Äîa raccoon rotates its hind feet so they are pointing backwards. Raccoons have a dual cooling system to regulate their temperature; that is
column19: they are able to both sweat and pant for heat dissipation.Raccoon skulls have a short and wide facial region and a voluminous braincase. The facial length of the skull is less than the cranial
column20: and their nasal bones are short and quite broad. The auditory bullae are inflated in form
column21: and the sagittal crest is weakly developed. The dentition‚Äî40 teeth with the dental formula:3.1.4.23.1.4.2‚Äîis adapted to their omnivorous diet: the carnassials are not as sharp and pointed as those of a full-time carnivore
column22: but the molars are not as wide as those of a herbivore. The penis bone of males is about 10 cm (4 in) long and strongly bent at the front end
column23: and its shape can be used to distinguish juvenile males from mature males. Seven of the thirteen identified vocal calls are used in communication between the mother and her kits
column24: one of these being the birdlike twittering of newborns.

column1: The most important sense for the raccoon is its sense of touch. The ""hyper sensitive"" front paws are protected by a thin horny layer that becomes pliable when wet. The five digits of the paws have no webbing between them
column2: which is unusual for a carnivoran. Almost two-thirds of the area responsible for sensory perception in the raccoon's cerebral cortex is specialized for the interpretation of tactile impulses
column3: more than in any other studied animal. They are able to identify objects before touching them with vibrissae located above their sharp
column4: nonretractable claws. The raccoon's paws lack an opposable thumb; thus
column5: it does not have the agility of the hands of primates. There is no observed negative effect on tactile perception when a raccoon stands in water below 10 ¬∞C (50 ¬∞F) for hours.Raccoons are thought to be color blind or at least poorly able to distinguish color
column6: though their eyes are well-adapted for sensing green light. Although their accommodation of 11 dioptre is comparable to that of humans and they see well in twilight because of the tapetum lucidum behind the retina
column7: visual perception is of subordinate importance to raccoons because of their poor long-distance vision. In addition to being useful for orientation in the dark
column8: their sense of smell is important for intraspecific communication. Glandular secretions (usually from their anal glands)
column9: urine and feces are used for marking. With their broad auditory range
column10: they can perceive tones up to 50‚Äì85 kHz as well as quiet noises
column11: like those produced by earthworms underground.

column1: Zoologist Clinton Hart Merriam described raccoons as ""clever beasts""
column2: and that ""in certain directions their cunning surpasses that of the fox"". The animal's intelligence gave rise to the epithet ""sly coon"". Only a few studies have been undertaken to determine the mental abilities of raccoons
column3: most of them based on the animal's sense of touch. In a study by the ethologist H. B. Davis in 1908
column4: raccoons were able to open 11 of 13 complex locks in fewer than 10 tries and had no problems repeating the action when the locks were rearranged or turned upside down. Davis concluded that they understood the abstract principles of the locking mechanisms and their learning speed was equivalent to that of rhesus macaques.Studies in 1963
column6: 1975 and 1992 concentrated on raccoon memory showed that they can remember the solutions to tasks for at least three years. In a study by B. Pohl in 1992
column7: raccoons were able to instantly differentiate between identical and different symbols three years after the short initial learning phase. Stanislas Dehaene reports in his book The Number Sense that raccoons can distinguish boxes containing two or four grapes from those containing three. In research by Suzana Herculano-Houzel and other neuroscientists
column8: raccoons have been found to be comparable to primates in density of neurons in the cerebral cortex
column9: which they have proposed to be a neuroanatomical indicator of intelligence.

column1: Studies in the 1990s by the ethologists Stanley D. Gehrt and Ulf Hohmann suggest that raccoons engage in sex-specific social behaviors and are not typically solitary
column2: as was previously thought. Related females often live in a so-called ""fission-fusion society""; that is
column3: they share a common area and occasionally meet at feeding or resting grounds. Unrelated males often form loose male social groups to maintain their position against foreign males during the mating season‚Äîor against other potential invaders. Such a group does not usually consist of more than four individuals. Since some males show aggressive behavior towards unrelated kits
column4: mothers will isolate themselves from other raccoons until their kits are big enough to defend themselves.With respect to these three different modes of life prevalent among raccoons
column5: Hohmann called their social structure a ""three-class society"". Samuel I. Zeveloff
column6: professor of zoology at Weber State University and author of the book Raccoons: A Natural History
column7: is more cautious in his interpretation and concludes at least the females are solitary most of the time and
column8: according to Erik K. Fritzell's study in North Dakota in 1978
column9: males in areas with low population densities are solitary as well.The shape and size of a raccoon's home range varies depending on age
column10: sex
column11: and habitat
column12: with adults claiming areas more than twice as large as juveniles. While the size of home ranges in the habitat of North Dakota's prairies lie between 7 and 50 km2 (3 and 20 sq mi) for males and between 2 and 16 km2 (1 and 6 sq mi) for females
column13: the average size in a marsh at Lake Erie was 0.5 km2 (0.19 sq mi). Irrespective of whether the home ranges of adjacent groups overlap
column14: they are most likely not actively defended outside the mating season if food supplies are sufficient. Odor marks on prominent spots are assumed to establish home ranges and identify individuals. Urine and feces left at shared raccoon latrines may provide additional information about feeding grounds
column15: since raccoons were observed to meet there later for collective eating
column16: sleeping and playing.Concerning the general behavior patterns of raccoons
column17: Gehrt points out that ""typically you'll find 10 to 15 percent that will do the opposite"" of what is expected.

column2: the raccoon is sometimes active in daylight to take advantage of available food sources. Its diet consists of about 40% invertebrates
column3: 33% plant material and 27% vertebrates. Since its diet consists of such a variety of different foods
column4: Zeveloff argues the raccoon ""may well be one of the world's most omnivorous animals"". While its diet in spring and early summer consists mostly of insects
column5: worms
column6: and other animals already available early in the year
column7: it prefers fruits and nuts
column8: such as acorns and walnuts
column9: which emerge in late summer and autumn
column10: and represent a rich calorie source for building up fat needed for winter.Contrary to popular belief
column11: raccoons only occasionally eat active or large prey
column12: such as birds and mammals. They prefer prey that is easier to catch
column13: specifically crayfish
column14: fish
column15: amphibians and bird eggs. Raccoons are virulent predators of eggs and hatchlings in both birds and reptile nests
column16: to such a degree that
column17: for threatened prey species
column18: raccoons may need to be removed from the area or nests may need to be relocated to mitigate the effect of their predations (i.e. in the case of some globally threatened turtles). When food is plentiful
column19: raccoons can develop strong individual preferences for specific foods. In the northern parts of their range
column20: raccoons go into a winter rest
column21: reducing their activity drastically as long as a permanent snow cover makes searching for food difficult.

column1: One aspect of raccoon behavior is so well known that it gives the animal part of its scientific name
column2: Procyon lotor; ""lotor"" is Latin for ""washer"". In the wild
column3: raccoons often dabble for underwater food near the shore-line. They then often pick up the food item with their front paws to examine it and rub the item
column4: sometimes to remove unwanted parts. This gives the appearance of the raccoon ""washing"" the food. The tactile sensitivity of raccoons' paws is increased if this rubbing action is performed underwater
column5: since the water softens the hard layer covering the paws. However
column6: the behavior observed in captive raccoons in which they carry their food to water to ""wash"" or douse it before eating has not been observed in the wild. Naturalist Georges-Louis Leclerc
column7: Comte de Buffon
column8: believed that raccoons do not have adequate saliva production to moisten food thereby necessitating dousing
column9: but this hypothesis is now considered to be incorrect. Captive raccoons douse their food more frequently when a watering hole with a layout similar to a stream is not farther away than 3 m (10 ft). The widely accepted theory is that dousing in captive raccoons is a fixed action pattern from the dabbling behavior performed when foraging at shores for aquatic foods. This is supported by the observation that aquatic foods are doused more frequently. Cleaning dirty food does not seem to be a reason for ""washing"". Experts have cast doubt on the veracity of observations of wild raccoons dousing food.

column1: Raccoons usually mate in a period triggered by increasing daylight between late January and mid-March. However
column2: there are large regional differences which are not completely explicable by solar conditions. For example
column3: while raccoons in southern states typically mate later than average
column4: the mating season in Manitoba also peaks later than usual in March and extends until June. During the mating season
column5: males restlessly roam their home ranges in search of females in an attempt to court them during the three- to four-day period when conception is possible. These encounters will often occur at central meeting places. Copulation
column6: including foreplay
column7: can last over an hour and is repeated over several nights. The weaker members of a male social group also are assumed to get the opportunity to mate
column8: since the stronger ones cannot mate with all available females. In a study in southern Texas during the mating seasons from 1990 to 1992
column9: about one third of all females mated with more than one male. If a female does not become pregnant or if she loses her kits early
column10: she will sometimes become fertile again 80 to 140 days later.

column1: After usually 63 to 65 days of gestation (although anywhere from 54 to 70 days is possible)
column2: a litter of typically two to five young is born. The average litter size varies widely with habitat
column3: ranging from 2.5 in Alabama to 4.8 in North Dakota. Larger litters are more common in areas with a high mortality rate
column4: due
column5: for example
column6: to hunting or severe winters. While male yearlings usually reach their sexual maturity only after the main mating season
column7: female yearlings can compensate for high mortality rates and may be responsible for about 50% of all young born in a year. Males have no part in raising young. The kits (also called ""cubs"") are blind and deaf at birth
column8: but their mask is already visible against their light fur. The birth weight of the about 10 cm (4 in)-long kits is between 60 and 75 g (2.1 and 2.6 oz). Their ear canals open after around 18 to 23 days
column9: a few days before their eyes open for the first time. Once the kits weigh about 1 kg (2 lb)
column10: they begin to explore outside the den
column11: consuming solid food for the first time after six to nine weeks. After this point
column12: their mother suckles them with decreasing frequency; they are usually weaned by 16 weeks. In the fall
column13: after their mother has shown them dens and feeding grounds
column14: the juvenile group splits up.  While many females will stay close to the home range of their mother
column15: males can sometimes move more than 20 km (12 mi) away. This is considered an instinctive behavior
column16: preventing inbreeding. However
column17: mother and offspring may share a den during the first winter in cold areas.

column1: Captive raccoons have been known to live for more than 20 years. However
column2: the species' life expectancy in the wild is only 1.8 to 3.1 years
column3: depending on the local conditions such as traffic volume
column4: hunting
column5: and weather severity. It is not unusual for only half of the young born in one year to survive a full year. After this point
column6: the annual mortality rate drops to between 10% and 30%. Young raccoons are vulnerable to losing their mother and to starvation
column7: particularly in long and cold winters. The most frequent natural cause of death in the North American raccoon population is distemper
column8: which can reach epidemic proportions and kill most of a local raccoon population. In areas with heavy vehicular traffic and extensive hunting
column9: these factors can account for up to 90% of all deaths of adult raccoons. The most important natural predators of the raccoon are bobcats
column10: coyotes
column11: and great horned owls
column12: the latter mainly preying on young raccoons but capable of killing adults in some cases. In Florida
column13: they have been reported to fall victim to larger carnivores like American black bear and cougars and these species may also be a threat on occasion in other areas. Where still present
column14: gray wolves may still occasionally take raccoons as a supplemental prey item. Also in the southeast
column15: they are among the favored prey for adult American alligators. On occasion
column16: both bald and golden eagles will prey on raccoons. In the tropics
column17: raccoons are known to fall prey to smaller eagles such as ornate hawk-eagles and black hawk-eagles
column18: although it is not clear whether adults or merely juvenile raccoons are taken by these. In rare cases of overlap
column19: they may fall victim from carnivores ranging from species averaging smaller than themselves such as fishers to those as large and formidable as jaguars in Mexico. In their introduced range in the former Soviet Union
column20: their main predators are wolves
column21: lynxes and Eurasian eagle-owls. However
column22: predation is not a significant cause of death
column23: especially because larger predators have been exterminated in many areas inhabited by raccoons.

column1: Although they have thrived in sparsely wooded areas in the last decades
column2: raccoons depend on vertical structures to climb when they feel threatened. Therefore
column3: they avoid open terrain and areas with high concentrations of beech trees
column4: as beech bark is too smooth to climb. Tree hollows in old oaks or other trees and rock crevices are preferred by raccoons as sleeping
column5: winter and litter dens. If such dens are unavailable or accessing them is inconvenient
column6: raccoons use burrows dug by other mammals
column7: dense undergrowth or tree crotches. In a study in the Solling range of hills in Germany
column8: more than 60% of all sleeping places were used only once
column9: but those used at least ten times accounted for about 70% of all uses. Since amphibians
column10: crustaceans
column11: and other animals around the shore of lakes and rivers are an important part of the raccoon's diet
column12: lowland deciduous or mixed forests abundant with water and marshes sustain the highest population densities. While population densities range from 0.5 to 3.2 animals per square kilometer (1.3 to 8.3 animals per square mile) in prairies and do not usually exceed 6 animals per square kilometer (15.5 animals per square mile) in upland hardwood forests
column13: more than 20 raccoons per square kilometer (51.8 animals per square mile) can live in lowland forests and marshes.

column1: Raccoons are common throughout North America from Canada to Panama
column2: where the subspecies Procyon lotor pumilus coexists with the crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus). The population on Hispaniola was exterminated as early as 1513 by Spanish colonists who hunted them for their meat. Raccoons were also exterminated in Cuba and Jamaica
column3: where the last sightings were reported in 1687. The Barbados raccoon became extinct relatively recently
column4: in 1964. When they were still considered separate species
column5: the Bahamas raccoon
column6: Guadeloupe raccoon and Tres Marias raccoon were classified as endangered by the IUCN in 1996.There is archeological evidence that in pre-Columbian times raccoons were numerous only along rivers and in the woodlands of the Southeastern United States. As raccoons were not mentioned in earlier reports of pioneers exploring the central and north-central parts of the United States
column7: their initial spread may have begun a few decades before the 20th century. Since the 1950s
column8: raccoons have expanded their range from Vancouver Island‚Äîformerly the northernmost limit of their range‚Äîfar into the northern portions of the four south-central Canadian provinces. New habitats which have recently been occupied by raccoons (aside from urban areas) include mountain ranges
column9: such as the Western Rocky Mountains
column10: prairies and coastal marshes. After a population explosion starting in the 1940s
column11: the estimated number of raccoons in North America in the late 1980s was 15 to 20 times higher than in the 1930s
column12: when raccoons were comparatively rare. Urbanization
column13: the expansion of agriculture
column14: deliberate introductions
column15: and the extermination of natural predators of the raccoon have probably caused this increase in abundance and distribution.

column1: As a result of escapes and deliberate introductions in the mid-20th century
column2: the raccoon is now distributed in several European and Asian countries. Sightings have occurred in all the countries bordering Germany
column3: which hosts the largest population outside of North America. Another stable population exists in northern France
column4: where several pet raccoons were released by members of the U.S. Air Force near the Laon-Couvron Air Base in 1966. Furthermore
column5: raccoons have been known to be in the area around Madrid since the early 1970s. In 2013
column6: the city authorized ""the capture and death of any specimen"". It is also present in Italy
column7: with one reproductive population in Lombardy.About 1
column8: 240 animals were released in nine regions of the former Soviet Union between 1936 and 1958 for the purpose of establishing a population to be hunted for their fur. Two of these introductions were successful‚Äîone in the south of Belarus between 1954 and 1958
column9: and another in Azerbaijan between 1941 and 1957. With a seasonal harvest of between 1
column10: 000 and 1
column11: 500 animals
column12: in 1974 the estimated size of the population distributed in the Caucasus region was around 20
column13: 000 animals and the density was four animals per square kilometer (10 animals per square mile).

column2: up to 1
column3: 500 raccoons were imported as pets each year after the success of the anime series Rascal the Raccoon (1977). In 2004
column4: the descendants of discarded or escaped animals lived in 42 of 47 prefectures. The range of raccoons in the wild in Japan grew from 17 prefectures in 2000 to all 47 prefectures in 2008. It is estimated that raccoons cause thirty million yen (~$275
column5: 000) of agricultural damage on Hokkaido alone.

column1: In Germany‚Äîwhere the raccoon is called the Waschb√§r (literally
column2: ""wash-bear"" or ""washing bear"") due to its habit of ""dousing"" food in water‚Äîtwo pairs of pet raccoons were released into the German countryside at the Edersee reservoir in the north of Hesse in April 1934 by a forester upon request of their owner
column3: a poultry farmer. He released them two weeks before receiving permission from the Prussian hunting office to ""enrich the fauna."" Several prior attempts to introduce raccoons in Germany were not successful. A second population was established in eastern Germany in 1945 when 25 raccoons escaped from a fur farm at Wolfshagen (today district of Altlandsberg)
column4: east of Berlin
column5: after an air strike. The two populations are parasitologically distinguishable: 70% of the raccoons of the Hessian population are infected with the roundworm Baylisascaris procyonis
column6: but none of the Brandenburgian population has the parasite. The estimated number of raccoons was 285 animals in the Hessian region in 1956
column7: over 20
column8: 000 animals in the Hessian region in 1970 and between 200
column10: 000 animals in the whole of Germany in 2008. By 2012 it was estimated that Germany now had more than a million raccoons.The raccoon was a protected species in Germany
column11: but has been declared a game animal in 14 of the 16 states since 1954. Hunters and environmentalists argue the raccoon spreads uncontrollably
column12: threatens protected bird species and supersedes domestic carnivorans. This view is opposed by the zoologist Frank-Uwe Michler
column13: who finds no evidence a high population density of raccoons has negative effects on the biodiversity of an area. Hohmann holds that extensive hunting cannot be justified by the absence of natural predators
column14: because predation is not a significant cause of death in the North American raccoon population.

column1: The raccoon is extensively hunted in Germany as they are seen as an invasive species and pests. In the 1990s
column2: only about 400 raccoons were hunted yearly. This increased to 67
column3: 700 by the 2010/11 hunting season and the tally broke the 100
column4: 000 barrier in 2013. During the 2015/16 hunting season
column5: the tally was 128
column6: 100 animals
column7: 60 percent of which were provided by the federal state of Hesse.

column1: Experiments in acclimatising raccoons into the USSR began in 1936
column2: and were repeated a further 25 times until 1962. Overall
column4: 222 individuals were released
column5: 64 of which came from zoos and fur farms (38 of them having been imports from western Europe). The remainder originated from a population previously established in Transcaucasia. The range of Soviet raccoons was never single or continuous
column6: as they were often introduced to different locations far from each other. All introductions into the Russian Far East failed; melanistic raccoons were released on Petrov Island near Vladivostok and some areas of southern Primorsky Krai
column7: but died. In Middle Asia
column8: raccoons were released in Kyrgyzstan's Jalal-Abad Province
column9: though they were later recorded as ""practically absent"" there in January 1963. A large and stable raccoon population (yielding 1000‚Äì1500 catches a year) was established in Azerbaijan after an introduction to the area in 1937. Raccoons apparently survived an introduction near Terek
column10: along the Sulak River into the Dagestani lowlands. Attempts to settle raccoons on the Kuban River's left tributary and Kabardino-Balkaria were unsuccessful. A successful acclimatization occurred in Belarus
column11: where three introductions (consisting of 52
column12: 37 and 38 individuals in 1954 and 1958) took place. By January 1
column14: 700 individuals were recorded in the country.

column2: the raccoon has been able to use urban areas as a habitat. The first sightings were recorded in a suburb of Cincinnati in the 1920s. Since the 1950s
column3: raccoons have been present in metropolitan areas like Washington
column4: DC
column5: Chicago
column6: and Toronto. Since the 1960s
column7: Kassel has hosted Europe's first and densest population in a large urban area
column8: with about 50 to 150 animals per square kilometer (130 to 390 animals per square mile)
column9: a figure comparable to those of urban habitats in North America. Home range sizes of urban raccoons are only 3 to 40 hectares (7.5 to 100 acres) for females and 8 to 80 hectares (20 to 200 acres) for males. In small towns and suburbs
column10: many raccoons sleep in a nearby forest after foraging in the settlement area. Fruit and insects in gardens and leftovers in municipal waste are easily available food sources. Furthermore
column11: a large number of additional sleeping areas exist in these areas
column12: such as hollows in old garden trees
column13: cottages
column14: garages
column15: abandoned houses
column16: and attics. The percentage of urban raccoons sleeping in abandoned or occupied houses varies from 15% in Washington
column17: DC (1991) to 43% in Kassel (2003).

column2: a lethal disease caused by the neurotropic rabies virus carried in the saliva and transmitted by bites. Its spread began in Florida and Georgia in the 1950s and was facilitated by the introduction of infected individuals to Virginia and North Dakota in the late 1970s. Of the 6
column3: 940 documented rabies cases reported in the United States in 2006
column5: 615 (37.7%) were in raccoons. The U.S. Department of Agriculture
column6: as well as local authorities in several U.S. states and Canadian provinces
column7: has developed oral vaccination programs to fight the spread of the disease in endangered populations. Only one human fatality has been reported after transmission of the rabies virus strain commonly known as ""raccoon rabies"". Among the main symptoms for rabies in raccoons are a generally sickly appearance
column8: impaired mobility
column9: abnormal vocalization
column10: and aggressiveness. There may be no visible signs at all
column11: however
column12: and most individuals do not show the aggressive behavior seen in infected canids; rabid raccoons will often retire to their dens instead. Organizations like the U.S. Forest Service encourage people to stay away from animals with unusual behavior or appearance
column13: and to notify the proper authorities
column14: such as an animal control officer from the local health department. Since healthy animals
column15: especially nursing mothers
column16: will occasionally forage during the day
column17: daylight activity is not a reliable indicator of illness in raccoons.Unlike rabies and at least a dozen other pathogens carried by raccoons
column18: distemper
column19: an epizootic virus
column20: does not affect humans. This disease is the most frequent natural cause of death in the North American raccoon population and affects individuals of all age groups. For example
column21: 94 of 145 raccoons died during an outbreak in Clifton
column22: Ohio
column23: in 1968. It may occur along with a following inflammation of the brain (encephalitis)
column24: causing the animal to display rabies-like symptoms. In Germany
column25: the first eight cases of distemper were reported in 2007.Some of the most important bacterial diseases which affect raccoons are leptospirosis
column26: listeriosis
column27: tetanus
column28: and tularemia. Although internal parasites weaken their immune systems
column29: well-fed individuals can carry a great many roundworms in their digestive tracts without showing symptoms. The larvae of the roundworm Baylisascaris procyonis
column30: which can be contained in the feces and seldom causes a severe illness in humans
column31: can be ingested when cleaning raccoon latrines without wearing breathing protection.While not endemic
column32: the worm Trichinella does infect raccoons
column33: and undercooked raccoon meat has caused trichinosis in humans.Trematode Metorchis conjunctus can also infect raccoons.

column1: The increasing number of raccoons in urban areas has resulted in diverse reactions in humans
column2: ranging from outrage at their presence to deliberate feeding. Some wildlife experts and most public authorities caution against feeding wild animals because they might become increasingly obtrusive and dependent on humans as a food source. Other experts challenge such arguments and give advice on feeding raccoons and other wildlife in their books. Raccoons without a fear of humans are a concern to those who attribute this trait to rabies
column3: but scientists point out this behavior is much more likely to be a behavioral adjustment to living in habitats with regular contact to humans for many generations. Raccoons usually do not prey on domestic cats and dogs
column4: but isolated cases of killings have been reported. Attacks on pets may also target their owners.

column1: While overturned waste containers and raided fruit trees are just a nuisance to homeowners
column2: it can cost several thousand dollars to repair damage caused by the use of attic space as dens. Relocating or killing raccoons without a permit is forbidden in many urban areas on grounds of animal welfare. These methods usually only solve problems with particularly wild or aggressive individuals
column3: since adequate dens are either known to several raccoons or will quickly be rediscovered. Loud noises
column4: flashing lights
column5: and unpleasant odors have proven particularly effective in driving away a mother and her kits before they would normally leave the nesting place (when the kits are about eight weeks old). Typically
column6: though
column7: only precautionary measures to restrict access to food waste and den sites are effective in the long term.Among all fruits and crops cultivated in agricultural areas
column8: sweet corn in its milk stage is particularly popular among raccoons. In a two-year study by Purdue University researchers
column9: published in 2004
column10: raccoons were responsible for 87% of the damage to corn plants. Like other predators
column11: raccoons searching for food can break into poultry houses to feed on chickens
column12: ducks
column13: their eggs
column14: or food.

column2: arts
column3: and entertainment ===

column1: In the mythology of the Indigenous peoples of the Americas
column2: the raccoon is the subject of folk tales. Stories such as ""How raccoons catch so many crayfish"" from the Tuscarora centered on its skills at foraging. In other tales
column3: the raccoon played the role of the trickster which outsmarts other animals
column4: like coyotes and wolves. Among others
column5: the Dakota believe the raccoon has natural spirit powers
column6: since its mask resembles the facial paintings
column7: two-fingered swashes of black and white
column8: used during rituals to connect to spirit beings. The Aztecs linked supernatural abilities especially to females
column9: whose commitment to their young was associated with the role of wise women in their society.The raccoon also appears in Native American art across a wide geographic range. Petroglyphs with engraved raccoon tracks were found in Lewis Canyon
column10: Texas; at the Crow Hollow petroglyph site in Grayson County
column11: Kentucky; and in river drainages near Tularosa
column12: the San Francisco River of New Mexico and Arizona. A true-to-detail figurine made of quartz
column13: the Ohio Mound Builders' Stone Pipe
column14: was found near the Scioto River. The meaning and significance of the Raccoon Priests Gorget
column15: which features a stylized carving of a raccoon and was found at the Spiro Mounds
column16: Oklahoma
column17: remains unknown.In Western culture
column18: several autobiographical novels about living with a raccoon have been written
column19: mostly for children. The best-known is Sterling North's Rascal
column20: which recounts how he raised a kit during World War I. In recent years
column21: anthropomorphic raccoons played main roles in the animated television series The Raccoons
column22: the computer-animated film Over the Hedge
column23: the live action film Guardians of the Galaxy (and the comics that it was based upon) and the video game series Sly Cooper.

column1: The fur of raccoons is used for clothing
column2: especially for coats and coonskin caps. At present
column3: it is the material used for the inaccurately named ""sealskin"" cap worn by the Royal Fusiliers of Great Britain. Sporrans made of raccoon pelt and hide have sometimes been used as part of traditional Scottish highland men's apparel since the 18th century
column4: especially in North America. Such sporrans may or may not be of the ""full-mask"" type. Historically
column5: Native American tribes not only used the fur for winter clothing
column6: but also used the tails for ornament. The famous Sioux leader Spotted Tail took his name from a raccoon skin hat with the tail attached he acquired from a fur trader. Since the late 18th century
column7: various types of scent hounds
column8: called ""coonhounds""
column9: which are able to tree animals have been bred in the United States. In the 19th century
column10: when coonskins occasionally even served as means of payment
column11: several thousand raccoons were killed each year in the United States. This number rose quickly when automobile coats became popular after the turn of the 20th century. In the 1920s
column12: wearing a raccoon coat was regarded as status symbol among college students. Attempts to breed raccoons in fur farms in the 1920s and 1930s in North America and Europe turned out not to be profitable
column13: and farming was abandoned after prices for long-haired pelts dropped in the 1940s. Although raccoons had become rare in the 1930s
column14: at least 388
column15: 000 were killed during the hunting season of 1934/35.After persistent population increases began in the 1940s
column16: the seasonal coon hunting harvest reached about one million animals in 1946/47 and two million in 1962/63. The broadcast of three television episodes about the frontiersman Davy Crockett and the film Davy Crockett
column17: King of the Wild Frontier in 1954 and 1955 led to a high demand for coonskin caps in the United States
column18: although it is unlikely either Crockett or the actor who played him
column19: Fess Parker
column20: actually wore a cap made from raccoon fur. The seasonal hunt reached an all-time high with 5.2 million animals in 1976/77 and ranged between 3.2 and 4.7 million for most of the 1980s. In 1982
column21: the average pelt price was $20. As of 1987
column22: the raccoon was identified as the most important wild furbearer in North America in terms of revenue. In the first half of the 1990s
column23: the seasonal hunt dropped to 0.9 from 1.9 million due to decreasing pelt prices.While primarily hunted for their fur
column24: raccoons were also a source of food for Native Americans and early American settlers. According to Ernest Thompson Seton
column25: young specimens killed without a fight are palatable
column26: whereas old raccoons caught after a lengthy battle are inedible. Raccoon meat was extensively eaten during the early years of California
column27: where it was sold in the San Francisco market for $1‚Äì3 apiece. American slaves occasionally ate raccoon at Christmas
column28: but it was not necessarily a dish of the poor or rural. The first edition of The Joy of Cooking
column29: released in 1931
column30: contained a recipe for preparing raccoon
column31: and US President Calvin Coolidge's pet raccoon Rebecca was originally sent to be served at the White House Thanksgiving Dinner.Although the idea of eating raccoons may seem repulsive to most mainstream consumers
column32: who see them as endearing
column33: cute
column35: several thousand raccoons are still eaten each year in the United States
column36: primarily in the Southern United States. Some people tout the taste of the meat.

column1: Raccoons are sometimes kept as pets
column2: which is discouraged by many experts because the raccoon is not a domesticated species. Raccoons may act unpredictably and aggressively and it is extremely difficult to teach them to obey commands. In places where keeping raccoons as pets is not forbidden
column3: such as in Wisconsin and other U.S. states
column4: an exotic pet permit may be required. One notable raccoon pet was Rebecca
column5: kept by US president Calvin Coolidge.Their propensity for unruly behavior exceeds that of captive skunks
column6: and they are even less trustworthy when allowed to roam freely. Because of their intelligence and nimble forelimbs
column7: even inexperienced raccoons are easily capable of unscrewing jars
column8: uncorking bottles and opening door latches
column9: with more experienced specimens having been recorded to open door knobs. Sexually mature raccoons often show aggressive natural behaviors such as biting during the mating season. Neutering them at around five or six months of age decreases the chances of aggressive behavior developing. Raccoons can become obese and suffer from other disorders due to poor diet and lack of exercise. When fed with cat food over a long time period
column10: raccoons can develop gout. With respect to the research results regarding their social behavior
column11: it is now required by law in Austria and Germany to keep at least two individuals to prevent loneliness. Raccoons are usually kept in a pen (indoor or outdoor)
column12: also a legal requirement in Austria and Germany
column13: rather than in the apartment where their natural curiosity may result in damage to property.When orphaned
column14: it is possible for kits to be rehabilitated and reintroduced to the wild. However
column15: it is uncertain whether they readapt well to life in the wild. Feeding unweaned kits with cow's milk rather than a kitten replacement milk or a similar product can be dangerous to their health.

of Central and South America

column2: also known as the topmouth gudgeon
column3: is a fish belonging to the Cyprinid family
column4: native to Asia
column5: but introduced and now considered an invasive species in Europe and North America. The fish's size is rarely above 8 cm and usually 2 to 7.5 cm long.

column2: P. parva is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.The fish was introduced in the 1960s into ponds in Nucet
column7: D√¢mbovi≈£a County
column8: Romania and it made its way into Danube
column9: then spreading throughout Europe. They pose danger to other species such as the sunbleaks (Leucaspius delineatus). They are the carrier of a parasite (Sphaerothecum destruens) that is not damaging to the topmouth gudgeon
column10: but attacks other fishes like the sunbleaks
column11: which are unable to spawn and have a higher mortality when infected. They also feed on eggs of locally valuable native fish species.

column1: The species has also been recently discovered in several lakes in the UK where it is believed to have been illegally stocked. This has called for a large scale eradication programme organised by the Environment Agency who kill the fish off with a piscicide called rotenone.

column1: The plant is native to East Asia (China

column1: The starch powder made from the East Asian arrowroot is called kudzu powder. Kudzu powder is used to make arrowroot tea in traditional medicines of China

also known as simply the grey squirrel
column3: is a tree squirrel in the genus Sciurus. It is native to eastern North America
column4: where it is the most prodigious and ecologically essential natural forest regenerator. Widely introduced to certain places around the world
column5: the eastern gray squirrel in Europe
column6: in particular
column7: is regarded as an invasive species.

column2: Sciurus carolinensis is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported

column1: Sciurus carolinensis is native to the eastern and midwestern United States
column2: and to the southerly portions of the central provinces of Canada. The native range of the eastern gray squirrel overlaps with that of the fox squirrel (Sciurus niger)
