column5: through southwestern Quebec and throughout southern Ontario plus in southern Manitoba
column6: south to East Texas and Florida. Breeding eastern gray squirrels are found in Nova Scotia
column7: but whether this population was introduced or came from natural range expansion is not known.A prolific and adaptable species
column8: the eastern gray squirrel has also been introduced to
column9: and thrives in
column10: several regions of the western United States and in 1966
column11: this squirrel was introduced into Vancouver Island in Western Canada in the area of Metchosin
column12: and has spread widely from there. They are considered highly invasive and a threat to both the local ecosystem and the native squirrel
column13: the American red squirrel.Overseas
column14: Eastern gray squirrels in Europe are a concern because they have displaced some of the native squirrels there. They have been introduced into Ireland
column15: Britain
column16: Italy
column17: South Africa
column18: and Australia (where it was extirpated by 1973).In Ireland
column19: the native squirrel ‚Äì also colored red ‚Äì the Eurasian red squirrel S. vulgaris ‚Äì has been displaced in several eastern counties
column20: though it still remains common in the south and west of the country. The gray squirrel is also an invasive species in Britain; it has spread across the country and has largely displaced the red squirrel. That such a displacement might happen in Italy is of concern
column21: as gray squirrels might spread to other parts of mainland Europe.

column2: Sciurus
column3: is derived from two Greek words
column4: skia
column5: meaning shadow
column6: and oura
column7: meaning tail. This name alludes to the squirrel sitting in the shadow of its tail. The specific epithet
column8: carolinensis
column9: refers to the Carolinas
column10: where the species was first recorded and where the animal is still extremely common. In the United Kingdom and Canada
column11: it is simply referred to as the ""grey squirrel"". In the US
column12: ""eastern"" is used to differentiate the species from the western gray squirrel (Sciurus griseus).

column1: The eastern gray squirrel has predominantly gray fur
column2: but it can have a brownish color. It has a usual white underside as compared to the typical brownish-orange underside of the fox squirrel. It has a large bushy tail. Particularly in urban situations where the risk of predation is reduced
column3: both white ‚Äì and black-colored individuals are quite often found. The melanistic form
column4: which is almost entirely black
column5: is predominant in certain populations and in certain geographic areas
column6: such as in large parts of southeastern Canada. Melanistic squirrels appear to exhibit a higher cold tolerance than the common gray morph; when exposed to ‚àí10 ¬∞C
column7: black squirrels showed an 18% reduction in heat loss
column8: a 20% reduction in basal metabolic rate
column9: and an 11% increase to non-shivering thermogenesis capacity when compared to the common gray morph. The black coloration is caused by an incomplete dominant mutation of MC1R
column10: where E+/E+ is a wild type squirrel
column11: E+/EB is brown-black
column12: and EB/EB is black.The head and body length is from 23 to 30 cm (9.1 to 11.8 in)
column13: the tail from 19 to 25 cm (7.5 to 9.8 in)
column14: and the adult weight varies between 400 and 600 g (14 and 21 oz). They do not display sexual dimorphism
column15: meaning there is no gender difference in size or coloration.The tracks of an eastern gray squirrel are difficult to distinguish from the related fox squirrel and Abert's squirrel
column16: though the latter's range is almost entirely different from the gray's. Like all squirrels
column17: the eastern gray shows four toes on the front feet and five on the hind feet. The hind foot-pad is often not visible in the track. When bounding or moving at speed
column18: the front foot tracks will be behind the hind foot tracks. The bounding stride can be two to three feet long.The dental formula of the eastern gray squirrel is 1023/1013 (upper teeth/lower teeth).1.0.2.31.0.1.3 √ó 2 = 22 total teeth.

column2: meaning they grow consistently throughout life
column3: and their cheek teeth exhibit brachydont (low-crowned teeth) and bunodont (having tubercles on crowns) structures.

column1: Like many members of the family Sciuridae
column2: the eastern gray squirrel is a scatter-hoarder; it hoards food in numerous small caches for later recovery. Some caches are quite temporary
column3: especially those made near the site of a sudden abundance of food which can be retrieved within hours or days for reburial in a more secure site. Others are more permanent and are not retrieved until months later. Each squirrel is estimated to make several thousand caches each season. The squirrels have very accurate spatial memory for the locations of these caches
column4: and use distant and nearby landmarks to retrieve them. Smell is used partly to uncover food caches
column5: and also to find food in other squirrels' caches. Scent can be unreliable when the ground is too dry or covered in snow.Squirrels sometimes use deceptive behavior to prevent other animals from retrieving cached food. They will pretend to bury the object if they feel that they are being watched. They do this by preparing the spot as usual
column6: for instance
column7: digging a hole or widening a crack
column8: miming the placement of the food
column9: while actually concealing it in their mouths
column10: and then covering up the ""cache"" as if they had deposited the object. They also hide behind vegetation while burying food or hide it high up in trees (if their rival is not arboreal). Such a complex repertoire suggests that the behaviors are not innate
column11: and imply theory of mind thinking.The eastern gray squirrel is one of very few mammalian species that can descend a tree head-first. It does this by turning its feet so the claws of its hind paws are backward-pointing and can grip the tree bark.Eastern gray squirrels build a type of nest
column12: known as a drey
column13: in the forks of trees
column14: consisting mainly of dry leaves and twigs. The dreys are roughly spherical
column15: about 30 to 60 cm in diameter and are usually insulated with moss
column16: thistledown
column17: dried grass
column18: and feathers to reduce heat loss. Males and females may share the same nest for short times during the breeding season
column19: and during cold winter spells. Squirrels may share a drey to stay warm. They may also nest in the attic or exterior walls of a house
column20: where they may be regarded as pests
column21: as well as fire hazards due to their habit of gnawing on electrical cables. In addition
column22: squirrels may inhabit a permanent tree den hollowed out in the trunk or a large branch of a tree.Eastern gray squirrels are crepuscular
column23: or more active during the early and late hours of the day
column24: and tend to avoid the heat in the middle of a summer day. They do not hibernate.

column1: Eastern gray squirrels can breed twice a year
column2: but younger and less experienced mothers normally have a single litter per year in the spring. Depending on forage availability
column3: older and more experienced females may breed again in summer. In a year of abundant food
column4: 36% of females bear two litters
column5: but none will do so in a year of poor food. Their breeding seasons are December to February and May to June
column6: though this is slightly delayed in more northern latitudes. The first litter is born in February or March
column7: the second in June or July
column8: though
column9: again
column10: bearing may be advanced or delayed by a few weeks depending on climate
column11: temperature
column12: and forage availability. In any given breeding season
column13: an average of 61 ‚Äì 66% of females bear young. If a female fails to conceive or loses her young to unusually cold weather or predation
column14: she re-enters estrus and has a later litter. Five days before a female enters estrus
column15: she may attract up to 34 males from up to 500 meters away. Eastern gray squirrels exhibit a form of polygyny
column16: in which the competing males will form a hierarchy of dominance
column17: and the female will mate with multiple males depending on the hierarchy established.

column2: one to four young are born in each litter
column3: but the largest possible litter size is eight. The gestation period is about 44 days. The young are weaned around 10 weeks
column4: though some may wean up to six weeks later in the wild. They begin to leave the nest after 12 weeks
column5: with autumn born young often wintering with their mother. Only one in four squirrel kits survives to one year of age
column6: with mortality around 55% for the following year. Mortality rates then decrease to around 30% for following years until they increase sharply at eight years of age.Rarely
column7: eastern gray females can enter estrus as early as five and a half months old
column8: but females are not normally fertile until at least one year of age. Their mean age of first estrus is 1.25 years. The presence of a fertile male will induce ovulation in a female going through estrus. Male eastern grays are sexually mature between one and two years of age. Reproductive longevity for females appears to be over 8 years
column9: with 12.5 years documented in North Carolina. These squirrels can live to be 20 years old in captivity
column10: but in the wild live much shorter lives due to predation and the challenges of their habitat. At birth
column11: their life expectancy is 1‚Äì2 years
column12: an adult typically can live to be six
column13: with exceptional individuals making it to 12 years.

column1: Newborn gray squirrels weigh 13‚Äì18 grams and are entirely hairless and pink
column2: although vibrissae are present at birth. 7‚Äì10 days postpartum
column3: the skin begins to darken
column4: just before the juvenile pelage grows in. Lower incisors erupt 19‚Äì21 days postpartum
column5: while upper incisors erupt after 4 weeks. Cheek teeth erupt during week 6. Eyes open after 21‚Äì42 days
column6: and ears open 3‚Äì4 weeks postpartum. Weaning is initiated around 7 weeks postpartum
column7: and is usually finished by week 10
column8: followed by the loss of the juvenile pelage. Full adult body mass is achieved by 8‚Äì9 months after birth.

column2: communication among eastern gray squirrel individuals involves both vocalizations and posturing. The species has a quite varied repertoire of vocalizations
column3: including a squeak similar to that of a mouse
column4: a low-pitched noise
column5: a chatter
column6: and a raspy ""mehr mehr mehr"". Other methods of communication include tail-flicking and other gestures
column7: including facial expressions. Tail flicking and the ""kuk"" or ""quaa"" call are used to ward off and warn other squirrels about predators
column8: as well as to announce when a predator is leaving the area. Squirrels also make an affectionate coo-purring sound that biologists call the ""muk-muk"" sound. This is used as a contact sound between a mother and her kits and in adulthood
column9: by the male when he courts the female during mating season.The use of vocal and visual communication has been shown to vary by location
column10: based on elements such as noise pollution and the amount of open space. For instance
column11: populations living in large cities generally rely more on the visual signals
column12: due to the generally louder environment with more areas without much visual restriction. However
column13: in heavily wooded areas
column14: vocal signals are used more often due to the relatively lower noise levels and a dense canopy restricting visual range.

column1: Eastern gray squirrels eat a range of foods
column2: such as tree bark
column3: tree buds
column4: flowers
column5: berries
column6: many types of seeds and acorns
column7: walnuts
column8: and other nuts
column9: like hazelnuts (see picture) and some types of fungi found in the forests
column10: including fly agaric mushrooms (Amanita muscaria). They can cause damage to trees by tearing the bark and eating the soft cambial tissue underneath. In Europe
column11: sycamore (Acer pseudoplatanus L.) and beech (Fagus sylvatica L.) suffer the greatest damage. The seeds and catkins of gymnosperms such as cedar
column12: hemlock
column13: pine
column14: and spruce are another food source. The squirrels also raid gardens for wheat
column15: tomatoes
column16: corn
column17: strawberries
column18: and other garden crops. Sometimes they eat the tomato seeds and discard the rest. On occasion
column19: eastern gray squirrels also prey upon insects
column20: frogs
column21: small rodents including other squirrels
column22: and small birds
column23: their eggs
column24: and young. They also gnaw on bones
column25: antlers
column26: and turtle shells ‚Äì likely as a source of minerals scarce in their normal diet.

column1: Eastern gray squirrels have a high enough tolerance for humans to inhabit residential neighborhoods and raid bird feeders for millet
column2: corn
column3: and sunflower seeds. Some people who feed and watch birds for entertainment also intentionally feed seeds and nuts to the squirrels for the same reason. However
column4: in the UK eastern gray squirrels can take a significant proportion of supplementary food from feeders
column5: preventing access and reducing use by wild birds. Attraction to supplementary feeders can increase local bird nest predation
column6: as eastern gray squirrels are more likely to forage near feeders
column7: resulting in increased likelihood of finding nests
column8: eggs and nestlings of small passerines.

column2: hawks
column3: weasels
column4: raccoons
column5: bobcats
column6: foxes
column7: domestic and feral cats
column8: snakes
column9: owls
column10: and dogs. In its introduced range in South Africa
column11: it has been preyed on by African harrier-hawks.

column2: eastern gray squirrels can be found inhabiting large areas of mature
column3: dense woodland ecosystems
column4: generally covering 100 acres (40 hectares) of land. These forests usually contain large mast-producing trees such as oaks and hickories
column5: providing ample food sources. Oak-hickory hardwood forests are generally preferred over coniferous forests due to the greater abundance of mast forage. This is why they are found only in parts of eastern Canada which do not contain boreal forest (i.e. they are found in some parts of New Brunswick
column6: in southwestern Quebec
column7: throughout southern Ontario and in southern Manitoba).

column1: Eastern gray squirrels generally prefer constructing their dens upon large tree branches and within the hollow trunks of trees. They also have been known to take shelter within abandoned bird nests. The dens are usually lined with moss plants
column2: thistledown
column3: dried grass
column4: and feathers. These perhaps provide and assist in the insulation of the den
column5: used to reduce heat loss. A cover to the den is usually built afterwards.Close to human settlements
column6: eastern gray squirrels are found in parks and back yards of houses within urban environments and in the farmlands of rural environments.

column1: The eastern gray squirrel is an introduced species in a variety of locations in western North America: in western Canada
column2: to the southwest corner of British Columbia and to the city of Calgary
column3: Alberta; in the United States
column4: to the states of Washington and Oregon and
column5: in California
column6: to the city of San Francisco and the San Francisco Peninsula area in San Mateo and Santa Clara Counties
column7: south of the city. It has become the most common squirrel in many urban and suburban habitats in western North America
column8: from north of central California to southwest British Columbia. At the turn of the 20th century
column9: the eastern gray squirrel was introduced into South Africa
column10: Ireland
column11: Hawaii
column12: Bermuda
column13: Madeira Island
column14: the Azores
column15: the Canary Islands
column16: Cape Verde
column17: Italy and the United Kingdom.In South Africa
column18: though exotic
column19: it is not usually considered an invasive species owing to its small range (only found in the extreme southwestern part of the Western Cape
column20: going north as far as the small farming town of Franschhoek)
column21: as well because it inhabits urban areas and places greatly affected by humans
column22: such as agricultural areas and exotic pine plantations. Here
column23: it mostly eats acorns and pine seeds
column24: although it will take indigenous and commercial fruit
column25: as well. Even so
column26: it is unable to use the natural vegetation (fynbos) found in the area
column27: a factor which has helped to limit its spread. It does not come into contact with native squirrels due to geographic isolation (a native tree squirrel
column28: Paraxerus cepapi

column1: Gray squirrels were first introduced to Britain in the 1870s
column2: as fashionable additions to estates. In 1921 it was reported in The Times that the Zoological Society of London had released Eastern Greys to breed at liberty in Regents Park:

column1: A dozen years ago the Zoological Society of London obtained a number from a private collection in Bedfordshire for the purpose of inducing them to breed at liberty in the Gardens in Regent‚Äôs Park. They were first kept in a large enclosure from which
column2: when they had become used to visitors
column3: they were allowed to pass in and out by a rope bridge to a tree. It was hoped that they would spread from the Gardens to the Park. After two or three years in which they seemed to be disappearing
column4: they suddenly became ubiquitous...The grey squirrels are plainly happy and plainly give happiness to Londoners...On the other hand
column5: grey squirrels
column6: whether by taking advantage of tubes and buses
column7: or by deliberate human connivance
column8: have spread from London and are invading the country over very wide areas. They are said to drive out the red squirrel
column9: to raid gardens
column10: and to add to the anxieties of the pheasant breeder. We hope that fuller inquiry will not sustain these charges.

column2: and then became established in both Wales and parts of southern Scotland. On mainland Britain
column3: they have almost entirely displaced native red squirrels. Larger than red squirrels and capable of storing up to four times more fat
column4: gray squirrels are better able to survive winter conditions. They produce more young and can live at higher densities. Gray squirrels also carry the squirrelpox virus
column5: to which red squirrels have no immunity. When an infected gray squirrel introduces squirrelpox to a red squirrel population
column6: its decline is 17‚Äì25 times greater than through competition alone.In Ireland
column7: the displacement of red squirrels has not been as rapid because only a single introduction occurred
column8: in County Longford. Schemes have been introduced to control the population of gray squirrels in Ireland to encourage the native red squirrels. Eastern gray squirrels have also been introduced to Italy
column9: and the European Union has expressed concern that they will similarly displace the red squirrel from parts of the European continent.

column2: the eastern gray squirrel is not regulated by natural predators
column3: other than the European pine marten
column4: which is generally absent from England and Wales. This has aided its rapid population growth and has led to the species being classed as a pest. Measures are being devised to reduce its numbers
column5: including a campaign starting in 2006 named ‚ÄúSave Our Squirrels‚Äù using the slogan ""Save a red
column6: eat a grey!"" which attempted to re-introduce squirrel meat in to the local market
column7: with celebrity chefs promoting the idea
column8: cookbooks introducing recipes containing squirrel and the Forestry Commission providing a regular supply of squirrel meat to British restaurants
column9: factories and butchers. In areas where relict populations of red squirrels survive
column10: such as the islands of Anglesey
column11: Brownsea and the Isle of Wight
column12: programs exist to eradicate gray squirrels and prevent them from reaching these areas in order to allow red squirrel populations to recover and grow.Although complex and controversial
column13: the main factor in the eastern gray squirrel's displacement of the red squirrel is thought to be its greater fitness
column14: hence a competitive advantage over the red squirrel on all measures. The eastern gray squirrel tends to be larger and stronger than the red squirrel and has been shown to have a greater ability to store fat for winter. The squirrel can
column15: therefore
column16: compete more effectively for a larger share of the available food
column17: resulting in relatively lower survival and breeding rates among the red squirrel. Parapoxvirus may also be a strongly contributing factor; red squirrels have long been fatally affected by the disease
column18: while the eastern gray squirrels are unaffected
column19: but thought to be carriers ‚Äì although how the virus is transmitted has yet to be determined. However
column20: several cases of red squirrels surviving have been reported
column21: as they have developed an immunity ‚Äì although their population is still being massively affected. The red squirrel is also less tolerant of habitat destruction and fragmentation
column22: which has led to its population decline
column23: while the more adaptable eastern gray squirrel has taken advantage and expanded.

column1: Similar factors appear to have been at play in the Pacific region of North America
column2: where the native American red squirrel has been largely displaced by the eastern gray squirrel in parks and forests throughout much of the region.
""fears"" for the future of the eastern gray squirrel arose in 2008
column3: as the melanistic form (black) began to spread through the southern British population. In the UK
column4: if a ""grey squirrel"" (eastern gray squirrel) is trapped
column5: under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981
column6: it is illegal to release it or to allow it to escape into the wild; instead
column7: it is legally required be ""humanely dispatched"".In the late 1990s
column8: Italy's National Wildlife Institute and University of Turin launched an eradication attempt to halt the spread of gray squirrels in northwest Italy
column9: but court action by animal rights groups blocked this. Hence gray squirrels are expected to cross the Alps into France and Switzerland in the next few decades.

column1: === Fossil record of the eastern gray squirrel ===
Twenty different Pleistocene fauna specimens contain S. carolinensis
column2: found in Florida and dated to be as early as the late Irvingtonian period. Body size seems to have increased during the early to middle Holocene and then decreased to the present size seen today.

column1: Gray squirrels were eaten in earlier times by Native Americans and their meat is still popular with hunters across most of their range in North America. Today

column3: physicians in the United States have warned that squirrel brains should not be eaten
column4: because of the risk that they may carry Creutzfeldt‚ÄìJakob disease.

Even though the Siberian chipmunk normally grows to 50‚Äì150 g (1.8‚Äì5.3 oz). The Siberian chipmunk exhibits sexual dimorphism

column1: The Siberian chipmunk can survive in a variety of habitats and conditions. They are usually found in coniferous forests
column2: stony areas within forests and mountains
column3: habitats filled with shrub
column4: along waterways or roads
column5: or other small patches of agricultural land. In Europe
column6: the introduced populations usually live in deciduous forests
column7: mixed deciduous and coniferous forests
column8: or urban areas with greenery. Tamias sibiricus is able to survive in various environmental conditions
column9: anywhere from 29¬∞N to 69¬∞N and ‚àí65 ¬∞C to 30 ¬∞C. However
column10: this species has a low ability of dispersal
column11: and since they are mainly introduced into woody forests or urban areas with greenery
column12: they have less potential to be naturally dispersed to other regions. Also they have trouble overcoming man-made and naturally occurring obstacles
column13: like roads or swamps.The Siberian chipmunk lives in loose colonies
column14: where every individual has its own territory. The territory ranges from 700 to 4000 m2 and is larger for females than males and is also larger in autumn than spring. The Siberian chipmunk marks its territory with urine and oral glands inside of its cheeks. This method illustrates one way in which this species communicates with one another.

column1: Siberian chipmunks usually live solitary lives
column2: but during the winter they create a burrow
column3: which they often share with another chipmunk. Its burrow
column4: which can be 2.5 m (8 ft 2 in) long and 1.5 m (4 ft 11 in) deep
column5: consists of a nest chamber
column6: several storage chambers and chambers for the waste. During this winter season
column7: these chipmunks store 3‚Äì4 kg (6.6‚Äì8.8 lb) of food in order to survive underground until April or May. In addition to pairing off during hibernation
column8: they also use a complex voice communication system to interact. They have two vocal sounds
column9: a fast
column10: sharp sound for when they are frightened and a deep croak sound that is thought to be used for mating.Chipmunks with more active and curious behaviour
column11: based on trappability of marked individuals
column12: have a greater number of ticks.

column1: It is known that they are iteroparous
column2: viviparous
column3: and their breeding season usually occurs after hibernation in mid April. They tend to breed only once or twice a year
column4: and the number of offspring varies from three to eight. The young are born blind and naked
column5: and they weigh between 3‚Äì5 g (0.11‚Äì0.18 oz). After the 28- to 35-day gestation period
column6: the offspring open their eyes about 20 to 25 days after birth. The females are responsible for caring for the young
column7: and they teach them how to forage around six weeks. Then the offspring complete the weaning stage around seven weeks
column8: and they reach the independent stage around eight weeks. Adult body mass is reached at around three to four months
column9: and by nine months
column10: both the male and the female reach sexual maturity.

column1: Siberian chipmunks are omnivores that store or cache food. Normally
column2: they eat pine seeds
column3: along with different deciduous and coniferous tree seeds. In addition to seeds

column5: insects
column6: molluscs
column7: birds
column8: reptiles
column9: grains
column10: fruit
column11: and fungus.

column1: Siberian chipmunks are essential food sources for other animals
column2: such as diurnal raptors
column3: weasels
column4: and small cats. Other known predators include hawks
column5: owls
column6: and foxes. They evade being preyed upon by these animals by being alert
column7: hiding in their burrows
column8: and using their camouflaged fur to blend in with surroundings. They distribute seeds and fungal spores
column9: and other animals feed off their stored food. They may help control forest tree pests. In Russia
column10: they eat approximately 50 percent of the forest nuts. In Belgium
column11: these chipmunks have been blamed for preying upon low-nesting birds.

column1: If the species were introduced to Britain

column1: Some people keep Siberian chipmunks as pets or sell them for their fur or other body parts. Siberian chipmunks may eat crops and damage gardens. In Russia they can cause serious economic damage to grain fields and orchards.
The species can carry Lyme disease
column2: caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi
column3: that can be transmitted through ticks. In a study in a park near Paris where the Siberian chipmunk had established itself
column4: in comparison to bank voles and wood mice
column5: the Siberian chipmunks had a much higher infection load than their native counterparts. Because they were more diseased
column6: it was theorised that they contributed to more infected questing nymph ticks

column1: Invasion of Siberian chipmunk in Paris
Threskiornis aethiopicushttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African%20sacred%20ibis"The African sacred ibis (Threskiornis aethiopicus) is a species of ibis
column2: a wading bird of the family Threskiornithidae. It is native to Africa and the Middle East. It is especially known for its role in the religion of the Ancient Egyptians
column3: where it was linked to the god Thoth; despite this
column4: the species is currently extirpated from Egypt.

column1: It is very closely related to the black-headed ibis and the Australian white ibis
column2: with which it forms a superspecies complex
column3: so much so that the three species are considered conspecific by some ornithologists. In mixed flocks these ibises often hybridise. The Australian white ibis is often called the sacred ibis colloquially.Although known to the ancient civilisations of Greece
column4: Rome and especially Africa
column5: ibises were unfamiliar to western Europeans from the fall of Rome until the 19th century
column6: and mentions of this bird in the ancient works of these civilisations were supposed to describe some type of curlew or other bird
column7: and were thus translated as such. In 1758
column8: Linnaeus was convinced that the ancient authors were describing a cattle egret (Bubulcus ibis)
column9: which he thus described as Ardea ibis. Following the work of Mathurin Jacques Brisson
column10: who calls it Ibis candida in 1760
column11: in the 12th edition of his Systema Naturae of 1766 Linnaeus classifies it as Tantalus ibis. These were also unfamiliar birds that did not occur in Europe at the time
column12: in English in these times called the 'Egyptian ibis' by Latham
column13: and the 'emseesy' or 'ox-bird' by George Shaw.In 1790
column14: John Latham provided the first unambiguous modern scientific description of the sacred ibis as Tantalus aethiopicus
column15: mentioning James Bruce of Kinnaird who called it 'abou hannes' in his writings describing his travels in Sudan and Ethiopia
column16: and also described Tantalus melanocephalus of India.Georges Cuvier named it Ibis religiosus in his Le R√®gne Animal of 1817.In 1842
column17: George Robert Gray reclassified the bird under the new genus Threskiornis
column18: because the type of the genus Tantalus was designated as to be the wood stork
column19: also formerly known as the wood ibis or wood pelican
column20: and Gray decided these birds could not be classified in the same genus.In a comprehensive review of plumage patterns by Holyoak in 1970
column21: it was noted that the three taxa were extremely similar and that the Australian birds resembled Threskiornis aethiopicus in adult plumage and T. melanocephalus in juvenile plumage
column22: he thus proposed they all be considered part of a single species T. aethiopicus. At the time this was generally accepted by the scientific community
column23: however in 'The Birds of the Western Palearctic' compendium of 1977
column24: Roselaar advocated splitting the group into 4 species
column25: recognising T. bernieri
column26: based again on the then known geographical morphological differences.In 1990
column27: Sibley & Monroe
column28: in the general reference 'Distribution and Taxonomy of Birds of the World' followed Roselaar in recognising four species
column29: which they repeated in 'A World Checklist of Birds' of 1993.This taxon being split from T. melanocephalus and T. molucca was further advocated by another morphological study by Lowe and Richards in 1991
column30: where
column31: like Holyoak
column32: they looked at plumage again but used much more skins
column33: but unlike him concluded that the differences were such to merit separate species status for the three taxa
column34: especially as they could find no intergradation in morphological characters in possible contact zones in SE Asia. They also cite purported differences in courtship displays between the Australian and Asian birds. Based on these characteristics they recommended the Malagasy birds be considered a subspecies of T. aethiopicus.In 2003
column35: Birdlife International elected to adopt the narrow taxonomic concept as advocated in Sibley & Monroe 1993.

column1: An adult individual is 68 cm (27 in) long with all-white body plumage apart from dark plumes on the rump. Wingspan is 112 to 124 cm (44 to 49 in) and body weight 1.35 to 1.5 kg (3.0 to 3.3 lb). Males are generally slightly larger than females.The bald head and neck

column4: a smaller bill and some feathering on the neck
column5: greenish-brown scapulars and more black on the primary coverts.This bird is usually silent
column6: but occasionally makes puppy-like yelping noises
column7: unlike its vocal relative
column8: the hadada ibis.

column1: The sacred ibis breeds in Sub-Saharan Africa and southeastern Iraq. A number of populations are migrant with the rains; some of the South African birds migrate 1
column2: 500 km as far north as Zambia
column3: the African birds north of the equator migrate in the opposite direction. The Iraqi population usually migrates to southwestern Iran

column1: It was formerly found in North Africa including Kemet
column2: where it was commonly venerated and mummified as a votive offering to the god Thoth. For many centuries until the Roman period the main temples buried a few dozen of thousands of birds a year
column3: and to sustain sufficient numbers for the demand for sacrifices by pilgrims from all over Egypt
column4: it was for some time believed that ibis breeding farms (called ibiotropheia by Herodotus) existed. Aristotle mentions in c. 350 BC that many sacred ibises are found all over Egypt. Strabo
column5: writing around 20 AD

column16: albeit questionable
column17: sighting in 1864. An examination of the genetic diversity among mummified ibises suggested that there was no reduction in genetic diversity as would be caused if they were bred in captivity and further studies on isotopes suggest that the birds were not just wild caught but came from a wide geographic range.The species did not breed in southern Africa before the beginning of the 20th century

column19: dams
column20: and commercial agricultural practices such as dung heaps
column21: carrion and refuse tips. It began to breed in the early 20th century

Its population for example expanded 2-3-fold during the period between 1972 and 1995 in Orange Free State. It is now found throughout southern Africa. The species is a common resident in most parts of South Africa. Local numbers are swollen in summer by individuals migrating southwards from the equator.Elsewhere in Africa it occurs throughout the continent south of the Sahara

column24: the Karoo
column25: the Kalahari) and probably the rainforests of the Congo. In west Africa it is fairly uncommon across the Sahel

column1: The first African sacred ibises brought to Europe were two imported from Egypt to France in the mid-1700s. In the 1800s the first escapes were sighted in Europe (in Austria

column3: which were allowed to forage in the area but would return to roost in the zoo every day. As such feral populations were established in Italy

column9: Florida
column10: Taiwan
column11: the United Arab Emirates and possibly Bahrain.Some studies indicate that the introduced populations in Europe have significant economic and ecological impacts

The first successful breeding was in 1993 at two sites
column7: the Golfe du Morbihan and Lac de Grand-Lieu

A cull was begun and by 2011 the population had fallen to 560‚Äì600 pairs. By January 2017 the eradication programme had lowered the number of birds in roosts in western France to 300‚Äì500 birds and the Lac de Grand-Lieu was the only regular breeding site in the region; as the programme has progressed the birds have become warier and the reduced numbers mean the effort and cost per bird has increased and complete eradication may never be achieved. The population near Sigean was eradicated by killing and capturing the birds with only a few remaining in the Camargue.This species is not considered established in mainland Spain. The Barcelona Zoo kept a small free-flying population which bred in the zoo and at least once in 1974 in the surrounding city park. Between 1983 and 1985 they had increased to 18 birds

column1: The African sacred ibis occurs in marshy wetlands and mud flats
column2: both inland and on the coast. It preferably nests on trees in or near water. It feeds wading in very shallow wetlands or slowly stomping in wet pastures with soft soil. It will also visit cultivation and rubbish dumps.

column1: The species are predators which feed primarily by day
column2: generally in flocks. The diet consists of mainly insects
column3: worms
column4: crustaceans
column5: molluscs and other invertebrates
column6: as well as various fish
column7: frogs
column8: reptiles
column9: small mammals and carrion. It may also probe into the soil with its long beak for invertebrates such as earthworms. It even sometimes feeds on seeds.Sacred ibises were observed to occasionally feed on the contents of pelican eggs broken by Egyptian vultures in the mixed colonies of the ibises
column10: cormorants
column11: pelicans and Abdim's storks at Lake Shala in Ethiopia. On Central Island in Lake Turkana sacred ibises were noted to incidentally eat Nile crocodile eggs excavated by Nile monitors. Most recently
column13: observations were reported from a large mixed colony on Bird Island (called Penguin Island in the article) in South Africa
column14: where 10
column15: 000 pairs of gannets nested
column16: together with 4800 pairs of Cape cormorant and other species such as gulls and jackass penguin. Within a period of 3 years
column17: a few specialized sacred ibis individuals out of the 400 that roosted on the island had fed on at least 152 eggs of the cormorant (other species were even more ovivorous).In a study of pellets and stomachs contents of nestlings in the Free State
column18: South Africa
column19: food is mostly reported to consist of frogs (mainly Amietia angolensis and Xenopus laevis)
column20: Potamonautes warreni crabs
column21: blow fly maggots
column22: Sphingidae caterpillars
column23: and adult beetles. During the first 10 days of life nestlings fed mainly on crabs and beetles
column24: and later mainly on Sphingidae caterpillars and more beetles. The breeding colony collected different (proportions of) prey the subsequent year.  The food of one one‚Äêmonth old nestlings at Lake Shala
column25: Ethiopia
column26: consisted of beetle larvae
column27: caterpillars and beetles. In France
column28: adult ibises fed largely on the invasive crayfish Procambarus clarkii
column29: for nestlings larvae of Eristalis species are important.In France
column30: they sometimes supplement their diet by feeding at rubbish tips in the winter.

column1: The most important predator of nestlings of the sacred ibis in Kenya is the African fish eagle

column1: This species was reported to be susceptible to avian botulism in a list of dead animals found around a man-made lake in South Africa which tested positive for the pathogen in the late 1960s and early 1970s. During a large scale mortality of Cape cormorants from avian cholera in 1991 in western South Africa
column2: small numbers of sacred ibis were killed. The new species Chlamydia ibidis was isolated from feral sacred ibis in France in 2013; it infected 6-7 of the 70 birds tested.In 1887
column3: the Italian scientist Corrado Parona reported a 3 cm Physaloptera species of nematode in the orbital cavity of a sacred ibis collected in Metemma
column4: Abyssinia (now Ethiopia) in 1882. He thought it was perhaps a new species
column5: as it differed morphologically from earlier seen worms. A single adult female was recovered
column6: and it has never been seen again. As the Physaloptera species infecting birds are generally parasites of the intestines of raptors; it might be an artefact
column7: or perhaps a misidentification
column8: or possibly a dead-end host infection. The digenean trematode Patagifer bilobus
column9: a fluke
column10: has been reported from sacred ibis in Sudan before 1949. It lives in the small intestine of this species
column11: among numerous other ibises

column13: and a few other waterfowl. It has a complicated life history involving three hosts: the eggs hatch in fresh water where they infect a ram's horn snail in which they multiply and produce cercariae
column14: which exit and encyst in a larger snail such as a Lymnaea
column15: waiting to be eaten by a bird.

column1: The species usually breeds once per year in the wet season. Breeding season is from March to August in Africa
column2: from April to May in Iraq. It builds a stick nest
column3: often in a baobab tree. The bird nests in tree colonies
column4: often with other large wading birds such as storks
column5: herons
column6: African spoonbills
column7: African darters
column8: cormorants. It may also form single-species groups on offshore islands or abandoned buildings. Large colonies consist of numerous subcolonies and can number 1000 birds.

column2: incubated by both parents for 21‚Äì29 days. After hatching
column3: one parent continuously stays at the nest for the first 7-days. Chicks fledge after 35‚Äì40 days and are independent after 44‚Äì48 days
column4: reaching sexual maturity 1‚Äì5 years after hatching.

column1: The African sacred ibis is classified as ""Least Concern"" by the IUCN. The global population is estimated at 200
column3: 000 individuals but appears to be decreasing. It is covered by the Agreement on the Conservation of African-Eurasian Migratory Waterbirds (AEWA).

column2: sacred ibis
column3: along with two other species in lesser numbers
column4: were commonly mummified by the Ancient Egyptians as a votive offering to the god Thoth. Thoth
column5: whose head is that of an ibis
column6: is the Ancient Egyptian god of wisdom and reason
column7: and thus of truth
column8: knowledge
column9: learning and study
column10: and writing and mathematics. The sacred ibis was considered the living incarnation of Thoth on earth. Pilgrims from all over Egypt brought thousands of ibis offerings to four or more main temples
column11: which at their peak mummified and buried thousands of birds a year in gigantic and ancient catacombs (one complex was in operation for 700 years). Eventually
column12: an estimated eight million birds were mummified and entombed by the Ancient Egyptians.It has long been thought
column13: to sustain sufficient numbers for the large and sometimes growing demand for sacrifices by the people
column14: dozens of ibis breeding farms (called ibiotropheia by Herodotus) were established
column15: initially throughout the regions of Egypt
column16: but later centralised around the main temples
column17: each producing around a thousand birds for mummies annually. An examination of the mitochondrial DNA disputes this and suggests that not only were wild birds caught and added to the captive flocks
column18: but that they provided the bulk of the supply. The mummified birds were often young and were usually killed by breaking their neck. The head and bill were often placed between the tail feathers
column19: and a piece of food was often placed in the bill (often a snail). The particulars of the mummification ritual often differed. The mummies could be stored in ceramic jars
column20: wooden chests or stone sarcophagi. Not all mummies contain whole birds; some (cheaper ones) contain only a leg
column21: an eggshell
column22: or even dried grass from the nest. Birds were given different burials according to their status; as pets
column23: offerings or holy individuals. Special sacred birds were afforded special mummification
column24: transported from their cities to the temples long after normal offerings were sourced from temple farm flocks
column25: and honoured with more luxurious burial. Different regions in Egypt observed slightly different practises regarding the ritual beliefs.Ibis mummification started by at least 1
column26: 100 BC and petered out by approximately 30 BC. Although the numbers of burials peaked at different times depending on the region and temple
column27: the rituals were most popular from the Late Period to the Ptolemaic Period.Mummified specimens of the sacred ibis were brought back to Europe by Napoleon's army
column28: where they became part of an early debate about evolution.According to Herodotus and Pliny the Elder the ibis was invoked against incursions of winged serpents. Herodotus wrote:

column1: There is a region moreover in Arabia

column3: to which place I came to inquire about the winged serpents: and when I came thither I saw bones of serpents and spines in quantity so great that it is impossible to make report of the number
column4: and there were heaps of spines
column5: some heaps large and others less large and others smaller still than these
column6: and these heaps were many in number.

column1: The region in which the spines are scattered upon the ground is of the nature of an entrance from a narrow mountain pass to a great plain
column2: which plain adjoins the plain of Egypt; and the story goes that at the beginning of spring winged serpents from Arabia fly towards Egypt
column3: and the birds called ibises meet them at the entrance of this country and do not suffer the serpents to go by but kill them. On account of this deed it is (say the Arabians) that the ibis has come to be greatly honored by the Egyptians
column4: and the Egyptians also agree that it is for this reason that they honor these birds.

Vespa velutina nigrithoraxhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian%20hornet"The Asian giant hornet (Vespa mandarinia)
column2: including the color form referred to as the Japanese giant hornet
column3: is the world's largest hornet. It is native to temperate and tropical East Asia
column4: South Asia
column5: Mainland Southeast Asia
column6: and parts of the Russian Far East. It was also found in the Pacific Northwest of North America in late 2019 with a few more additional sightings in 2020
column7: and nests found in 2021
column8: prompting concern that it could become an invasive species.Asian giant hornets prefer to live in low mountains and forests
column9: while almost completely avoiding plains and high-altitude climates. V. mandarinia creates nests by digging
column10: co-opting pre-existing tunnels dug by rodents
column11: or occupying spaces near rotted pine roots. It feeds primarily on larger insects
column12: colonies of other eusocial insects
column13: tree sap
column14: and honey from honey bee colonies. The hornet has a body length of 45 mm (1+3‚ÅÑ4 in)
column15: a wingspan around 75 mm (3 in)
column16: and a stinger 6 mm (1‚ÅÑ4 in) long
column17: which injects a large amount of potent venom.Although the scientific literature and official government sources continue to refer to this species by its established common name
column18: the mainstream media have taken to using the nickname ""murder hornet"". The species has been around since the Miocene as indicated by fossils found in Shanwang formation.

column1: V. mandarinia is a species in the genus Vespa
column2: which comprises all true hornets. Along with seven other species
column3: V. mandarinia is a part of the V. tropica species group
column4: defined by the single notch located on the apical margin of the seventh gastral sternum of the male. The most closely related species within the species group is V. soror. The triangular shape of the apical margin of the clypeus of the female is diagnostic
column5: the vertex of both species is enlarged
column6: and the shape of the apex of the aedeagus is distinct and similar. Division of the genus into subgenera has been attempted in the past
column7: but has been abandoned
column8: due to the anatomical similarity among species and because behavioral similarity is not associated with phylogeny.As of 2012
column9: three subspecies were recognized: V. m. mandarinia
column10: V. m. magnifica
column11: and V. m. nobilis. The former subspecies referred to as V. m. japonica has not been considered valid since 1997. The most recent revision in 2020 eliminated all of the subspecies rankings entirely
column12: with ""japonica""
column13: ""magnifica""
column14: and ""nobilis"" now relegated to informal non-taxonomic names for different color forms.

column2: the hornet's head is a light shade of orange and its antennae are brown with a yellow-orange base. Its eyes and ocelli are dark brown to black. V. mandarinia is distinguished from other hornets by its pronounced clypeus and large genae. Its orange mandible contains a black tooth that it uses for digging. The thorax is dark brown
column3: with two grey wings varying in span from 35 to 76 mm (1+3‚ÅÑ8 to 3 in). Its fore legs are brighter than the mid and hind legs. The base of the fore legs is darker than the rest. The abdomen alternates between bands of dark brown or black
column4: and a yellow-orange hue (consistent with its head color). The sixth segment is yellow. Its stinger is typically 6 mm (1‚ÅÑ4 in) long and delivers a potent venom that in cases of multiple hornets stinging simultaneously can kill a human.

column1: The queens are considerably larger than workers. Queens can exceed 50 mm (2 in)
column2: while workers are between 35 and 40 mm (1+1‚ÅÑ2 and 1+1‚ÅÑ2 in). The reproductive anatomy is consistent between the two
column3: but workers do not reproduce.

column2: and can attain 38 millimetres (1+1‚ÅÑ2 in) in length
column3: but lack stingers. This is a consistent feature among the Hymenoptera.

column1: Larvae spin a silk cocoon when they complete development and are ready to pupate. Larval silk proteins have a wide variety of potential applications due to their wide variety of potential morphologies
column2: including the native fiber form
column3: but also sponge
column4: film
column5: and gel.

column1: Reports of this species from other parts of the world appear to be erroneous identifications of other introduced hornet species

column3: V. velutina in Europe
column4: and the European hornet (V. crabro) in the eastern United States.The eastern cicada killer (Sphecius speciosus) also lives in the Eastern United States. It is a large digger wasp that can reach 2 inches (5.1 cm) in length
column5: and has also been mistaken for the Asian giant hornet.

column1: V. mandarinia is primarily a forest dweller. When it does live in urban landscapes

column3: V. mandarinia is highly associated with green space. It is the most dependent upon green space of the Vespa species (with V. analis the least). Extremely urbanized areas thus provide a refuge for V. analis
column4: whereas V. mandarinia ‚Äì its predator ‚Äì is entirely absent.

column2: with nests also discovered in neighboring Whatcom County
column3: Washington
column4: in the United States.

column3: Washington.

column6: Washington

column1: Three hornets were seen (and two killed) southeast of Blaine on 21 and 25 September 2020

column2: the Washington State Department of Agriculture announced that a nest was found 2.5 metres (8.3 ft) above ground in a cavity of a tree in Blaine
column3: with dozens of hornets entering and leaving. The nest was eradicated the next day
column4: including the immediate discovery and removal of about 100 hornets. After further analysis
column5: it was determined that the nest had contained about 500 live specimens
column6: including about 200 queens. Some of these specimens were sent to the Smithsonian Institution to become a part of the NMNH Biorepository permanent cryogenic collection. It was announced that several undiscovered live nests were also believed to exist within Washington State
column7: when considering the captures of individual hornets in Birch
column8: Blaine
column9: and Custer that were all relatively far from the discovered nest. However
column10: cautious optimism was expressed by officials saying that it might still be possible to eradicate the hornets before they can become established in the area. A Canadian official said that although individual specimens had been found in Canada and some nests were suspected to exist there
column11: the presence there seemed to be only in near-border regions
column12: and the center of the invasion seemed to be in Washington State.

column2: one individual was found in Abbotsford
column3: BC. As a result the BC government asked Abbotsford beekeepers and residents to report any sightings.

column2: a queen was found in Aldergrove
column3: BC.

column2: a nest was discovered in Whatcom County
column3: Washington near Blaine
column4: only 2 miles (3.2 km) from the nest WSDA eradicated in 2020. This nest was destroyed two weeks later on 25 August
column5: before it could produce new queens.

column2: two more nests were found near Blaine
column3: in the vicinity of the nest found in August
column4: and a ""potential sighting"" was reported from near Everson
column5: some 25 miles east of Blaine.A mitochondrial DNA analysis was performed to determine the maternal population(s) ancestral to the British Columbia and Washington introduced populations. The high dissimilarity between these two was similar to the mutual distances between each of the Chinese
column6: Japanese
column7: and Korean native populations suggesting the specimens collected in 2019 were from two different maternal populations
column8: Japanese in BC and South Korean in Washington. This suggests that two simultaneous introductions of the Asian giant hornet occurred in North America within about 80 km (50 mi) of one another within a few months.

column2: authorities in Washington asked members of the public to be alert and report any sightings of these hornets
column3: which are expected to become active in April if they are in the area. If they become established
column4: the hornets ""could decimate bee populations in the United States and establish such a deep presence that all hope for eradication could be lost."" A ""full-scale hunt"" for the species by the WSDA was then underway. Two assessment models of their potential to spread from their present location on the US‚ÄìCanada border suggested that they could spread northward into coastal British Columbia and Southeast Alaska
column5: and southward as far as southern Oregon. The USDA's Agricultural Research Service is engaged in lure/attractant development and molecular genetics research
column6: both as part of its normal research mission
column7: but also to further the near-term eradication goal in Washington.In 2020
column8: the United States Congress considered specific legislation to eradicate V. mandarinia including a proposal by the Interior Secretary
column9: the Fish and Wildlife Director
column10: and the other relevant agencies
column11: which has been introduced as an amendment to the appropriations omnibus. British Columbia Agriculture is prepared for a ""long fight"" lasting years
column12: if necessary. One advantage humans will have is the lack of diversity of such an invasive population ‚Äì leaving the hornets less prepared for novel environments and challenges.On June 4
column13: 2021 a dead
column14: desiccated male was found near Marysville
column15: Snohomish County
column16: Washington and reported to WSDA. Its different
column17: more reddish color form immediately suggested yet another parental population from the Japanese and Korean ones already known
column18: but DNA testing was needed. USDA APHIS (Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service) did the analysis and a few days later together with WSDA confirmed it was of a third
column19: unrelated population. The discovery of a male in June is ""perplexing"" given that the earliest male emergence in 2020 was July
column20: which was already earlier than normal for the home range. This and its desiccated state indicate it did not emerge in 2021 at all
column21: but is instead a dead specimen that had already emerged in a previous year.

column1: V. mandarinia nests in low mountain foothills and lowland forests. As a particularly dominant species
column2: no efforts are directed toward conserving V. mandarinia or its habitats
column3: as they are common in areas of low human disturbance. Unlike other species of Vespa
column4: V. mandarinia almost exclusively inhabits subterranean nests ‚Äì in 1978 it was still doubted that aerial nests were possible
column5: as Matsuura and Sakagami reported this to be unknown in Japan in 1973 and aerial nesting is still described as extremely rare in Japan
column6: and yet as of 2021 all nests in the invasive range have been aerial. In a study of 31 nests
column7: 25 were found around rotten pine roots
column8: and another study found only 9 of 56 nests above ground. Additionally
column9: rodents
column10: snakes
column11: or other burrowing animals previously made some of the tunnels. The depth of these nests was between 6 and 60 cm (2 and 24 in). The entrance at the ground surface varies in length from 2 to 60 cm (1 to 24 in) either horizontally
column12: inclined
column13: or vertically. The queens that found the nest prefer narrow cavities.Nests of V. mandarinia typically lack a developed envelope. During the initial stages of development
column14: the envelope is in an inverted-bowl shape. As the nest develops
column15: one to three rough sheets of combs are created. Often
column16: single primordial combs are created simultaneously and then fused into a single comb.A system of one main pillar and secondary pillars connects the combs. Nests usually have four to seven combs. The top comb is abandoned after summer and left to rot. The largest comb is at the middle to bottom portion of the nest. The largest combs created by V. mandarinia measured 49.5 by 45.5 cm (19+1‚ÅÑ2 by 18 in) with 1
column17: 192 cells (no obstacles
column18: circular) and 61.0 by 48.0 cm (24 by 19 in) (elliptical; wrapped around a root system).

column1: The nesting cycle of V. mandarinia is fairly consistent with that of other eusocial insects. Six phases occur in each cycle.

Inseminated and uninseminated queens enter hibernation following a cycle. They first appear in early to mid-April and begin feeding on the sap of Quercus (oak) trees. Although this timing is consistent among hornets
column2: V. mandarinia dominates the order
column3: receiving preference for premium sap sources. Among the V. mandarinia queens is a dominance hierarchy. The top-ranked queen begins feeding
column4: while the other queens form a circle around her. Once the top queen finishes
column5: the second-highest-ranking queen feeds. This process repeats until the last queen feeds at a poor hour.

column2: cooperative
column3: and polyethic periods ===

column1: Inseminated queens start to search for nesting sites in late April. The uninseminated queens do not search for nests
column2: since their ovaries never fully develop. They continue to feed
column3: but then disappear in early July.

column1: An inseminated queen begins to create relatively small cells in which she raises around 40 small workers. Workers do not begin to work outside of the hive until July. Queens participate in activities outside the hive until mid-July
column2: when they stay inside the nest and allow workers to do extranidal activities. Early August marks a fully developed nest
column3: containing three combs holding 500 cells and 100 workers. After mid-September
column4: no more eggs are laid and the focus shifts to caring for larvae. The queens die in late October.

column1: Males and new queens take on their responsibilities in mid-September and mid-October
column2: respectively. During this time
column3: their body color becomes intense and the weights of the queens increase about 20%. Once the males and queens leave the nest
column4: they do not return. In V. mandarinia
column5: males wait outside the nest entrance until the queens emerge
column6: when males intercept them in midair
column7: bring them to the ground
column8: and copulate from 8 to 45 seconds. After this episode
column9: the males return to the entrance for a second chance
column10: while the now-mated queens leave to hibernate. Many queens (up to 65%) attempt to fight off the males and leave unfertilized
column11: at least temporarily. After this episode
column12: pre-hibernating queens are found in moist
column13: subterranean habitats.

column2: workers shift their focus from protein and animal foods to carbohydrates. The last sexed individuals to emerge may die of starvation.

column1: The stinger of the Asian giant hornet is about 6 mm (1‚ÅÑ4 in) long
column2: which is about 4.5 mm (3‚ÅÑ16 in) longer than that of a honeybee.

column1: That stinger injects an especially potent venom that contains
column2: like many bee and wasp venoms
column3: a cytolytic peptide (specifically
column4: a mastoparan) that can damage tissue by stimulating phospholipase action
column5: in addition to its own phospholipase. Masato Ono
column6: an entomologist at Tamagawa University
column7: described the sensation of being stung as feeling ""like a hot nail being driven into my leg"". Besides using their stingers to inject venom
column8: Asian giant hornets are apparently able to spray venom into a person's eyes under certain circumstances
column9: with one report in 2020 from Japan of long-term damage
column10: though the exact extent of actual visual impairment still remains unassessed.The venom contains a neurotoxin called mandaratoxin
column11: a single-chain polypeptide with a molecular weight around 20 kDa. While a single wasp cannot inject a lethal dose
column12: multiple stings can be lethal even to people who are not allergic if the dose is sufficient
column13: and allergy to the venom greatly increases the risk of death. Tests involving mice found that the venom falls short of being the most lethal of all wasp venoms
column14: having an LD50 of 4.0 mg/kg. (In comparison
column15: the deadliest wasp venom (at least to laboratory mice) by weight belongs to V. luctuosa at 1.6 mg/kg.) The potency of the V. mandarinia sting is due
column16: rather
column17: to the relatively large amount of venom injected.

column1: Evidence is insufficient to believe that prophylactic immunotherapy for the venom of other Vespidae will prevent allergic reaction to V. mandarinia venom
column2: because of wide differences in venom chemistry.
van der Vecht was under the impression humans in the native range lived in constant fear of V. mandarinia and Iwata reported in 1976 that research and removal were hampered by its attacks. Since 2001
column3: the yearly human death toll caused by stings of bees
column4: wasps
column5: and hornets in Japan has been ranging between 12 and 26. Since this number also includes deaths caused by bees
column6: wasps
column7: and other hornet species
column8: the number of deaths caused by Asian giant hornets is likely to be much lower.Advice in China is that people stung more than 10 times should seek medical help
column9: and require emergency treatment for more than 30 stings. The stings can cause kidney failure. In 2013
column10: stings by Asian giant hornets killed 41 people and injured more than 1
column11: 600 people in Shaanxi
column12: China.One source claims that most people who sought medical attention for a sting entered anaphylaxis before or during the medical session
column13: and that deaths from envenomation are primarily related to anaphylactic shock or cardiac arrest. Either way
column14: certainly some venom fractions are immunogenic and some are cardiotoxic to mammals. Deaths have occurred as a result of multiple organ failure
column15: typically after a large number of stings. Sting victims who experience life-threatening organ failure commonly exhibit signs of skin hemorrhaging and necrosis
column16: though in patients without organ failure
column17: these symptoms are very rare. The two likely reasons for skin hemorrhaging and necrosis are an inability to effectively neutralize the venom
column18: or unusually potent venom toxicity for that set of stings. In either case
column19: for a small number of victims
column20: these stings lead to multiple organ injury. While not all such victims displayed lesions or necrosis
column21: a strong correlation existed between the number of stings and the severity of injury. Those who died
column22: on average
column23: were stung 59 times (with a standard error of 12)
column24: while those who survived suffered only
column25: on average
column26: 28 stings (with a standard error of four
column27: and a p = 0.01).

column1: The strepsipteran Xenos moutoni is a common parasite among Vespa species. In a study of parasites among species of Vespa
column2: 4.3% of V. mandarinia females were parasitized. Males were not stylopized (parasitization by stylopid strepsipterans
column3: such as X. moutoni) at all. The major consequence of being parasitized is the inability to reproduce
column4: and stylopized queens follow the same fate as uninseminated queens. They do not search for an area to create a new colony and feed on sap until early July
column5: when they disappear. In other species of Vespa
column6: males also have a chance of being stylopized. The consequences between the two sexes are similar
column7: as neither sex is able to reproduce.

column1: V. mandarinia uses both visual and chemical cues as a means of navigating itself and others to the desired location. Scent marking was discussed as a way for hornets to direct other members of the colony to a food source. Even with antennae damage
column2: V. mandarinia was able to navigate itself. It was unable to find its destination only when vision impairment was induced. This implies that while chemical signaling is important
column3: visual cues play an equally important role in guiding individuals. Other behaviors include the formation of a ""royal court"" consisting of workers that lick and bite the queen
column4: thereby ingesting her pheromones.

column1: These pheromones could directly communicate between the queen and her court or indirectly between her court and other workers due to the ingested pheromones. This is merely speculation
column2: as no direct evidence has been collected to suggest the latter. V. mandarinia communicates acoustically
column3: as well. When larvae are hungry
column4: they scrape their mandibles against the walls of the cell. Furthermore
column5: adult hornets click their mandibles as a warning to other creatures that encroach upon their territories.

column1: V. mandarinia is the only species of social wasp known to apply a scent to direct its colony to a food source. The hornet secretes the chemical from the sixth sternal gland
column2: also known as  van der Vecht's gland. This behavior is observed during autumnal raids after the hornets begin hunting in groups instead of individually. The ability to apply scents may have arisen because the Asian giant hornet relies heavily on honey bee colonies as its main food source. A single hornet is unable to take on an entire colony of honey bees because species such as Apis cerana have a well-organized defense mechanism; the honey bees swarm one wasp and flutter their wings to heat up the hornet and raise carbon dioxide to a lethal level. So
column3: organized attacks are much more effective and easily devastate a colony of tens of thousands of honey bees.

column1: In an experiment observing four different species of Vespa (V. ducalis
column2: V. crabro
column3: V. analis
column4: and V. mandarinia)
column5: V. mandarinia was the dominant species. Multiple parameters were set to determine this. The first set parameter observed interaction-mediated departures
column6: which are defined as scenarios wherein one species leaves its position due to the arrival of a more dominant individual. The proportion of interaction-mediated departures was the lowest for V. mandarinia. Another measured parameter was attempted patch entry. Over the observed time
column7: conspecifics (interactions with the same species) resulted in refused entry far more than heterospecifics (interactions with different species). Lastly
column8: when feeding at sap flows
column9: fights between these hornets
column10: Pseudotorynorrhina japonica
column11: Neope goschkevitschii
column12: and Lethe sicelis were observed
column13: and once more V. mandarinia was the most dominant species. In 57 separate fights
column14: one loss was observed to Neope goschkevitschii
column15: giving V. mandarinia a win rate of 98.3%. Based on interaction-mediated departures
column16: attempted patch entry
column17: and interspecific fights
column18: V. mandarinia is the most dominant Vespa species.

column1: The Asian giant hornet is intensely predatory; it hunts medium- to large-sized insects
column2: such as bees
column3: other hornet species
column4: and mantises. The latter are favored targets in late summer and fall. Large insects such as mantises are key protein sources to feed queen and drone larvae. Workers forage to feed their larvae
column5: and since their prey can include crop pests
column6: the hornets are sometimes regarded as beneficial.

column1: This hornet often attacks both colonies of other Vespa species (V. simillima being the usual prey species) and honey bee hives to obtain the adults
column2: pupae
column3: and larvae as food for their own larvae; sometimes
column4: they also cannibalize each other's colonies. A single scout
column5: sometimes two or three
column6: cautiously approaches the hive
column7: producing pheromones to lead its nest-mates to the hive. The hornets can devastate a colony of honey bees
column8: especially if it is the introduced western honey bee; a single hornet can kill as many as 40 bees per minute due to its large mandibles
column9: which can quickly strike and decapitate prey. The honey bees' stings are ineffective because the hornets are five times their size and heavily armored. Only a few hornets (under 50) can exterminate a colony of tens of thousands of bees in a few hours. The hornets can fly up to 100 km (60 mi) in a single day
column10: at speeds up to 40 km/h (25 mph). The smaller Asian hornet similarly preys on honey bees
column11: and has been spreading throughout Europe.

column2: but not adults
column3: can digest solid protein; the adult hornets can only drink the juices of their victims
column4: and they chew their prey into a paste to feed to their larvae. The workers dismember the bodies of their prey to return only the most nutrient-rich body parts
column5: such as flight muscles
column6: to the nest. Larvae of predatory social vespids generally (not just Vespa) secrete a clear liquid
column7: sometimes referred to as Vespa amino acid mixture
column8: the exact amino acid composition of which varies considerably from species to species
column9: and which they produce to feed the adults on demand.

column1: Beekeepers in Japan attempted to introduce western honey bees (Apis mellifera) for the sake of their high productivity. Western honey bees have no innate defense against the hornets
column2: which can rapidly destroy their colonies
column3: Kakugo virus infection
column4: though
column5: may provide an extrinsic defence. Although a handful of Asian giant hornets can easily defeat the uncoordinated defenses of a western honey bee colony
column6: the Japanese honey bee (Apis cerana japonica) has an effective strategy. When a hornet scout locates and approaches a Japanese honey bee hive
column7: she emits specific pheromonal hunting signals. When the Japanese honey bees detect these pheromones
column8: 100 or so gather near the entrance of the nest and set up a trap
column9: keeping the entrance open. This permits the hornet to enter the hive. As the hornet enters
column10: a mob of hundreds of bees surrounds it in a ball
column11: completely covering it and preventing it from reacting effectively. The bees violently vibrate their flight muscles in much the same way as they do to heat the hive in cold conditions. This raises the temperature in the ball to the critical temperature of 46 ¬∞C (115 ¬∞F). In addition
column12: the exertions of the honey bees raise the level of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the ball. At that concentration of CO2
column13: they can tolerate up to 50 ¬∞C (122 ¬∞F)
column14: but the hornet cannot survive the combination of high temperature and high carbon dioxide level. Some honey bees do die along with the intruder
column15: much as happens when they attack other intruders with their stings
column16: but by killing the hornet scout
column17: they prevent it from summoning reinforcements that would wipe out the entire colony.Detailed research suggests this account of the behavior of the honey bees and a few species of hornets is incomplete and that the honey bees and the predators are developing strategies to avoid expensive and mutually unprofitable conflict. Instead
column18: when honey bees detect scouting hornets
column19: they transmit an ""I see you"" signal that commonly warns off the predator. Another defence used by Apis cerana is speeding up dramatically when returning to the colony
column20: to avoid midair attacks.

column1: V. mandarinia is among the diurnal pollinators of the obligate plant parasite
column2: the plant Mitrastemon yamamotoi.
six different methods were used to control hornets in Japan; these methods decrease damage done by V. mandarinia.

column1: Hornets are crushed with wooden sticks with flat heads. Hornets do not counterattack when they are in the bee-hunting phase or the hive-attack phase (""slaughter"")
column2: but they aggressively guard a beehive once they kill the defenders and occupy it. The biggest expenditure in this method is time
column3: as the process is inefficient.

column1: Applying poisons or fires at night is an effective way of exterminating a colony. The most difficult part about this tactic is finding the subterranean nests. The most common method of discovering nests is giving a piece of frog or fish meat attached to a cotton ball to a wasp and following it back to its nest. With V. mandarinia
column2: this is particularly difficult considering its common home flight radius of 1‚Äì2 kilometres (0.62‚Äì1.24 mi). V. mandarinia travels up to 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) away from the nest.For the rare nest that is up in a tree
column3: wrapping the tree in plastic and vacuuming the hornets out is used.

column1: Bait traps can be placed in apiaries. The system consists of multiple compartments that direct the hornet into a one-sided hole which is difficult to return through once it is in the cul-de-sac compartment
column2: an area located at the top of the box from which honey bees can escape through a mesh opening
column3: but wasps cannot due to their large size. Baits used to attract the hornets include a diluted millet jelly solution or a crude sugar solution with a mixture of intoxicants
column4: vinegar
column5: or fruit essence.The WSDA has been using plastic bottle traps
column6: baited with fruit juice and added alcohol. The alcohol is used because it repels bees
column7: but not V. mandarinia
column8: thus reducing the bycatch.

column1: Hornets at the apiary are captured and fed a sugar solution or bee that has been poisoned with malathion. The toxin is expected to spread through trophallaxis. This method is good in principle
column2: but has not been tested extensively.

column1: The trap is attached to the front of beehives. The effectiveness of the trap is determined by its ability to capture hornets while allowing honey bees to escape easily. The hornet enters the trap and catches a bee. When it tries to fly back through the entrance of the hive
column2: it hits the front of the trap. The hornet flies upwards to escape and enters the capture chamber
column3: where the hornets are left to die. Some hornets find a way to escape the trap through the front
column4: so these traps can be very inefficient.

column1: As explained in the trapping section
column2: if met by resistance
column3: hornets lose the urge to attack and instead retreat. Different measures of resistance include weeds
column4: wire
column5: or fishing nets or limiting the passage size so only honey bees can make it through. Experienced hornets catch on and eventually stay on these traps
column6: awaiting the arrival of bees. The best method of controlling hornets is to combine protective screens with traps.

column2: the nests are excavated and the larvae are considered a delicacy when fried. In the central Ch≈´bu region
column3: these wasps are sometimes eaten as snacks or an ingredient in drinks. The grubs are often preserved in jars
column4: pan-fried or steamed with rice to make a savory dish called hebo-gohan. The adults are fried on skewers
column5: stinger and all
column6: until the body becomes crunchy.
