Procambarus fallax f. virginalishttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marbled%20crayfish"The marbled crayfish or Marmorkrebs (Procambarus virginalis)
column2: is a parthenogenetic crayfish that was discovered in the pet trade in Germany in 1995. Marbled crayfish are closely related to the ""slough crayfish""
column3: Procambarus fallax
column4: which is widely distributed across Florida. No natural populations of marbled crayfish are known. Information provided by one of the original pet traders as to where the marbled crayfish originated was deemed ""totally confusing and unreliable"". The informal name Marmorkrebs is German for ""marbled crayfish"".

column1: Marbled crayfish are the only known decapod crustaceans to reproduce only by parthenogenesis. All individuals are female
column2: and the offspring are genetically identical to the parent. Marbled crayfish are triploid animals with 276 chromosomes
column3: which may be the main reason for their parthenogenetic reproduction. It is hypothesized that marbled crayfish originated from an error in meiosis resulting in a diploid gamete
column4: which was then fertilized and created a viable triploid individual in a single generation. Marbled crayfish are thus a model for the rapid generation of species. Unlike other parthenogenetic organisms
column5: the marbled crayfish is a relatively young species; it was discovered in 1995.Because marbled crayfish are genetically identical
column6: easy to care for
column7: and reproduce at high rates
column8: they are a potential model organism
column9: particularly for studying development. A major drawback
column10: however
column11: is the long generation time (several months) compared to other research organisms.The marbled crayfish genome was sequenced in 2018
column12: which provides an essential foundation for further research.

column1: Marbled crayfish have caused concern as a potential invasive species because only a single individual is needed to establish a new population
column2: and they can reproduce at high rates. Marbled crayfish are also a known carrier of a crayfish plague pathogen
column3: Aphanomyces astaci. Marbled crayfish inhabit freshwater environments
column4: and have not successfully invaded ecosystems with higher salinity levels due to their reduced ability to reproduce and grow. However
column5: it has been proven that they can adjust to increasing saline environments
column6: which may allow for their further expansion.They have since been introduced into natural ecosystems on four continents. They have been found in the wild in the following countries:

column1: While initial reports of marbled crayfish in the wild in Europe consisted of only single individuals
column2: the number of European countries reporting populations of marbled crayfish is rising.In Europe
column3: the marbled crayfish is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column4: bred
column5: transported
column6: commercialized
column7: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.The Madagascar population has grown rapidly and is estimated to be in the millions
column8: with their geographical distribution having increased 100-fold from 2007 to 2017
column9: causing concern among local authorities.

column1: Marbled crayfish are one of the most widely distributed species of crayfish in the international pet trade and release from aquariums has likely been the main source of unwanted introductions. Concerns about the potential damage from their introduction have prompted several jurisdictions to regulate ownership of marbled crayfish.
The European Union instituted ""a total ban on the possession
column2: trade
column3: transport
column4: production and release of these species [including the marbled crayfish] in the wild"" in 2016.Japan banned most North American crayfish species
column5: including marbled crayfish
column6: in 2020.Marbled crayfish are prohibited in the American states of Idaho
column7: Missouri
column8: Tennessee
column9: and Michigan
column10: Maryland
column11: and the Canadian province of Saskatchewan.

column2: commonly referred to as Water primrose
column3: is an aquatic plant of the order Myrtales.It is closely related and easily confused with Ludwigia hexapetala. The two species can be distinguished at a chromosomal level
column4: because L. grandiflora is hexaploid and L. hexapetala is decaploid. However
column5: they can be distinguished morphologically. L. grandiflora has villous hairs
column6: smaller flowers and smaller pollen grains. Some authorities consider that these differences are too slight to consider these different species and so separate these taxa as two varieties or two subspecies.

column1: Ludwigia grandiflora has been listed on the List of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern since 2016 and in the United States it is on the South Carolina State-listed Noxious Weed list. It out-competes other plants by forming dense mats at the margins and in ponds. It is introduced to warm temperate areas of North America
column2: Japan and Europe and has formed large stable populations
column3: particularly in France.

column2: and does
column3: produce viable seed
column4: but it is also highly effective at vegetative reproduction and apparently recruitment of new plants from seed is low. The large showy flowers attract a wide variety of insects. A study in Belgium
column5: where L. grandiflora is introduced
column6: showed that the flowers are visited by a wide variety of insects including bees
column7: Lepidoptera
column8: beetles and hoverflies.

column1: Trachemys scriptahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pond%20slider"The pond slider (Trachemys scripta) is a species of common
column2: medium-sized
column3: semiaquatic turtle. Three subspecies are described
column4: the most recognizable of which is the red-eared slider (T. s. elegans)
column5: which is popular in the pet trade and has been introduced to other parts of the world by people releasing it to the wild. Hatchling and juvenile pond sliders have a greenish upper shell (carapace)
column6: yellow bottom shell (plastron)
column7: and green and yellow stripes and markings on their skin. These patterns and colors in the skin and shell fade with age until the carapace is a muted olive green to orange brown or brown and the plastron is a dull yellow or darker. Some sliders become almost black with few visible markings.

column1: The carapace is oval with a bit of rounding and a central crest with knobs
column2: but these features soften and fade with age
column3: adults being smoother and flatter. For determining an adult slider's sex
column4: males typically have much longer front claws than adult females
column5: while females usually have shorter
column6: more slender tails than males. Their lifespans range from 20 to 50 years.

column1: The origin of the name slider stems from the behavior of these turtles when startled. Groups of sliders
column2: sometimes quite large
column3: as well as many other types of less abundant freshwater turtles
column4: are often seen basking and sunning on logs
column5: branches
column6: and vegetation at or even well above the water's surface
column7: but they readily and quickly scramble if they sense danger
column8: shooting back in and darting away to safety underwater.

column1: Pond sliders are native to the south-central and southeastern United States and northern Mexico.

column2: many pond sliders were captured for sale. In the 1950s
column3: millions of turtles were being farmed and shipped abroad as part of the pet trade.

column1: These turtles often compete with native species for food
column2: habitat
column3: and other resources. Eventually
column4: they bully many native species out of basking sites
column5: where sunlight (and warmth) is available for the species. When basking
column6: pond sliders commonly bask on birds' nests
column7: thereby killing the eggs. They also prey on young birds.

column1: Turtles that were raised in captivity can develop diseases that are unfamiliar to native species
column2: which can be harmful. Turtles raised in captivity are often released because they become too much to handle or grow bigger than expected. Not uncommonly
column3: they also escape.

column1: Conservationists have warned owners of turtles to not release them into the wild. Many states also have passed legislation to control the possession and release of pond sliders. Two states have completely banned the sale of these turtles.

column2: T. script is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: Myriophyllum aquaticumhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myriophyllum%20aquaticum"Myriophyllum aquaticum is a flowering plant
column2: a vascular dicot
column3: commonly called parrot's-feather and parrot feather watermilfoil.

column1: Parrot feather is a perennial plant. Parrot feather gets its name from its feather-like leaves that are arranged around the stem in whorls of four to six. The emergent stems and leaves are the most distinctive trait of parrot feather
column2: as they can grow up to a foot above the water surface and look almost like small fir trees. The woody emergent stems grow over 5 feet long and will extend to the bank and shore. Attached to the Parrot feather are pinkish-white flowers that extend approximately 1/16 inches long. As the water warms in the spring
column3: parrot feather begins to flourish. Most plants flower in the spring; however
column4: some also flower in the fall. Almost all plants of this species are female
column5: in fact there are no male plants found outside of South America. Seeds are not produced in any North American plants. Parrot feather reproduces asexually. New plants grow from fragments of already rooted plants. The plant has whorls of feathery blue-green to waxy gray-green leaves deeply cut into many narrow lobes.

column1: Kasselmann recently described a new variety
column2: M. aquaticum var. santacatarinense
column3: which distinguishes itself from the typical variety by its more stiff and robust habitus and pinnae that are fewer and broader.

column1: Parrot feather is native to the Amazon River in South America
column2: but it can now be found on every continent except Antarctica. It is thought that this plant was introduced to North America around the late 1800s. It was first discovered in the United States in the 1890s in Washington
column3: D.C. Parrot's feather typically grows in freshwater streams
column4: ponds
column5: lakes
column6: rivers
column7: and canals that have a high nutrient content. During the 20th century it colonized areas in South Africa
column8: Japan
column9: England
column10: New Zealand
column11: and Australia. As it prefers a warmer climate
column12: it is chiefly found in the southern parts of the United States.

column1: Parrot feather is now used for indoor and outdoor aquatic use. It is a popular plant in aquatic gardens. It spreads easily and has become an invasive species and a noxious weed in many areas. The plant can be introduced to new areas when sections of its rhizome are dug up and moved. In Florida in the United States
column2: flea beetles have been found to use parrot feather as a host for their larvae.

column1: Because of its attractiveness and ease of cultivation
column2: parrot feather has been introduced worldwide for use in indoor and outdoor aquaria. It is also a popular aquatic garden plant. However
column3: it has escaped cultivation and spread via plant fragments and intentional plantings. While parrot feather may provide cover for some aquatic organisms
column4: it can seriously change the physical and chemical characteristics of lakes and streams. The parrot feather grows abundantly
column5: shades out naturally occurring algae
column6: and clogs irrigation ducts and canals. The Parrot feather typically exist in bundles and extend out of the water. In large numbers
column7: the plants make a dense mat on the water's surface. Because of this
column8: they shade the water from sunlight and cause native plants to die because of light deficiency. The organisms that feed on the native plants can die off due to starvation. The dense mats also cause problems for recreation. Swimmers and boat propellors can become entangled. The mats are also a breeding ground for mosquitos.

column1: Herbicides have not been found very useful in controlling its growth
column2: partly because the plant has a waxy cuticle that seals out the poison. Cutting and chopping can actually promote the plant's spread. In the U.S. states of Alabama
column3: Connecticut
column4: Massachusetts
column5: Maine
column6: Vermont
column7: and Washington
column8: parrot feather is a declared noxious weed and is therefore banned from sale.The two main solutions to manage this aquatic nuisance is physically removing the plant and or using herbicides.The physical aspects of removal are such acts of cutting
column9: harvesting
column10: and rotovation (underwater rototilling). These methods see best results only when the extent of the infestation has taken over all available niches. Best results are seen this way due to the availability of space as compared to rapid growth. Using physical control methods while the plant is still invading will tend to enhance its rate of spread.Another method of controlling Parrots feather is by the usage of herbicides. The herbicides are effective to the plant part exposed above water. The plant parts beneath the water never come fully into contact with the herbicides and are therefore washed away. Herbicides are most effective when applied to young growing plants. They should be applied repeatedly to show maximum results. M. aquaticum is more difficult to control with herbicides than other aquatic species. The leaves are protected by a thick waxy coating
column11: and in order for herbicides to penetrate the leaves
column12: surfactants must be added; however
column13: herbicides may impact non-target native plants or animals.In the United Kingdom
column14: this plant is one of five introduced aquatic plants which are to be banned from sale from April 2014. This is the first ban of its kind in the country.In Europe
column15: Parrot feather is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column16: cultivated
column17: transported
column18: commercialized
column19: planted
column20: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

Persicaria perfoliatahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persicaria%20perfoliata"Persicaria perfoliata (basionym Polygonum perfoliatum) is a species of flowering plant in the buckwheat family. Common names include mile-a-minute
column2: devil's tail
column3: giant climbing tearthumb
column4: and Asiatic tearthumb. It is a trailing herbaceous annual vine with barbed stems and triangular leaves. It is native to most of temperate and tropical eastern Asia
column5: occurring from eastern Russia and Japan in the north
column6: and the range extending to the Philippines and India in the south. P. perfoliata is an aggressive
column7: highly invasive weed.In Europe
column8: Persicaria perfoliata is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column9: cultivated
column10: transported
column11: commercialized
column12: planted
column13: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: Persicaria perfoliata has a reddish stem that is armed with downward pointing hooks or barbs which are also present on the underside of the leaf blades. The light green leaves are shaped like an equilateral (equal-sided) triangle and alternate along the narrow
column2: delicate stems. Distinctive circular
column3: cup-shaped leafy structures
column4: called ochreas
column5: surround the stem at intervals. Flower buds
column6: and later flowers and fruits
column7: emerge from within the ocreas. Flowers are small
column8: white and generally inconspicuous. The edible fruits are attractive
column9: metallic blue and segmented
column10: each segment containing a single glossy
column11: black or reddish-black seed.

column1: Persicaria perfoliata prefers warm open areas
column2: along the edges of woods
column3: wetlands
column4: stream banks
column5: and roadsides
column6: and uncultivated open fields
column7: resulting from both natural and human causes
column8: dense wooded areas where the overstory has opened up increasing the sunlight to the forest floor. Natural areas such as stream banks
column9: parks
column10: open space
column11: road shoulders
column12: forest edges and fence lines are all typical areas to find P. perfoliata. It also occurs in environments that are extremely wet with poor soil structure.

column1: Available light and soil moisture are both integral to the successful colonization of this species. It will tolerate shade for a part of the day
column2: but needs a good percentage
column3: 63-100% of the available light. The ability of P. perfoliata to attach to other plants with its recurved barbs and climb over the plants to reach an area of high light intensity is a key to its survival.  It can survive in areas with relatively low soil moisture
column4: but demonstrates a preference for high soil moisture.

column1: Persicaria perfoliata is an edible species. Its tender leaves and shoots can be eaten raw or cooked as a salad green or vegetable and its fruit is sweet and can be eaten fresh.

column2: Persicaria perfoliata is known as gangbangui (Chinese: Êù†ÊùøÂΩí; pinyin: gƒÅngb«éng≈´i)
column3: and is thought to be useful for various remedies in herbal medicine. It can also be used as a fiber or used in rope making.

column1: The first records of Persicaria perfoliata in North America are from Portland
column2: Oregon (1890)
column3: and Beltsville
column4: Maryland (1937). Both of these sites were eliminated or did not establish permanent populations of the species. However
column5: the introduction of P. perfoliata somewhere between the late 1930s and 1946 to a nursery site in Stewartstown
column6: York County
column7: Pennsylvania
column8: produced a population of this plant that did become established in the wild. It is speculated that the seed was spread with Rhododendron stock. Starting in 2004
column9: the weevil Rhinoncomimus latipes has been introduced in eastern US to control this plant
column10: with certain amount of success.

column1: Persicaria perfoliata is primarily a self-pollinating plant (supported by its inconspicuous
column2: closed flowers with little scent)
column3: with occasional outcrossing. Fruits and viable seeds are produced without assistance from pollinators. Vegetative propagation from roots has not been successful for this plant. It is a very tender annual
column4: withering with a slight frost
column5: and reproduces successfully until the first frost. P. perfoliata is a prolific seeder
column6: producing many seeds on a single plant over a long season
column7: from June until October in Virginia
column8: and a slightly shorter season in more northern geographic areas. It can cover as much as 30 feet (9.1 m) in a single season
column9: maybe even more in the southern United States.

column1: Birds are probably the primary long-distance dispersal agents of P. perfoliata. Transport of seeds short distances by native ant species has been observed. This activity is probably encouraged by the presence of a tiny white food body (elaiosome) on the tip of the seed that may be attractive to the ants. These seed-carrying ants may play an important role in the survival and germination of the seeds of P. perfoliata. Local bird populations are important for dispersal under utility lines
column2: bird feeders
column3: fence lines and other perching locations. Other animals observed eating its fruits are chipmunks
column4: squirrel and deer.

column1: Water is also an important mode of dispersal. Its fruits can remain buoyant for 7‚Äì9 days
column2: an important advantage for dispersing seed long distances in stream and river environments. The long vines frequently hang over waterways
column3: allowing fruits that detach to be carried away in the water current.

column2: also known as the eastern fox squirrel or Bryant's fox squirrel
column3: is the largest species of tree squirrel native to North America. Despite the differences in size and coloration
column4: it is sometimes mistaken for American red squirrels or eastern gray squirrels in areas where the species co-exist.

column1: The squirrel's total length measures 20 to 30 in (50.8 to 76.2 cm)
column2: with a body length of 10 to 15 in (25.4 to 38.1 cm) and a similar tail length. They range in weight from 1.0 to 2.5 pounds (453.6 to 1
column3: 134.0 g). There is no sexual dimorphism in size or appearance. Individuals tend to be smaller in the west. There are three distinct geographical phases in coloration: In most areas the animal's upper body is brown-grey to brown-yellow with a typically brownish-orange underside
column4: while in eastern regions such as the Appalachians there are more strikingly-patterned dark brown and black squirrels with white bands on the face and tail. In the south are isolated communities with uniform black coats. To help with climbing
column5: the squirrels have sharp claws
column6: developed extensors of digits and flexors of forearms
column7: and abdominal musculature. Fox squirrels have excellent vision and well-developed senses of hearing and smell. They use scent marking to communicate with other fox squirrels. ""Fox squirrels also have several sets of vibrissae
column8: hairs or whiskers that are used as touch receptors to sense the environment. These are found above and below their eyes
column9: on their chin and nose
column10: and on each forearm."" The dental formula of S. niger is 1.0.1.31.0.1.3‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ2 = 20.

column1: The fox squirrel's natural range extends through most of the eastern United States
column2: north into the southern prairie provinces of Canada
column3: and west to the Dakotas
column4: Colorado
column5: and Texas. They are absent (except for vagrants) in New England
column6: New Jersey
column7: most of New York
column8: northern and eastern Pennsylvania
column9: Ontario
column10: Quebec
column11: and the Atlantic provinces of Canada. They have been introduced to both northern and southern California
column12: Oregon
column13: Idaho
column14: Montana
column15: Washington
column16: and New Mexico
column17: as well as Ontario and British Columbia in Canada. While very versatile in their habitat choices
column18: fox squirrels are most often found in forest patches of 40 hectares or less with an open understory
column19: or in urban neighborhoods with trees. They thrive best among oak
column20: hickory
column21: walnut
column22: pecan and pine trees
column23: storing their nuts for winter. Western range extensions in Great Plains regions such as Kansas are associated with riverine corridors of cottonwood. A subspecies native to several eastern US states is the Delmarva fox squirrel (S. n. cinereus).

column2: Sciurus niger is included since 2016 in the list of Invasive Alien Species of Union concern (the Union list). This implies that this species cannot be imported
column3: bred
column4: transported
column5: commercialized
column6: or intentionally released into the environment in the whole of the European Union.

column1: Fox squirrels are most abundant in open forest stands with little understory vegetation; they are not found in stands with dense undergrowth. Ideal habitat is small stands of large trees interspersed with agricultural land. The size and spacing of pines and oaks are among the important features of fox squirrel habitat. The actual species of pines and oaks themselves may not always be a major consideration in defining fox squirrel habitat. Fox squirrels are often observed foraging on the ground several hundred meters from the nearest woodlot. Fox squirrels also commonly occupy forest edge habitat.Fox squirrels have two types of shelters: leaf nests (dreys) and tree dens. They may have two tree cavity homes or a tree cavity and a leaf nest. Tree dens are preferred over leaf nests during the winter and for raising young. When den trees are scarce
column2: leaf nests are used year-round. Leaf nests are built during the summer months in forks of deciduous trees about 30 feet (9 m) above the ground. Fox squirrels use natural cavities and crotches (forked branches of a tree) as tree dens. Den trees in Ohio had an average diameter at breast height (d.b.h.) of 21 inches (53 cm) and were an average of 58.6 yards (53.6 m) from the nearest woodland border. About 88% of den trees in eastern Texas had an average d.b.h. of 12 inches (30 cm) or more. Dens are usually 6 inches (15 cm) wide and 14‚Äì16 inches (36‚Äì41 cm) inches deep. Den openings are generally circular and about 2.9 to 3.7 inches (7.4 to 9.4 cm). Fox squirrels may make their own den in a hollow tree by cutting through the interior; however
column3: they generally use natural cavities or cavities created by northern flickers (Colaptes auratus) or red-headed woodpeckers (Melanerpes erythrocephalus). Crow nests have also been used by fox squirrels.Fox squirrels use leaf nests or tree cavities for shelter and litter rearing. Forest stands dominated by mature to over mature trees provide cavities and a sufficient number of sites for leaf nests to meet the cover requirements. Overstory trees with an average d.b.h. of 15 inches (38 cm) or more generally provide adequate cover and reproductive habitat. Optimum tree canopy closure for fox squirrels is from 20% to 60%. Optimum conditions of understory closure occur when the shrub-crown closure is 30% or less.Fox squirrels are tolerant of human proximity
column4: and even thrive in crowded urban and suburban environments. They exploit human habitations for sources of food and nesting sites
column5: being as happy nesting in an attic as they are in a hollow tree.

column1: Food habits of fox squirrels depend largely on geographic location. In general
column2: fox squirrel foods include mast
column3: tree buds
column4: insects
column5: tubers
column6: bulbs
column7: roots
column8: bird eggs
column9: seeds of pines and spring-fruiting trees
column10: and fungi. Agricultural crops such as corn
column11: soybeans
column12: oats
column13: wheat
column14: and fruit are also eaten. Mast eaten by fox squirrels commonly includes turkey oak (Quercus laevis)
column15: southern red oak (Quercus falcata)
column16: blackjack oak (Quercus marilandica)
column17: bluejack oak (Quercus incana)
column18: post oak (Quercus stellata)
column19: and live oak (Quercus virginiana).In Illinois
column20: fox squirrels rely heavily on hickories from late August through September. Pecans
column21: black walnuts (Juglans nigra)
column22: osage orange (Maclura pomifera) fruits
column23: and corn are also important fall foods. In early spring
column24: elm buds and seeds are the most important food. In May and June
column25: mulberries (Morus spp.) are heavily used. By early summer
column26: corn in the milk stage becomes a primary food.During the winter in Kansas
column27: osage orange is a staple item supplemented with seeds of the Kentucky coffee tree (Gymnocladus dioicus) and honey locust (Gleditsia triacanthos)
column28: corn
column29: wheat
column30: eastern cottonwood (Populus deltoides var. deltoides) bark
column31: ash seeds
column32: and eastern red cedar (Juniperus virginiana) berries. In the spring
column33: fox squirrels feed primarily on buds of elm
column35: and oaks but also on newly sprouting leaves and insect larvae.Fox squirrels in Ohio prefer hickory nuts
column38: and black walnuts. The squirrels are absent where two or more of these mast trees are missing. Fox squirrels also eat buckeyes
column39: seeds and buds of maple and elm
column43: they feed mainly on buds and seeds of elm
column46: eastern fox squirrels have the following order of food preference: white oak (Quercus alba) acorns
column51: fox squirrels prefer the acorns of bluejack oak
column54: and overcup oak (Q. lyrata). The least preferred foods are acorns of swamp chestnut oak (Q. michauxii) and overcup oak. In California
column55: fox squirrels feed on English walnuts (J. regia)
column60: they feed on eucalyptus seeds.In Michigan
column61: fox squirrels feed on a variety of foods throughout the year. Spring foods are mainly tree buds and flowers
column64: and seeds of red maple (Acer rubrum)
column66: and elms. Summer foods include a variety of berries
column72: seeds of sugar (Acer saccharum) and black maple (Acer nigrum)
column75: and unripe corn. Fall foods consist mainly of acorns
column80: and hazelnuts. Caches of acorns and hickory nuts are heavily used in winter.

column2: non-territorial
column3: and spend more of their time on the ground than most other tree squirrels. They are still
column4: however
column5: agile climbers. They construct two types of homes called ""dreys""
column6: depending on the season. Summer dreys are often little more than platforms of sticks high in the branches of trees
column7: while winter dens are usually hollowed out of tree trunks by a succession of occupants over as many as 30 years. Cohabitation of these dens is not uncommon
column8: particularly among breeding pairs.

column1: Fox squirrels will form caches by burying food items for later consumption. They like to store foods that are shelled and high in fat
column2: such as acorns and nuts. Shelled foods are favored because they are less likely to spoil than non-shelled foods
column3: and fatty foods are valued for their high energy density.They are not particularly gregarious or playful
column4: in fact they have been described as solitary and asocial creatures
column5: coming together only in breeding season.  They have a large vocabulary
column6: consisting most notably of an assortment of clucking and chucking sounds
column7: not unlike some ""game"" birds
column8: and they warn of approaching threats with distress screams. In the spring and fall
column9: groups of fox squirrels clucking and chucking together can make a small ruckus. They also make high-pitched whines during mating. When threatening another fox squirrel
column10: they will stand upright with their tail over their back and flick it.They are impressive jumpers
column11: easily spanning fifteen feet in horizontal leaps and free-falling twenty feet or more to a soft landing on a limb or trunk.

column1: Female fox squirrels come into estrus in mid-December or early January
column2: then again in June. They normally produce two litters a year; however
column3: yearling females may only produce one. Females become sexually mature at 10 to 11 months of age and usually produce their first litter when they are a year old.Gestation occurs over a period of 44 to 45 days. Earliest litters appear in late January; most births occur in mid-March and July. The average litter size is three
column4: but can vary according to season and food conditions.Tree cavities
column5: usually those formed by woodpeckers
column6: are remodeled to winter dens and often serve as nurseries for late winter litters. If existing trees lack cavities
column7: leaf nests known as dreys are built by cutting twigs with leaves and weaving them into warm
column8: waterproof shelters. Similar leafy platforms are built for summer litters and are often referred to as ""cooling beds.""Tree squirrels develop slowly compared to other rodents. At birth
column9: the young are blind
column10: without fur and helpless. Eyes open at 4 to 5 weeks of age and ears open at 6 weeks. Eastern fox squirrels are weaned between 12 and 14 weeks but may not be self-supporting until 16 weeks. Juveniles usually disperse in September or October
column11: but may den either together or with their mother during their first winter.

column2: fox squirrels have been known to live 18 years
column3: but in the wild most fox squirrels die before they become adults. Their maximum life expectancy is typically 12.6 years for females and 8.6 years for males. Because of overhunting and the destruction of mature forests
column4: many subspecies of fox squirrel (the Delmarva fox squirrel for example) are endangered. Another major cause of fox squirrel population decline is mange mite (Cnemidoptes sp.) along with severe winter weather.Relatively few natural predators can regularly capture adult fox squirrels. Of these predators
column5: most only take fox squirrels opportunistically. Predators include: bobcats (Lynx rufus)
column6: Canada lynx (Lynx canadensis)
column7: foxes (Vulpes vulpes and Urocyon cinereoargenteus)
column8: red-tailed hawks (Buteo jamaicensis)
column9: red-shouldered hawks (Buteo lineatus)
column10: great horned owls (Bubo virginianus)
column11: barred owls (Strix varia)
column12: and coyotes (Canis latrans). Former predators extirpated from most of the fox squirrel's range included cougars (Puma concolor) and grey wolves (Canis lupus). Nestlings and young fox squirrels are particularly vulnerable to climbing predators such as raccoons (Procyon lotor)
column13: opossums (Didelphis virginiana)
column14: rat snakes (Elaphe obsoleta)
column15: and pine snakes (Pituophis melanoleucus). In those states where fox squirrels are not protected
column16: they are considered a game animal.  Fox squirrels were an important source of meat for European settlers in the 17th and 18th centuries. They are still hunted over most of their range.

column1: Overhunting has been reported from small woodlots and public shooting areas in Ohio
column2: Michigan
column3: and Indiana.
